site_title: SingHaiyi FY14 net soars to $23.15m
summary: SingHaiyi Group reported a net profit of $23.15 million for FY14, up from $1.68 million in the previous year. Revenue more than tripled to $56.95 million, driven by property development income and investment property gains. The group's gross profit margin increased 2.8 percentage points to 39.3%, driven by cost reductions. Under new leadership, SingHaiyi diversified its portfolio with US market acquisitions and expects further contributions from existing assets and associated companies.

site_title: Bespoke Down Under
summary: In Australia, bespoke experiences await in Sydney and Melbourne. In Sydney, explore the Sydney Opera House on a private tour, sail across the harbour with a professional regatta crew, and climb the Sydney Harbour Bridge for a private experience. Nearby, Glenworth Valley offers outdoor adventures such as trekking, horse-riding, and camping. In Melbourne, take a guided walking tour of the city, brew your own Melbourne-style coffee, and view a musical or the Australian Open from a private suite. The Yarra Valley in Melbourne is also home to numerous wineries and entertainment venues, including Rochford Wines and Rayner's Orchard.

site_title: 68 Holdings' offer for Hotel Properties declared unconditional
summary: 68 Holdings' consortium, led by Ong Beng Seng and Wheelock Singapore, has declared its offer for Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) unconditional after crossing the 50% mark of HPL's maximum potential issued share capital. The offer price has been revised to $4.05, a 29.4% premium over the last traded price. The closing date of the offer has been extended to June 26, with no intention to extend it further. The consortium now owns or controls around 50.28% of HPL's issued share capital.

site_title: Tackling the complexity of data protection
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) will take effect on July 2, requiring corporations to keep customer data secure. Despite the public's focus on unsolicited calls and messages, data breaches beyond borders are a concern. eBay is under investigation in the UK for a data breach compromising millions of customers' details, and other companies such as AOL and Spotify have also reported unauthorized access. The investigation will test cross-border cooperation on personal data protection, with implications for the region.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Eastern Holdings reported a net profit of $23.05 million for FY 2014, up from $2.17 million, with revenue doubling to $26.6 million. Courts Asia's Q4 net profit fell 38% to $7.84 million, while King Wan Corp's Q4 profit declined 29% to $2.05 million. PEC secured $100 million in new contracts. Rexonic appointed two new independent directors, William Wright and Herbert Hoffstätter.

site_title: Swathe of ocean ruled out as jet crash zone
summary: Australia has ruled out a large swathe of the Indian Ocean as the final resting place of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 after a lengthy underwater hunt. The search in the area using a mini sub where acoustic transmissions were detected in early April is now complete, with no signs of aircraft debris found. US Navy officials have questioned whether the plane ever went to the area, citing unverified pings that may have been produced by the ship or electronics. The search will now move to a new phase involving sophisticated equipment to scan the unmapped ocean floor.

site_title: IMF warns Japan against over-reliance on monetary policy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned Japan against relying too heavily on monetary policy to drive its economic recovery, citing risks of asset inflation, financial sector problems, and currency depreciation. The warning came after Japan's household spending and industrial production fell in April, following the hike in the national consumption tax. The IMF said "more forceful structural reforms" are needed to sustain growth, and that transitioning to self-sustaining growth requires greater fiscal and structural reforms to avoid deflation and overburdening monetary policy.

site_title: Lufthansa eyes ANA cargo tie-up to cut costs
summary: Lufthansa is reviewing its cargo operations and considering a partnership with ANA Holdings to cut costs. The airline aims to quadruple earnings in its cargo business within two years, part of its broader goal to achieve record profit by 2015. With the arrival of larger passenger jets, Lufthansa is also reviewing its requirement for freighter aircraft, potentially reducing its need for freighter planes. The airline plans to lift operating profit to 2.65 billion euros by 2015, up from 77 million euros last year.

site_title: DBS PayLah! takes on mobile wallet market
summary: DBS has launched its mobile wallet, DBS PayLah!, allowing customers to send money to other DBS customers via mobile app, with daily transfer limits of $999. The service, which can be funded from a designated DBS savings or current account, aims to be more convenient than traditional Internet banking transactions. DBS expects the service to be more secure due to its limited access to customer funds, and plans to expand its mobile payment terminal for on-the-go merchants by the end of the year.

site_title: Tung Lok Restaurants' net loss for FY2014 more than doubles to $6.8m
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants reported a net loss of $6.8 million for FY2014, more than doubling from $3.2 million in the previous year. Revenue fell 4% to $77.9 million due to outlet closures and higher operating costs. The group attributed the loss to rising food, manpower, and rental costs, as well as a labor crunch in Singapore. To improve revenue and manage costs, Tung Lok plans to boost productivity through technology and streamline processes. The company did not declare a dividend and its stock closed at 17.5 cents.

site_title: Performing arts for beginners
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Singapore International Festival of Arts and its pre-event The OPEN feature performances and talks introducing various performing arts to beginners. The London Sinfonietta brings its acclaimed 20th-century classical music series "Listen To The 20th Century" to Singapore, condensed into four concerts. Greek tragedy "Medea on media" and "The Chorus; Oedipus" are also staged, with the latter being reimagined as a modern musical. Contemporary dance expert Richard Move discusses Martha Graham's legacy and performs her iconic solos, while Graham's documentary "Ghostlight" is screened. These events showcase a range of performing arts for beginners.

site_title: BP Singapore marks golden jubilee of its operations
summary: BP Singapore, a key oil refiner and trading hub, marks its 50th anniversary, having evolved from refining and retail operations to a leading commodities trader and knowledge centre in the Asia-Pacific region. Formed in 1964, the company has closed its refinery and sold off downstream assets, focusing on trading and supply activities. Today, BP Singapore performs vital knowledge-based functions, is a major player in Singapore's oil and gas trading hub, and employs 700 staff. The company's business activities include oil, gas, and finance trading, and serves as the regional headquarters for various industries.

site_title: May sees lower investor confidence in Asia
summary: Investor confidence in Asia decreased in May, with the State Street Investor Confidence Index falling 10.6 points to 104.4 points, indicating a lower risk appetite. This follows similar declines in North America, while Europe saw a 9.2-point increase to 111.2 points. Foreign institutional investors were more selective in Asia, with inflows into India and Indonesia, but outflows from Thailand amid growing political risk. This marks a temporary decrease in enthusiasm for the region's markets, with concerns of bubble territory in the US equity and Asian property markets.

site_title: Chief executive of SingTel's mobile ad unit steps down
summary: Trevor Healy, CEO of SingTel's mobile ad unit Amobee, has stepped down after just two years, succeeding Mark Strecker, previously Amobee's president and COO. Healy will stay on in an advisory role for a few months to ensure a smooth transition. The departure was not requested by SingTel, but rather Healy's desire to pursue philanthropic interests. Amobee's revenue under SingTel's group digital division has seen a 51.5% gain to $169 million for the financial year, despite the division reporting negative earnings.

site_title: Frustrating the audience
summary: Artist David Chan's exhibition "Context" aims to evoke strong emotions, particularly frustration, in its audience. The 35-year-old hopes that viewers will become invested in his works, which explore the human condition through art. The exhibition features a range of pieces, including sculptures from the "Anamorphosis" series and bold paintings of animals as humans. Through "Context," Chan seeks to encourage viewers to think critically about the art and themselves, applying the themes to their own lives. The exhibition runs at EY Asean Art Outreach until September 26.

site_title: Cantopop King ready to rule again
summary: Sam Hui, the Cantopop King, is set to continue entertaining his fans with his "What a Wonderful World" tour, which includes a family act featuring his sons and wife. The 65-year-old singer-songwriter-actor has enjoyed a successful career spanning over four decades, with 23 Cantonese albums and 26 movies to his name. Hui has been in semi-retirement since 2004 but has since bounced back to tour the world, releasing a new studio album in 2007. The tour will feature 37 songs, including Hui's evergreen hits and tributes to his departed Cantopop peers.

site_title: One Raffles Place reopens today after major makeover
summary: One Raffles Place, a Singapore shopping mall, reopens after a major refurbishment, introducing new brands such as H&M, Uniqlo, and Victoria's Secret. The mall, with a net lettable area of 98,500 sq ft, has a 90% occupancy rate. OUE shares rose 3.8% ahead of the soft relaunch. The mall's location attracts 259,000 working professionals and 10,700 international tourists, positioning OUE for stronger recurrent income streams. Swedish clothing retailer H&M is the first tenant to open, marking the mall's return to business.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The Singapore government will shelve $2 billion worth of projects to address a construction worker shortage. Alibaba acquired a 10.35% stake in SingPost for $312.5 million. The government may trim land supply for private housing in the second half of 2014. French electric car-sharing service Autolib is exploring a pilot program in Singapore. Meanwhile, China has eased curbs on foreign investment in joint-venture hospitals as part of a healthcare overhaul.

site_title: SingPost shares jump to record high on Alibaba deal
summary: SingPost shares surged to a record high after announcing a 10.35% stake deal with Alibaba for $312.5 million, with the counter reaching a day's high of $1.75. Analysts, including CIMB Research, praised the strategic pact, predicting SingPost's earnings growth potential and potential for further acquisitions. Some analysts even speculated that Alibaba could buy a larger stake in SingPost, including Singapore Telecommunications' 25% stake, citing the deal's value compared to Alibaba's planned US IPO.

site_title: Minimum $60 pay rise for low income
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore has recommended that employers continue paying a minimum $60 built-in wage increase to workers earning up to $1,000 a month, and an "equitable and reasonable" pay hike for those above $1,000. The government has accepted the recommendations, urging employers to consider the labour market's "challenging" conditions. The NWC also called for real wage hikes to stay in line with productivity growth, and suggested building wage recommendations into contracts for outsourced services.

site_title: S'pore bourse up four months in a row
summary: The Singapore stock market rose for the fourth consecutive month in May, increasing 1.8% to $967.86 billion, with gains across all industries except electricity, manufacturing, and agriculture. The mining/quarry sector was the top performer, gaining nearly 255% year-over-year. Nearly all sectors reported month-on-month gains, with the transport/storage/comms sector rising 6%. The billion-dollar club added two new members, bringing the total to 115 companies with a market value of $1 billion or more.

site_title: Banking on a themed edge
summary: New hotels in Singapore are incorporating unique themes to stand out from the crowd. Sofitel So Singapore, now open, features a Parisian-chic design with local accents, while Holiday Inn Express Singapore Clarke Quay boasts a green oasis atmosphere. Hotel Clover The Arts, a boutique hotel, showcases local art with individually themed rooms, each featuring murals created by local artists. These hotels demonstrate a focus on distinctive character, engaging guests and minimizing environmental impact. Room rates vary, with Sofitel So Singapore starting at $599++, Holiday Inn Express starting at $180++, and Hotel Clover The Arts starting at $235++.

site_title: Degustation options
summary: Singaporean chef Emmanuel Stroobant, a Relais & Chateaux master chef, has introduced a vegetarian degustation menu at his restaurant, offering a 5- or 10-course tasting experience for $128++ and $148++, respectively. The menu, crafted with seasonal ingredients and a focus on Japanese sensibilities, features dishes such as olive oil-pickled cherry tomatoes and parmesan ice-cream, and shoyu egg yolks paired with thyme salt and umami soil. Stroobant, who has adopted a vegetarian diet, aims to provide a haute cuisine experience for vegetarians and health-conscious diners.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Global financial standards body announces a change in revenue recognition, while Japanese Premier Shinzo Abe is set to deliver a reassuring message on his country's new security policy. Two Singaporean start-ups raised record Series B funding, and SingPost shares jumped to a record high after an Alibaba deal. In other news, Tat Hong Holdings' Q4 profit plummeted 77%, and China urged faster spending to boost its economy. The US economy contracted for the first time in three years, and Australia's organic exports may be impacted by a GMO contamination ruling.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q1 profit up 25% at RM159m
summary: IHH Healthcare reported a 25% year-on-year increase in net profit to RM$159.05 million for the first quarter, driven by higher in-patient admissions and revenue growth across its operations. Revenue rose 8% to RM$1.757 billion, with Parkway Pantai contributing a 14% increase to RM$1.04 billion. The group expects to continue registering earnings growth in 2014, backed by its strong balance sheet and cash flow.

site_title: Value-add main criterion for admitting foreign entrepreneurs
summary: Singapore has made it easier for foreign entrepreneurs to start businesses in the country, with relaxed regulations and a supportive government. The EntrePass scheme, which allows foreign entrepreneurs to start businesses, has seen a 23.1% decline in the number of holders from 1,300 in 2012 to 1,000 last year. However, experts believe that the quality of entrepreneurs, not just the quantity, is what matters. Foreign entrepreneurs like Phippo Hardegger, founder of Casa Italia gelato, and Anders Peter Juel Sauerberg, founder of Norbreeze Group, have found success in Singapore, with some expecting turnover to exceed $70 million this year. The government has revised EntrePass requirements to attract high-quality entrepreneurs, and experts predict that foreign entrepreneurship in Singapore will continue to rise.

site_title: SIA, JetBlue seek codeshare nod from Washington
summary: Singapore Airlines and JetBlue Airways have filed an application with the US Department of Transportation to launch a codeshare agreement, allowing passengers to combine flights and enjoy seamless connections. The partnership would put the "SQ" code on JetBlue-operated flights out of New York to 16 US cities and tag the "B6" code on five daily SIA flights to US destinations. The agreement aims to expand network options for customers, offering one-stop ticketing and baggage check-in. Approval pending from regulators, the partnership is seen as a move to fortify SIA's network and provide customers with more travel options.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines and US carrier JetBlue Airways are seeking to launch a codeshare agreement that would put the "SQ" code on JetBlue-operated flights out of New York to 16 US destinations - PHOTO: SIA

site_title: Meatless mainstream
summary: Chef Bryan Chou, formerly of Wowprime's meat restaurants, created a vegetarian menu for Sufood, a joint venture between Wowprime and Putien. Sufood offers healthy, value-for-money meals with dishes like the Star Pizza, Baked Potato Al Funghi, and Porcini Pasta. Chef Chou overcame the challenge of replacing meat flavor by incorporating seaweed and shiitake mushrooms, which he discovered naturally add sweetness and bridge the gap between meatless and meat-based dishes. Sufood aims to promote a healthy lifestyle concept, with plans to expand to 8-10 outlets in Singapore within five years.

site_title: Lesser lights of 1990 show their class
summary: A recent wine tasting of six non-First 1990 Bordeaux wines revealed that they have aged well, with 1990 Bordeaux considered the best among the three vintages (1988, 1989, and 1990). The wines, including Chateaux Cos d'Estournel, Grand Puy Lacoste, Gruaud Larose, Rauzan Segla, Magdelaine, and L'Eglise Clinet, showed varying levels of complexity and balance, with the exception of L'Eglise Clinet, which did not perform well. The tasting suggests that these wines are at their peak and should be consumed within the next few years for optimal enjoyment.

site_title: Tie-up may boost Alibaba's potential IPO valuation
summary: Alibaba invests $249 million in Singapore Post to expand its logistics network outside China, highlighting the value of growth in the region. The deal aims to create local Taobao marketplaces in Singapore and Malaysia, targeting young populations with broadband access. The move may boost Alibaba's potential IPO valuation, but the benefits are unclear, and the deal's symbolism may be ahead of its stock market debut. The investment underscores Alibaba's focus on expanding its network globally, particularly in developing markets with fragmented shipping.

site_title: NS proposals to cost $4.5b over 10 yrs
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen announced that implementing the Committee to Strengthen National Service's (CSNS) 30 recommendations will cost $4.5 billion over 10 years. The proposals include financial incentives, housing, healthcare, and education support for NSmen, as well as accreditation of skills acquired during NS. The measures aim to strengthen National Service and make it more responsive to the needs of "Millennial NSmen". The government has accepted the recommendations, with Ng describing the investment as a "significant commitment" to support NSmen and volunteers.

site_title: The right path for your heart
summary: A 50-year-old man underwent a CT coronary angiography (CTCA) scan after experiencing chest pain, which revealed near-total occlusion in two of his major heart arteries. The scan was less expensive and safer than traditional coronary angiography (CCA), but its accuracy varied significantly between hospitals. Research shows that high-volume centers with experienced doctors produce more accurate reports. The American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association recommend considering non-invasive alternatives to CCA, especially for younger patients, women, and those with low-risk profiles.

site_title: CPF provides peace of mind: Chuan-Jin
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) system provides peace of mind for citizens, with a constant stream of income in retirement, according to Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin. The system caters to housing, healthcare, and retirement adequacy needs, but has trade-offs, including limited flexibility. The government is studying ways to enhance the CPF Life annuity scheme, including keeping pace with the cost of living, and will announce more details in August. Minister Tan emphasized that any changes would prioritize the needs of future generations, not just current citizens.

site_title: SingTel spends $2m on data compliance
summary: SingTel has spent $2 million to comply with Singapore's Personal Data Protection Act, which comes into full effect on July 2. The telco expects to spend $500,000 annually on operating costs, including staff training and DNC registry fees. SingTel will launch a new online portal for subscribers to opt in or out of marketing messages, allowing for more specific preferences. Competitors M1 and StarHub have also invested in compliance programs, with M1 appointing data protection officers.

site_title: Swing Media posts record earnings of HK$83.13m
summary: Swing Media Technology Group posted record earnings of HK$83.13 million for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2014, driven by a 9.8% year-on-year increase in sales to HK$1.09 billion. DVD-R sales rose 4.5% and trading sales jumped 40.4%, while leasing income increased 45.8%. Earnings per share rose to 18.45 HK cents, and the group recommended a 0.15 Singapore cent per share final cash dividend. The company attributed its success to industry consolidation and reduced supply.

site_title: Tat Hong Q4 profit plunges 77% to $4.2m
summary: Tat Hong Holdings' fourth-quarter net profit plummeted 77% to $4.2 million due to a slowdown in the Australian economy and losses from Indonesian subsidiaries. Revenue fell 22% to $155.9 million, with the Australian business contributing significantly to the decline. The company expects a more balanced economy in Australia, with opportunities in residential and commercial construction, and is cautiously optimistic about its future prospects in FY2015.

site_title: Abe: Japan to help in ensuring peace in Asia
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged Tokyo's "utmost support" for Southeast Asian countries in maintaining freedom of navigation and overflight in the region. Abe emphasized the need for respect of international law and expressed regret over the failed bilateral communication mechanism with China. He urged China to resume talks to prevent unexpected situations and promote peace and stability in the region.

site_title: A master shows the way
summary: Acclaimed abstract painter Milenko Prvacki is showcasing the work of four of his students at an exhibition titled "Departure" at the iPreciation gallery in Singapore. The students, Jeremy Sharma, Hilmi Johandi, Luke Heng, and Filip Gudovic, are all emerging artists who have been mentored by Prvacki over the years. The exhibition features a range of artworks, including abstract paintings and figure paintings, that showcase the students' unique styles and techniques. Prvacki, who has sold his own works for up to $40,000, believes that his students have the potential to become successful artists in their own right.

site_title: Abe 'to deliver reassuring message' on security policy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to deliver a keynote speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, aiming to reassure nations on his government's new security policy. The policy prioritizes a proactive contribution to peace through Japan's Self-Defence Forces, aiming to lower regional tensions. Abe's visit comes amid rising tensions between China and Japan, as well as between China and some Asean member states. The speech is seen as an opportunity for Abe to explain Japan's stance on territorial disputes and promote adherence to the "rule of law."

site_title: SIA boosts Scoot's capital by buying $400m of its stock
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines has invested $400 million by buying 400 million shares of Scoot, its budget carrier subsidiary, boosting its capital. This investment will be used to fund the purchase of Boeing 787 Dreamliners, with deliveries starting in November. Scoot aims to compete with budget carriers that hold over 50% of the seats in Singapore. The move follows SIA's increase in stake in affiliate Tiger Airways Holdings Ltd through a rights offer last year, further solidifying its presence in the low-fare market.

site_title: Singing the stories of her life
summary: Spanish indie-folk singer Lourdes Hernandez, known as Russian Red, is set to perform in Singapore on June 13. Hernandez, 29, got her start in music at 13 and cites The Beatles as her biggest influence. Her unique sound combines retro-pop, indie, and folk elements, and is inspired by personal experiences and emotions. Hernandez has released three albums since 2008 and is looking to broaden her horizons, including learning to play bass and writing a diary. Tickets for "The Gathering with Russian Red" are available for $50-$70.

site_title: Bank lending limps along in April
summary: Bank lending growth in Singapore remained steady in April at 0.6% compared to March, with business and consumer loans growing at the same pace. The growth in the business loan segment, particularly in general-commerce financing, was a notable exception, increasing 6.9% in March before shrinking 0.8% in April. Total business loans grew 17.6% year-on-year, while consumer loans increased 6.8%. The sluggishness in bank lending growth reflects weaker growth in the business loan segment, with consumer loans also showing a slower pace of growth.

site_title: Return of Singapore's Orchid Artist
summary: Singapore's Orchid Artist, Tang Juey Lee, returns to the local arts scene after 23 years with a solo exhibition titled "Reunion" featuring 20 of his works. The Malaysian artist, known for his orchid paintings, counts Queen Elizabeth II as a collector and has sold all his paintings since starting in the 1970s. His exhibition parallels the friendship between Singapore and Malaysia, featuring a specially commissioned piece with both countries' national flowers. Tang has upcoming exhibitions in Melbourne and New York and is committed to his unique signature technique.

site_title: Two homegrown start-ups raise record Series B funding
summary: Two Singapore-based start-ups, GrabTaxi and Green Koncepts, have raised record Series B funding. GrabTaxi secured over $15 million, led by GGV Capital and Qunar, to accelerate expansion and product development in South-east Asia. The funds will also support social initiatives for taxi drivers. Meanwhile, Green Koncepts, a green tech company, raised "several million dollars" from existing and private investors to double its headcount, expand regionally, and invest in research and development.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust completes private placement of 88 million units at $1.835 per unit, raising $161.5 million. LionGold Corp reported a $89.3 million loss for Q4 2014, reversing a $2.7 million loss in the previous quarter. Willas-Array Electronics recorded a HK$25.38 million profit for FY2014, down from HK$41.29 million. CSC Holdings won a $21.6 million contract for the State Courts complex at Havelock Square.

site_title: Another EC site put up for tender
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has released a 99-year leasehold executive condominium site in Sembawang Avenue for tender, expected to yield around 620 residential units. The site is part of the first half 2014 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme and is adjacent to Skypark Residences. Property consultants expect moderate and realistic bidding, with prices ranging from $320 to $380 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The tender closes on July 10, with five to eight bidders anticipated.

site_title: Hawking formula for a World Cup win
summary: Physicist Stephen Hawking has developed a formula to predict England's success in the World Cup, citing favorable conditions such as a 3pm kick-off, red jerseys, and a European referee. According to Hawking's analysis, England has a 20% higher success rate in games wearing red jerseys, a 33% better chance in short-haul games, and a 59% reduced chance in games played at high temperatures. He also recommends a 4-3-3 formation and advises England to take a longer run-up in penalty shootouts to increase their chances of winning the tournament.

site_title: 3 plays stand out with their price movements
summary: In Singapore's market on May 29, 2014, three stocks stood out: Tiger Airways, GuocoLeisure, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Tiger Airways saw a 18% gain due to speculation about potential privatization by Singapore Airlines. GuocoLeisure hit a multi-year high amid speculation of a potential privatisation, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares plummeted 10.62% after a Chinese-listed rail company reported alleged illegal activities of its chairman, Ren Yuanlin.

site_title: Making waves with world's first portable solar generator
summary: AspectSolar, a Singapore start-up, has developed the world's first portable solar generator, the SunSocket Solar Generator, which automatically tracks sunlight to provide electricity. The device won the innovation award for portable power at the Consumer Electronics Show and is sold through Amazon.com. It has also created EnergyBar250, a battery pack that can charge from SunSocket or a grid. The company aims to target the US market, particularly American truckers with sleep apnea, who can use the device to power their CPAP machines without idling their trucks.

site_title: Rich Asian investors enjoy trading: Barclays Wealth
summary: Rich Asian investors, particularly in Singapore, are skilled traders in foreign exchange and derivatives, with 20 years of experience in financial markets. They are not typically gamblers, but rather savvy investors who understand financial markets and make informed decisions. Barclays Wealth, Asia Pacific, reports strong demand for derivative products, with sales increasing 12.4% from 2012 to 2013. The renminbi remains a popular currency play, and Indian rupee non-deliverable forwards (NDF) contracts are also in high demand.

site_title: Islamic finance chiefs to gather in Singapore
summary: Islamic finance chiefs will gather in Singapore for the 5th World Islamic Banking Conference to discuss capital market opportunities and develop products to tap into international markets. Despite rapid growth, the industry faces challenges such as adapting to robust regulatory frameworks and boosting talent. Assets of Islamic banks are expected to double to $3.4 trillion by 2018, with international financial centers like Hong Kong and Britain also getting into the Islamic finance act. The conference aims to strengthen international linkages and develop new financial products to support growing markets.

site_title: Japanese oil tanker listing after explosion
summary: A 998-tonne Japanese oil tanker, Shoko-Maru, listed heavily after an explosion and subsequent fire off the Japanese coast, near Hyogo prefecture, on May 29, 2014. Seven of the eight Japanese crew members were rescued, with four sent to hospital due to severe burns. One crew member, believed to be the captain, was still unaccounted for. The explosion is thought to have been triggered by a grinder used to remove paint, and the tanker was nearly empty of crude oil at the time of the accident.

site_title: Eschewing meat
summary: The demand for healthier eating and greener food has grown significantly, with restaurateurs embracing vegetarian cuisine as a viable business option. High-end dining restaurants like Saint Pierre and Beyond Veggie have seen high acceptance rates for vegetarian dishes, with sales exceeding expectations. Chefs are now experimenting with ingredients and modernizing traditional cooking methods, such as incorporating quinoa and agar-agar pearls into dishes. The trend is expected to continue, driven by growing food intolerance and increasing knowledge of bad food practices.

site_title: Chasen Holdings back in the black with Q4 net of $2.09 million
summary: Chasen Holdings reported a net profit of $2.09 million for its Q4 2014, reversing a net loss of $7.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 46% to $26.5 million, driven by a 46% increase in the relocation business segment. Earnings per share improved to 0.83 cents, up from a net loss of 2.95 cents in Q4 FY2013. The company expects the relocation segment to continue contributing significantly this financial year, with FY2014 net profit attributable to equity-holders at $2.5 million.

site_title: A peek at the flipside of her stage personality
summary: Actor Judee Tan is set to unveil a new side of herself with her upcoming solo show "Nu Men: The Wild Woman Sings" at The Esplanade Recital Studio on June 6 and 7. The gritty cabaret will focus on Tan's life as a performer, with songs chosen to reflect her experiences and emotions. The show, directed by Jonathan Lim and composed by Julian Wong, will showcase Tan's triple-threat abilities as a singer, actress, and dancer. This marks a departure from her comedic roles in TV satire and stage shows, and promises to be an eye-opening experience for fans.

site_title: Cellists from Croatia rock
summary: Croatian music duo 2CELLOS, consisting of cellists Luka Sulic and Stjepan Hauser, performed their first solo concert in Singapore, deviating from traditional classical music. They played a mix of pop and rock covers, including hits by Coldplay, Sting, Michael Jackson, Guns N' Roses, and AC/DC, showcasing their electric cello skills. The concert featured a drummer joining the duo on stage, and the audience responded enthusiastically to the high-energy performance. The duo's unique blend of classical and rock music has gained them international recognition, including a special guest appearance on the TV show Glee.

site_title: Old Chang Kee profit rises 21% to $6m
summary: Old Chang Kee reported a 20.8% rise in net profit to $6.02 million for the fiscal year ended March 31, driven by a 5% increase in turnover to $68.89 million. The snack chain's signature puff products remained the major contributor, accounting for 31.4% of total revenue. Gross profit margin increased to 62.2% due to improved production efficiency and revised selling prices. The group expects operating lease expenses, labor, and raw material costs to remain high in the next reporting period.

site_title: SingPost, privatisation plays underpin activity
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced a boost this week, driven by the government's transport sector revamp and the announcement that China's Alibaba is buying a 10.35% stake in SingPost. The Straits Times Index gained 17 points to 3,295.85, with turnover improving despite a decline in Yangzijiang's shares. Other companies such as AddValue Technologies, JES International, and Mirach Energy saw increased activity, but some analysts, like OCBC Investment Research, have expressed caution on SingPost's stock.

site_title: Countdown to World Cup
summary: The 2014 FIFA World Cup is just 12 days away, with 64 matches scheduled over the month-long tournament. The author is excited to catch as much of the action as possible and has even locked in a two-year contract to avoid the $112 World Cup subscription fee. The author favors Argentina to win the trophy, but notes that Lionel Messi's injury-plagued season may impact their chances. Brazil is the favorite to win, but the author believes the pressure of hosting the tournament could hinder their performance. Other contenders include Spain, Germany, England, Portugal, Belgium, Ivory Coast, and Mexico, with the author predicting a riveting and unpredictable tournament.

site_title: Coming Home, sensitive recall of a dismal past
summary: Coming Home, directed by Zhang Yimou, tells the tragic story of a family's struggle to overcome adversity during China's Cultural Revolution. The film follows a family's rebuilding of their past after the failed socio-political experiment initiated by Mao Zedong, resulting in the persecution of millions. Zhang, who came of age during the revolution, returns to the period drama genre, starring Gong Li as a middle-aged woman devastated by the Party's purge of her husband. The film explores themes of love, resilience, and the devastating effects of the Cultural Revolution, ultimately leaving a grim reminder of China's unfortunate past.

site_title: FTSE Asean Index to include more indices
summary: The FTSE Asean Index series will expand to include four new indices covering 90-95% of the region's investible market capitalisation. The new indices include the FTSE Asean All-Share Index, FTSE Asean All-Share ex-Developed Index, FTSE Asean Sector Indices, and FTSE Asean Stars Index. The expansion aims to increase investor understanding and interest in the region, following the establishment of the series in partnership with Asean finance ministers. The new indices will be calculated in accordance with the Industry Classification Benchmark, providing a more comprehensive representation of the Asean market.

site_title: Speedy Spider
summary: The McLaren 650S Spider is an updated version of the 12C, boasting a more powerful 3.8-litre turbocharged V6 engine producing 650 hp and 678 Nm of torque. The car features a revised design with a single-blade front air intake, dihedral doors, and a compact retractable hardtop roof. With a 0-100 km/h time of 3.0 seconds and a 0-200 km/h time of 8.6 seconds, the 650S Spider offers improved responsiveness and handling. The car also features a new exhaust system and "cylinder cut" technology, making it more engaging to drive.

site_title: Full convergence with IFRS slated for 2018
summary: Singapore-incorporated companies listed on the Singapore Exchange will adopt the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) framework by 2018, aligning with global standards. This move aims to enhance the country's standing as a financial hub and make its financial reports more comparable to those of international companies. The Accounting Standards Council (ASC) and the SGX will work together to facilitate the transition, with the goal of reducing costs for companies and improving the exchange's standing. This convergence was a strategic direction set by the ASC in 2009.

site_title: An old fairy tale told anew with a difference
summary: Maleficent, a live-action retelling of the classic Disney fairy tale, offers a fresh perspective on the iconic villain. The film, directed by Robert Stromberg, tells the story from Maleficent's point of view, played by Angelina Jolie, who brings depth and nuance to the character. The movie humanizes Maleficent, portraying her as a good-natured fairy who is betrayed by Stefan, a peasant with ambitions for the throne. The film's rich visuals and Jolie's performance make it a modern enchantment with much to admire, challenging traditional views of the character and inviting sympathy for the villain.

site_title: Booking of contract revenue set to change
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) have jointly released a new standard, IFRS 15, which changes the way companies recognize revenue from contracts with customers. Effective January 2017, the new standard requires a five-step model, more judgment, and estimates, affecting various industries, including telecommunications, technology, and real estate. The standard aims to improve comparability and quality of financial reporting, but companies may need to revise budgets, executive compensation packages, and IT systems to comply with the new standard.

site_title: House specials
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Three new homeware stores have opened in Singapore: Linen & More, Peace of Chic, and Mondays Off. Linen & More offers unique embroidered textiles and minimalist designs, while Peace of Chic features an eclectic mix of furniture and decor. Mondays Off showcases Scandinavian-inspired homeware and unique items from local artists. The stores offer a range of products, from affordable items like cushion covers and posters to high-end furniture pieces. Each store has a distinct personality and aesthetic, catering to customers looking for unique and stylish homeware options. They are located in various parts of the city.

site_title: B787 gets FAA nod for extended flying
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has approved extended operations for Boeing's 787 Dreamliner, allowing airlines to fly routes up to 5½ hours away from a landing field, up from the current 3-hour limit. The approval, known as ETOPS, marks a vote of confidence in the high-tech jet, which has faced scrutiny over its reliability and safety issues. The FAA's decision reflects the plane's "reliability history" and Boeing's effectiveness in addressing issues, and is seen as a positive development for airlines and investors.

site_title: GuocoLeisure shares up on more delisting talk
summary: GuocoLeisure shares surged 7.7% in intra-day trading, reaching a multi-year closing high of $1.155, amid speculation that the hospitality operator could be privatised. The company's shares have jumped 34% year-to-date, driven by speculation about delisting prospects. GuocoLeisure is set to remove its secondary listing from the New Zealand Stock Exchange on June 24, further fueling speculation. The company's UK hotel operations and Singapore market entries have also sparked increased corporate activity.

site_title: 49 SGX listed firms have business in Thailand
summary: About 49 SGX-listed firms with a total market value of $46.2 billion have reported business activity in Thailand, representing 7% of all listed securities. 19 firms have at least 10% of revenue from Thailand, with Thai Beverage and Total Access Communication reporting full-year revenue from the country. KrisEnergy reported 82.8% of its revenue originating from Thailand, resulting in a 37.1% total return loss. These firms offer an average total return gain of 7.4% and an average indicative dividend yield of 3%.

site_title: SGX: Trade with caution on Addvalue
summary: Addvalue Technologies saw its shares surge 40% to 13.6 cents, becoming the most actively traded stock, after the firm failed to explain the sudden price jump. The company is considering a $330 million sale of its subsidiary, Addvalue Communications Pte Ltd, to a Chinese firm, Secbase, sparking concerns over the premium price. Analysts point to recent acquisitions of peers and the company's limited disclosure as reasons for the unusual price movement.

site_title: Translating local dishes
summary: A new restaurant, Beyond Veggie, has opened in Singapore, offering a range of Asian-inspired vegetarian dishes with a healthier twist. The restaurant, which has over 20 outlets in Malaysia, translates local dishes into meatless plates using natural ingredients and creative alternatives to traditional meat-based ingredients. The menu features dishes such as wok-fried vegetables, sambal, and rojak, as well as egg-less tofu and desserts. The restaurant aims to cater to foodies of all dietary preferences, with a focus on consistency and quality in its recipes.

site_title: Include SingPost and others in any trading probe
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is investigating recent trading in the shares of SMRT, ComfortDelgro, and SingPost, amid allegations of insider trading following the government's transport sector reforms and Alibaba's acquisition of SingPost. Both SMRT and ComfortDelgro experienced significant price movements before the government's announcement, while SingPost's stock rose after a trading halt. The SGX is reviewing other recent developments, including the possible takeovers of STATS ChipPAC and RH PetroGas, as well as Olam International's takeover, which saw significant price movements before the deal was completed.

site_title: Korea's SK Group, Saudi firm forge US$595m S'pore JV
summary: South Korea's SK Group and Saudi Arabia's Sabic have formed a $595 million joint venture in Singapore to operate high-performance polyethylene manufacturing plants worldwide. The 50:50 venture will use SK's cutting-edge Nexlene technology to produce premium polymer products for industries like automotive, healthcare, and electronics. The joint venture will start with a plant in Ulsan, South Korea, and a second plant planned for Saudi Arabia, marking Sabic's second Far East manufacturing investment.

site_title: Real-time tracking of planes can take 2-3 years: ICAO official
summary: Global standards to track aircraft in real time may not be ready for 2-3 years, according to ICAO official Nancy Graham. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) is forming a group to come up with methods for tracking, with airlines implementing voluntary measures before any rules are in place. The move comes after the Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 mystery, with costs and implementation concerns raised by industry officials.

site_title: Biosensors' profit takes a hit
summary: Biosensors International reported a net profit of US$6.1 million for its fourth quarter, down 79% from the previous year, due to lower revenue and thinner gross margins. Total revenue fell 8% to US$81.6 million, with a 14% decline in interventional cardiology segment revenue. For the full year, net profit fell 65% to US$40.6 million, and revenue slipped 4% to US$323.8 million. The company appointed a new CEO and announced a transition to a more diverse and structured international organization.

site_title: KKR's $2.50 a share offer for Goodpack fair, decent: analysts
summary: KKR has made a $2.50 per share offer for Goodpack, valued at $1.4 billion. Analysts consider the offer "fair" and "decent," with CIMB Research noting it implies a multiple of 17.5 times the expected earnings for 2015. However, Goodpack's bondholders must approve the deal, and a majority of shareholders must vote in favor. The offer is subject to a scheme of arrangement, which requires a 75% stake from present shareholders to be successful.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings' subsidiary YSH Finance has increased its stake in Myanmar's Digicel Asian Holdings to 25% after subscribing for 420,000 new shares. CCM Group has revised its rights issue terms, expanding its investment scope beyond construction and property. Enviro-Hub Holdings and Soilbuild Construction Group are partnering on a $179.5 million Singapore construction project. A-Reit will become part of the Straits Times Index from June 4, replacing its current FTSE ST Mid Cap Index listing.

site_title: Fair-value gains boost Metro's Q4 bottom line
summary: Metro Holdings posted a fiscal fourth-quarter net profit of $43.8 million, boosted by fair-value gains on investment properties, despite a 97.3% fall in fair-value changes of short-term investments. Revenue edged up 4.3% to $49.7 million due to higher rental income at its property division. The company's full-year net profit increased 65% to $106.85 million, with earnings per share rising to 12.9 cents. Metro chairman Winston Choo said the group will continue to expand its footprint in China and add value to its existing portfolio through asset enhancements.

site_title: The French edge in engineering, tech
summary: French engineering and tech firms, such as Morpho, Safran, Airbus, Gemalto, and Alstom, are gaining global recognition for their expertise. Morpho's biometric identification technologies have applications in various sectors, including commercial, law enforcement, and democracy promotion. The company aims to double its 2013 revenues to 3 billion euros within five years. France is also attracting foreign investment, with Singaporean firms employing over 1,600 people in the country. French engineering and tech firms have established a presence in Singapore, with companies like Egis, Intersec, and Esker expanding their operations in the region.

site_title: Over $2b projects shelved to ease labour shortage
summary: Singapore's government has shelved over $2 billion worth of projects to ease a construction labor shortage, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong describing these projects as "less urgent". The decision aims to manage the number of foreign workers needed for these projects, saving around 20,000 to 30,000 workers. The government is also reviewing projects in the pipeline to spread out the demand for construction workers, and will continue to tighten the tap on foreign-worker inflow to boost productivity and restructure the economy.

site_title: Dr M not the remedy for Proton
summary: Malaysia's national carmaker Proton has failed to revive its fortunes despite the appointment of former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad as its chairman. Dr. Mahathir, who has been closely tied to Proton since its inception, has not delivered the fresh jumpstart needed to revive the company. Proton's losses have widened to RM840 million, and it faces mounting challenges, including dwindling market share and increasing debts. The company's prospects remain uncertain, and its future remains in doubt despite Dr. Mahathir's commitment to making it a success.

site_title: Results snapshot
summary: Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi services to California and Arizona, while FedEx partners with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robot deliveries in commercial areas. Meanwhile, Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share. The US stock market continued its rally despite new Trump threats, with some stocks even increasing by 6,000% due to Japan's succession crisis. Foreign investors also returned to Vietnam's markets after sweetened US trade terms.

site_title: US shipyard enjoys new lease of life
summary: The historic Philadelphia Navy Yard, 213 years old, has experienced a resurgence in shipbuilding thanks to the shale boom and the Jones Act. The yard, which was closed in 1995, has tripled employment and created a $978 million order backlog, with Aker ASA planning to build 10 petroleum tankers over the next five years. The Jones Act, which restricts US shipments to American-built vessels, has driven demand for shipyards, leading to increased employment and a significant boost to the US economy.

site_title: Spanish property stabilises, mortgage approvals rise
summary: Spanish home mortgage approvals rose 2% in March, the first increase in almost four years, as the country's property market stabilizes six years after the worst recession. House prices fell 3.5% in the first quarter, the smallest decline in over three years, and home sales jumped 45% in the same period. The economy expanded twice as fast as the euro region average in the first quarter, and experts predict the property market may be close to reaching the end of declines. Mortgage approvals are expected to evolve positively this year.

site_title: Union Properties plans to build cheaper hotels
summary: Dubai developer Union Properties plans to build around 1,000 hotel rooms in the next five years to cater to the demand for affordable hotels, addressing a shortage in the middle and lower end of the market. The company aims to build four hotels, using its own cash to start construction and potentially borrowing from banks or seeking equity partners. This move is part of Dubai's plan to almost double hotel rooms to 160,000 by 2020, with the goal of increasing annual visitors to 20 million by the end of the decade.

site_title: Alibaba in $312m deal to leverage SingPost network
summary: Alibaba has agreed to buy a 10.35% stake in Singapore Post for $312.5 million, marking the Chinese e-commerce giant's first strategic pact in the Asia-Pacific. The deal will enable SingPost to grow its e-commerce logistics business and strengthen its regional revenue stream. Alibaba will gain access to SingPost's extensive last-mile delivery network in the region, competing against US giants Amazon and eBay. The deal is expected to offset declining mail business revenue for SingPost.

site_title: The power of understatement
summary: Audi has upgraded the A8L 4.0 TFSI quattro, its flagship limousine, with visual and performance enhancements. The updated model features a new front end design, Matrix LED headlights, and "3D" tail lamps. The turbocharged 4.0-litre V8 engine now produces 435 hp, a 15-horse increase, with a 0.1-second reduction in the 0-100 km/h sprint. Additional features include a head-up display, 360-degree camera, and Park Assist. The A8L also boasts improved refinement, handling, and a more spacious interior, making it an even more refined luxury sedan.

site_title: Mitsui Fudosan share issue to raise 324b yen
summary: Japanese property developer Mitsui Fudosan plans to raise 324.5 billion yen ($4 billion) through an international issue of new shares to finance office and commercial building developments in Tokyo. The move signals Japan's property market is taking off after two decades of stagnation, with Tokyo governor Yoichi Masuzoe aiming to make the city the "best city in the world" by 2020. The share issue, which may issue 110 million shares, is seen as a significant sign of investor confidence in the market, with some warning of a potential "bubble" in property values.

site_title: Urban drive offers hope for China property
summary: China's property market is expected to remain healthy for the next 15 years due to the country's urbanization drive, according to China Vanke Co Ltd. The company's president, Yu Liang, stated that the slowdown in home prices is a sign of a shift towards quality and service, rather than speculation. Ratings agency Moody's has forecast flat to 5% yearly growth for the property sector over the next 12 months. Land transaction prices have become more rational, with developers bidding 40% higher than the asking price, and new housing starts have fallen 25.2% compared to last year.

site_title: Electric car sharing on the horizon
summary: French electric car-sharing provider Autolib' is exploring the possibility of piloting a similar program in Singapore. The company has discussed its plans with the Land Transport Authority (LTA) and has expressed confidence in its value proposition as a green transport alternative for customers who want to drive but don't want to own a car. Autolib' has already launched similar services in Paris, Lyon, and Bordeaux, and plans to expand to the US and London later this year.

site_title: Tender unveiled for first bus service package
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has unveiled the tender for the first bus service package, comprising 24 bus services from Jurong East, Bukit Batok, and Clementi. The package will be operated by SBS Transit and SMRT, with 380 buses to be introduced in 2016 and growing to 500 buses by 2021. The Bulim bus depot, set to be completed in 2015, will accommodate the buses and provide workshop facilities. The tender will be announced in the second half of 2014, with the implementation to start in the second half of 2016.

site_title: LCD Global offer: investors urged to base choice on timeframe
summary: Independent directors of LCD Global Investments advise short-term shareholders to accept and long-term shareholders to consider rejecting a takeover bid by RDL Investments. Provenance Capital notes the offer's financial terms are fair from a historical market share price perspective but acknowledges the offer price is below the current market value of LCD shares. The offer, valued at 17 cents per share, is conditional on RDL obtaining a majority stake in LCD and the company intends to remain listed. Provenance places LCD's net asset value at 27.2 cents per share, considering the valuation of its properties.

site_title: Signs of London market cooling: Nationwide
summary: Nationwide, a UK mortgage lender, warns that London home prices may start to fall this summer due to signs of a cooling market. The lender cited a natural correction as the cause, citing a drop in viewings and house price reductions. This comes as the Bank of England governor Mark Carney warned of a housing bubble posing a risk to Britain's economy. Nationwide's underlying profit more than doubled last year, and the lender has achieved a leverage ratio requirement ahead of schedule.

site_title: Consultants expect further paring of confirmed list supply
summary: Singapore property consultants predict the government will further trim land supply for private housing development in the second half of 2014, citing a slowdown in home sales and a substantial supply pipeline. The majority of consultants expect 2,000-4,400 units to be sold through the confirmed list, with 6,000-8,000 units on the reserve list. This is 10% lower than the first half of the year. Authorities may also offer commercial sites to speed up development in areas like Paya Lebar and Woodlands.

site_title: Automobile association pays $43m for East Coast building
summary: The Automobile Association of Singapore (AAS) has acquired a five-storey commercial building, Tides, on East Coast Road for $43 million. The building, fully leased with F&B outlets and offices, is valued at 4.5% gross yield. Located in District 15, Tides has 18 basement car-park lots and 22,927 sq ft of net lettable area. The purchase was approved by AAS members and brokered by DTZ. The building underwent a major renovation in 2012 and has no immediate redevelopment potential.

images.alt_text: Multi-faceted: The building is fully leased with food and beverage outlets on Level 1, shops on Level 2 and offices on the third to fifth levels

site_title: CSC swings back into the black in Q4
summary: CSC Holdings reported a net profit of $533,000 for the January-March quarter, swinging back into the black after previous losses due to provisions for doubtful debts. Revenue fell 13.4% to $111.2 million in Q4 and 8.6% to $487.1 million for the full year, mainly due to property cooling measures in Singapore. Gross profit margins fell to 6.9%, and the group expects the current financial year to be "extremely challenging" due to intense competition.

site_title: Police report made on jump in transport shares
summary: A blogger has made a police report alleging insider trading in the shares of transport operators SMRT and ComfortDelGro before the government's announcement of changes to the public bus framework. The report points to a sharp increase in share prices on May 20, a day before the announcement. The police are investigating the matter, but officials from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Singapore Police Force have declined to comment.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages turns around
summary: Global Yellow Pages reported a net profit of $5.13 million for the financial year ended March 31, reversing a net loss of $124.27 million in the previous year. Revenue decreased 9.8% to $27.2 million, mainly due to lower revenue for Search Solutions and the Personal Data Protection Act. However, revenue from Singapore River Tour and Taxi Services rose 81%. Total expenses fell 6% to $27.8 million, driven by lower printing and staff costs.

site_title: India's Jet plans big cost cuts after record Q4 loss
summary: India's Jet Airways, partly owned by Etihad, reported its biggest quarterly loss of 21.54 billion rupees (S$458.5 million) in Q4, with net loss for the year soaring to 41.3 billion rupees. The airline plans "stringent" cost-cutting measures, including network and fleet changes, as part of a three-year business plan to return to profitability. Jet named its new CEO, Cramer Ball, and will reconfigure planes and write down overvalued assets. The airline aims to establish a solid financial foundation and compete in the crowded Indian market.

site_title: Durable goods orders increase 0.8% in April
summary: US durable goods orders rose 0.8% in April, driven by a surge in defence capital goods and orders for fabricated metal products. Non-defence capital goods orders fell 1.2%, tempering expectations for a sharp rebound in economic growth this quarter. The increase in durable goods orders, but decline in core capital goods shipments, suggests some cooling in factory activity. This report adds to weak industrial production data, and may lead economists to trim expectations for second-quarter growth.

site_title: Thai junta appoints two anti-Thaksin men as advisers
summary: Thailand's junta has appointed two retired generals with palace connections, General Prawit Wongsuwan and General Anupong Paochinda, as advisers, solidifying the establishment's grip on power and further antagonizing former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra. The appointments come as the country struggles with a stagnant economy, with trade shrinking in April and factory output falling for the 13th consecutive month. The military has also relaxed a night-time curfew and aims to revive the economy, but faces opposition from anti-coup protesters and the challenge of reviving domestic confidence.

site_title: Aon nears 70,000 sq ft lease at SGX Centre
summary: A series of office leasing deals have been sealed or are in advanced stages of negotiations in Singapore. Vodafone has leased 30,000 sq ft at Asia Square Tower 2, while Jardine Lloyd Thompson is nearing a 40,000 sq ft lease at CapitaGreen. Insurance broker Willis has signed a 20,000 sq ft lease at SGX Centre 1, and Aon is expected to lease around 70,000 sq ft at the same location. Despite the activity, industry observers caution against increasing asking rents, as not all tenants are expanding.

images.alt_text: New tenant: The space that Aon is set to lease at SGX Centre 1 was previously occupied by the Singapore Exchange, which has moved the bulk of its operations to The Metropolis in Buona Vista. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Norway's oil rig workers reach wage accord
summary: Norway's oil rig workers reached a wage accord with employers to avoid a strike, following similar negotiations with other oil sector workers that broke down. The deal, reached by the Safe and Industri Energi unions, resulted in a financial settlement, with the unions pleased with the outcome. The agreement comes after a 16-day strike two years ago, which helped push oil prices above $100 per barrel and is set to avert a potential strike by ExxonMobil and GDF Suez.

site_title: No deadline extension for OSG share sale
summary: US Bankruptcy Judge Peter Walsh denied an extension for Overseas Shipholding Group Inc (OSG) shareholders to sell their stock, giving them until June 3 to find a buyer. The company plans to raise about $1.5 billion through a share sale, offering shareholders a choice between buying more shares, accepting $3 per share, or selling on the open market. Small shareholders, who hold less than 5% of the company's stock, face a difficult decision due to the company's low trading price of around $6.

site_title: Indian PM gets off to a good start
summary: India's new Prime Minister, Narendra Modi, has made a promising start, with his swearing-in ceremony marking a historic diplomatic coup by inviting leaders of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation and Mauritius. Modi discussed trade with Pakistani counterpart Nawaz Sharif, focusing on bilateral relations, and announced the formation of a special investigation team to probe black money stashed abroad. Modi has also reduced the Cabinet size and merged related departments into a single super ministry. However, challenges lie ahead, including reviving stalled economic growth and navigating India's complex bureaucracy.

site_title: Tycoon loses lawsuit against Trans Eurokars
summary: Singapore billionaire Koh Wee Meng, who sued Rolls-Royce distributor Trans Eurokars over a defective $1.4 million Phantom, has lost his lawsuit. Koh claimed a "loud moaning noise" and significant steering vibration after taking delivery in 2008, but the court ruled the car was of satisfactory quality and that any noise was normal for the Phantom. High Court Justice Judith Prakash dismissed Koh's claim with costs, stating the car performed safely and comfortably, and Koh's expectations were not met due to his failure to disclose noise and vibration concerns prior to purchase.

site_title: Keppel veteran Teo Soon Hoe to retire
summary: Keppel Corp announced the retirement of senior executive director Teo Soon Hoe after almost 40 years with the company. He will step down on June 1 and remain on board as a nominee director for certain companies. Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua will take over as chairman of Keppel T&T, while CFO Chan Hon Chew will be appointed to the board. Teo's departure follows a period of financial prudence and discipline, as stated by Keppel chairman Lee Boon Yang.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's finance sector faces potential threats from global market upheaval, despite its resilience. A police report has been made over a sharp spike in transport operator share prices, while cooling measures have impacted household wealth. Global private equity firm KKR is acquiring Goodpack in a $1.4 billion deal. The services sector saw a 4.9% increase in Q1 sales. China is pushing domestic banks to remove IBM servers, escalating a dispute over spying claims. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi faces easing trade spats with the US, a task inherited from his predecessor.

site_title: Govt finalising plans to extend re-employment age to 67
summary: The Singapore government is finalising plans to extend the re-employment age to 67, with Senior Minister of State Amy Khor confirming that more details will be released later this year. The move aims to help mitigate the effects of the tight labour market and encourage employers to re-employ workers above 65. The government also plans to review its guidelines on wage adjustment and engage voluntary welfare groups and businesses in the process. The changes are part of a broader effort to address the challenges of an ageing society, with Health Minister Gan Kim Yong urging a shift in mindset to celebrate longevity.

site_title: Valuetronics' full-year earnings up 88% at HK$147.9m
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 88% increase in full-year earnings to HK$147.9 million (S$24 million) due to growth in its industrial and commercial segment. Revenue rose 10.1% to HK$2.43 billion, driven by increased demand in both business segments. The company proposed a total dividend of 20 HK cents per share, aiming to pay out between 30-50% of net profit annually. Valuetronics plans to expand its customer base, invest in automation and lean manufacturing, and improve cost efficiency.

site_title: KKR to acquire Goodpack in a $1.4b deal
summary: KKR is acquiring Goodpack, a Singapore-based packaging logistics company, in a deal valued at approximately $1.4 billion. The acquisition will be made through a scheme of arrangement, with an affiliate of KKR offering $2.50 per share, representing a 23.2% premium to Goodpack's closing price on March 18. The deal requires approval from at least 75% of Goodpack's shareholders and will see Goodpack become a wholly owned subsidiary of IBC Capital, an affiliate of KKR.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Wilmar's subsidiary completed the subscription of 257.5 million shares in Shree Renuka Sugars at 20.08 rupees per share, now owning 27.72% of the company's equity. Global Yellow Pages acquired 672,000 shares in Yamada Green Resources for $116,600, increasing its stake to 20%. LionGold Corp is expected to report a pre-tax loss for FY2014 due to operational costs and impairment losses.

site_title: $1.2b govt IT tenders planned for this year
summary: Singapore's government plans to allocate $1.2 billion for IT projects this fiscal year, focusing on smaller and more focused initiatives in areas like cybersecurity, infrastructure, and data analytics. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) aims to co-source models with the industry to develop capabilities and solutions. A multi-modal approach will be used to accommodate innovation and respond to complex demands. The IDA will also break up tenders into smaller ones, allowing for faster completion of projects and providing opportunities for smaller companies to bid.

site_title: GE hopes CFM venture will boost its bid for Alstom
summary: GE's aircraft engine partnership with CFM International is being cited as evidence of its ability to work with France, supporting its $13.5 billion bid for Alstom's power generation and transmission business. CFM, a 50-50 joint venture between GE and French aerospace group Safran, has produced over 10,000 planes with its CFM56 engine, and its backlog of nearly 11,000 orders is expected to keep GE's factories busy for the next decade. France's economy minister has praised the CFM venture, suggesting that Paris may be more inclined to accept a balanced GE-Alstom partnership.

site_title: A wake-up call for Europe's politicians
summary: European politicians received a wake-up call in the recent EP elections, where far-right parties outperformed centrists, winning significant gains in France, the UK, and other EU member states. The National Front in France and UKIP in the UK topped the polls, while far-right parties in Austria, Denmark, Hungary, Germany, and Greece also secured seats. Despite centrists controlling the majority, the presence of extremist parties will impact EU-wide legislation and trade agreements. The economic crisis, including high unemployment rates and austerity programs, contributed to the rise of these parties, leading to a region-wide disillusionment with the EU's current governance.

site_title: Disposal gain puts Transcu in the black
summary: Transcu Group reported a net profit of US$4.53 million for the financial year ended March 31, 2014, after a US$15.9 million gain on disposal of subsidiaries. The company had previously reported a loss of US$64 million. No revenue was recorded in FY14, but earnings per share improved to 0.09 US cents. Transcu has disposed of its pharmaceutical division and sold its cosmetics business in Japan, and is planning a reverse takeover of Straits Construction to revitalize its business.

site_title: S'pore firms take longer to close books: survey
summary: A survey by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) and SAP found that Singapore companies take about 1.5 times longer to close annual and quarterly books compared to global peers, with average closing times of 27.9 days. Audit costs are also higher, at 0.12% of revenue, compared to 0.06% globally. The survey suggests that Singapore's role as a regional headquarters hub may be a contributing factor, and companies that adopt best practices through technology can achieve significant productivity gains.

site_title: Etisalat given US$500m for Maroc Telecom deal
summary: Abu Dhabi has granted Etisalat a US$500 million grant to support its acquisition of 53% of Maroc Telecom for 4.14 billion euros. The grant is part of Abu Dhabi's support for local firms' foreign expansion, but may raise concerns about the emirate's use of hydrocarbon wealth to subsidize state-owned businesses. The deal, valued at S$7.1 billion, is Etisalat's largest to date and will be repaid through a bond issue.

site_title: Seadrill to be top owner of North Atlantic Drilling
summary: Seadrill, the world's largest offshore driller, will remain the majority owner of North Atlantic Drilling, a rig firm controlled by shipping tycoon John Fredriksen, following a cooperation deal with Russia's Rosneft. The deal, signed until 2022, will deploy up to nine offshore rigs in Russia, with Rosneft potentially taking up to 50% ownership. Seadrill will retain a majority stake, with 70% ownership. The agreement is seen as a positive for both companies, despite tensions over the Ukraine crisis.

site_title: HSH plans to cut ship loans by quarter in bad bank unit
summary: HSH Nordbank AG, the world's largest ship financier, plans to cut its $12 billion in loans by more than one-quarter by 2016. The bank aims to reduce its shipping portfolio by 500-750 million euros per year through loan sales, mergers, and pooling distressed companies. This move follows the European shipping crisis, with container shipping facing a sixth year of decline due to a glut of vessels. The bank's restructuring unit has already reduced its portfolio by 4 billion euros since 2009.

site_title: POSH posts 76.3% increase in Q1 earnings
summary: POSH, an offshore support vessel operator, reported a 76.3% year-on-year increase in Q1 net profit to US$36.7 million, driven by vessel sales and lower cost of sales. Revenue fell 6% to US$52.9 million, while gross profit rose 28%. The company expects continued spending on exploration and production activities, leading to increased demand for offshore support vessels. POSH plans to upgrade or replace vessels with more sophisticated technology and expand into deepwater offshore accommodation.

site_title: US airports become biz meeting centres
summary: US airports are becoming popular meeting destinations for business travelers due to their convenience and productivity. With shrinking travel budgets and companies scrutinizing productivity, many companies are opting for airport conference centers instead of hotels. This trend has led airports to reconfigure areas not suitable for other concessions, offering meeting spaces and minimizing travel logistics. As a result, airports are becoming business meeting centers, with companies like Therese Hampton's Public Generating Pool utilizing these facilities for regional and district meetings.

site_title: Baja Ferries in talks to buy ailing SNCM
summary: Baja Ferries, a US-Mexico ferry operator, is in talks with French transport firm Transdev to buy a 66% stake in loss-making France-Corsica ferry operator SNCM. The proposal is part of Unishipping's efforts to restructure the company, which has racked up cumulative losses of 250 million euros between 2001 and 2013. Transdev's CEO, Olivier Diehl, will lead the restructuring process and seek a buyer for SNCM. The move comes after Norway's Siem Shipping withdrew its bid and Veolia's bid was also rejected.

site_title: Jason Marine profit up as operations revamp pays off
summary: Jason Marine Group reported a significant surge in revenue and earnings for its financial year 2014, with a 32.4% increase in revenue to $50.2 million. The company posted a net profit of $2.8 million, more than five times the previous year's $517,000. A proposed total dividend of one cent per share was announced, comprising a first and final dividend of 0.2 cents and a special dividend of 0.8 cents per share. The company's share price rose 40% to 25 cents, driven by better results and the proposed dividend.

site_title: SME development agency will provide a boost: McKinsey
summary: McKinsey & Company has suggested the formation of an independent SME development institution in Singapore to provide stable financing to the country's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMEs, which account for 99% of companies and 50% of the country's GDP, are struggling to obtain financing, with a 12.5% annual failure rate compared to 6.25% in Korea and 6% in Taiwan. The proposed institution would have the power to raise capital, extend different forms of financing, and develop targeted sectors or companies.

site_title: Women's say in family businesses
summary: Asian societies are shifting towards greater gender equity in wealth planning, driven by rising education levels and evolving corporate governance in family businesses. Wealth owners are increasingly considering jumbo life policies to ensure equal distribution of wealth among family members. This approach allows women to take on philanthropic roles and contribute to the family's social and intellectual capital. Trust vehicles, family constitutions, and councils are also being used to empower women and promote gender equity in wealth planning, particularly in countries with traditional inheritance laws.

site_title: S'pore's finance sector needs better resilience
summary: Singapore's finance sector faces challenges from global economic restructuring and needs to boost resilience to sustain stable growth. A report by McKinsey & Company suggests that the sector should focus on wealth management, fund management, and infrastructure finance to ride the growth potential of the region. The sector can tap into emerging trends such as rising affluence across Asia and the decline of global investment activities. With its strategic location and robust financial ecosystem, Singapore has the potential to stake a claim in specialised financing, particularly in infrastructure financing, which is expected to reach US$8 trillion over the next decade.

site_title: Opportunities aplenty in frontier markets
summary: Frontier markets, despite uncertainty in financial markets, remain a strong investment opportunity due to their high dividend yield, lower volatility, and low correlations to other markets. The 19 fastest-growing economies in 2013 were frontier countries, and these economies are expected to add $1 trillion in GDP over the next five years. However, strong country analysis and understanding of individual local markets are crucial to success, with challenges including the European financial crisis and the "Arab Spring." A macro-focused, top-down strategy and a strong stock-picking culture are necessary to invest in these markets effectively.

site_title: What's a healthy level of speculation?
summary: A regulatory regime perceived as overly strict may be hindering retail participation in the stock market, as it limits opportunities for speculative trading. Proponents argue that the authorities' actions, following last October's penny stock debacle, have driven retail investors away due to the lack of volatility and potential for quick profits. While some speculation is necessary for liquidity and volatility, a balance must be struck to ensure a level playing field, particularly with retirement savings at stake.

site_title: Leading role for Chocolate King in Ukraine crisis
summary: Ukrainian billionaire Petro Poroshenko, known as the "Chocolate King," claimed a commanding victory in the country's presidential election with 54% of the vote, surpassing his arch rival Yulia Tymoshenko. Poroshenko, who has a US$1.2 billion personal fortune, has been a pro-European businessman and has worked with both pro-European and pro-Russian camps. His business empire includes a television channel, a car plant, and a shipyard, and he has been a prominent figure in the country's protests against pro-Kremlin Viktor Yanukovych, who was ousted in February.

site_title: M'sia, UK firm release satellite data on MH370
summary: Malaysia and a British satellite firm, Inmarsat, have released satellite data on the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, providing hourly "handshakes" from March 8, when the plane disappeared. The data, released in response to family demands for transparency, suggests the plane went down in the Indian Ocean, off western Australia, nearly three months after its disappearance. Investigators believe someone shut off the plane's data links, but no suspicious activity has been found among the crew or passengers. Experts will now analyze the data to refine the search area and determine if any information was missed.

site_title: MPs offer ideas to improve CPF
