summary: Members of Parliament proposed ideas to improve the Central Provident Fund (CPF) system, aiming to provide enough savings for Singaporeans during retirement. MPs suggested a government-backed investment plan to track inflation, which could improve returns on CPF savings and reduce citizens' unhappiness with the changing Minimum Sum amount. The plan could help address the issue of only half of Singaporeans meeting the Minimum Sum requirement. The government has also promised to improve CPF savings and annuity schemes to ensure older Singaporeans have enough for their golden years.

site_title: Cut the VHF chatter, follow the rules!
summary: A joint guide, "Safe Passage: The Straits of Singapore and Malacca," has been launched by Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Bimco to promote best practices for shipping in the busy Straits of Malacca and Singapore. The guide emphasizes the importance of following International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (Colregs) and highlights the dangers of relying solely on VHF radio communication for collision avoidance. It cites recent incidents, including a collision in the East China Sea, where VHF radio communication contributed to the accident, as evidence of the need for stricter adherence to Colregs.

site_title: Emaar Properties to list malls unit on bigger bourse
summary: Emaar Properties, the builder of Dubai's Dubai Mall, plans to list up to 25% of its malls business on the Dubai Financial Market, a shift from earlier plans to list on Nasdaq Dubai. The listing is expected to raise 8-9 billion dirhams, one of the region's largest equity offers since 2008. The move is seen as a boost for the Dubai bourse, which has seen a recovery in the economy.

site_title: UK, Germany top foreign investment ranking: study
summary: Britain and Germany topped an annual ranking of foreign investment projects in Europe, with Britain seeing a 15% increase to 799 projects and Germany increasing by 12% to 701. France, while lagging, saw a 9% increase in foreign investments. The total number of foreign investments in Europe rose 5% to a record 3,955 projects, creating 166,300 jobs, down from pre-crisis levels. The US was the single biggest foreign investor, followed by Germany and Britain.

site_title: Cooling measures hit Bukit Sembawang's Q4 earnings
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 29.1% decline in net profit to $18.2 million in Q4 2014 due to the impact of property cooling measures and loan restrictions. Revenue rose 94.5% to $89.5 million, primarily driven by higher development project recognition. The developer attributed earnings decline to a "foreseeable loss" on its Paterson Collection project, citing a weakening high-end property market. The company recommended a final dividend of four cents and a special dividend of 12 cents per share for FY2014.

site_title: Ronaldinho home for US$15,600 a night
summary: Former Brazil and Barcelona star Ronaldinho is renting out his seven-bedroom mansion in Rio de Janeiro's Barra da Tijuca district for US$15,600 a night during the World Cup. The property features a swimming pool, gardens, and a stage, and is being advertised on Airbnb. Ronaldinho shared the listing on Twitter, stating it's for those who "don't believe" he's renting his home. The listing is priced at 34,350 reais a day, approximately US$15,600.

site_title: Modi sworn in as PM with message of inclusive India
summary: Narendra Modi was sworn in as India's prime minister, marking the country's first parliamentary majority in 25 years. Modi, a Hindu nationalist leader, has given India ample room to advance reforms. He invited leaders from South Asia, including Pakistan's Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, to his swearing-in ceremony, a gesture seen as a show of his global ambitions. Modi's message emphasized development, good governance, and stability, and he plans to streamline the Cabinet and appoint super ministers to coordinate better decision-making.

images.alt_text: Watch this space: Millions of Indians watched Mr Modi's inauguration live on television; his parliamentary majority gives him room to advance reforms. - PHOTO: AFP

site_title: Russia-China gas deal has huge global implications
summary: Russia has signed a massive gas deal with China, worth over $400 billion, which will see Gazprom supply 38 billion cubic meters of gas annually to China via the "Power of Siberia" pipeline. The deal, set to come on-stream by 2020, will make China Russia's second-largest gas market after Germany and significantly reduce Russia's dependence on European gas imports. The agreement has major implications for the US and EU, with analysts warning that sanctions against Russia could backfire and lead to higher gas prices in Europe.

site_title: Leveraged buyout loans likely to rise in Asia: Credit Agricole
summary: Leveraged buyout loans in Asia are expected to rise as companies mature and seek to grow through acquisition. The Asia-Pacific region saw a 67% increase in merger and acquisition activity to $312.4 billion in 2014, with 169 leveraged finance transactions completed in emerging Asia in the first three months of the year. Asian lenders are now ready to provide capital for leveraged buyouts, with $4 billion of fresh capital raised in the first quarter, according to Credit Agricole. This trend is expected to continue as companies mature and entrepreneurs seek to cash in on their success.

site_title: Boustead's Q4 profit dips on lower value of one-time items
summary: Boustead Singapore's Q4 net profit declined 8% to $25.5 million due to lower value of non-recurring items, despite a 1% increase in revenue to $513.7 million. The company proposed a final dividend of 7 cents per share, unchanged from the previous year. Boustead's order book backlog stands at $380 million, and it has a healthy net cash position. The group faces intense competition in various sectors, but plans to differentiate itself through design and build capabilities and strategic tie-ups.

images.alt_text: Boustead chairman and group chief executive officer Wong Fong Fui said competition was clicking higher in the real estate solutions space, compelling the group to differentiate itself with its design and build capabilities - PHOTO: BOUSTEAD SINGAPORE LIMITED

site_title: Plant cutback hurts output, raises questions
summary: Singapore's industrial production growth slowed to 4.6% in April, down from March and February's double-digit expansions, due to a surprise 8.8% year-on-year contraction in the semiconductor sector, the largest contributor to manufacturing output. The drop, attributed to a single company, has raised questions about the competitiveness of the economy and the competitiveness of the electronics sector. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic about the outlook for the electronics sector, citing improving purchasing managers' index from the US and a steady US semiconductor book-to-bill ratio.

site_title: Temasek may get cheaper financing for Olam: analyst
summary: Temasek Holdings, a unit of Singapore investment company Temasek Holdings, may be able to cut annual borrowing costs for Olam International, a global agribusiness company, after a change in ownership control. The takeover by Breedens Investments Pte, a unit of Temasek, has narrowed spreads on Olam's bonds by 147 basis points, resulting in a $100 million annual cost reduction. Analysts expect Temasek's ownership to provide comfort to bankers and creditors, leading to lower refinancing rates for Olam's long-term debt.

site_title: Closer ties between finance and HR make for better bottom line
summary: EY's latest study found that companies with closer ties between their CFOs and CHROs experience higher earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) growth and stronger human capital issues, such as employee engagement and productivity. 41% of "high-performing" companies reported Ebitda growth over 10%, compared to 14% of non-high performers. This collaborative relationship involves more time spent on finance and HR integration, strategic workforce planning, and analytics to better understand the workforce.

site_title: China seeks tie-up with Vale to tranship ore
summary: China is exploring a partnership with Brazilian mining major Vale to tranship iron ore from giant vessels to smaller ones, as a ban on large ships docking at Chinese ports continues. The ban, due to size restrictions, has frustrated Vale's attempts to reduce freight costs and compete with Australian rivals. Ambassador Li Jinzhang stated that discussing and resolving the issue, including transhipment options, is of interest to China's transport department. Transhipment could save Vale around US$7 a tonne, reducing their transportation costs. Technical issues remain as a major obstacle to the Valemax ships docking at Chinese ports.

site_title: China property developers go down-market
summary: Chinese property developers, such as Franshion Properties, are shifting their focus from high-end developments to lower-end coffee shops and restaurants due to a crackdown on official corruption and extravagance. The decision comes as consumption per head among business clients has dropped by 30-40% since 2012, forcing developers to adapt to the new environment. Other luxury developers, such as Shanghai Xintiandi and Soho China, are also adjusting their tenant mix to target middle-market consumers. The introduction of a property registration system in June is expected to further weigh on market supply.

site_title: Ser Luck assures SMEs on economic transition
summary: Singapore's government is committed to supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) during the country's economic transformation. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Teo Ser Luck assured SMEs of all necessary assistance to navigate this period. The government will facilitate collaboration with large organizations, provide productivity support, and expand its network of SME centers. The government has already committed over half of the National Productivity Fund to SMEs and set aside $300 million for the next three years to support SME restructuring.

site_title: Miners lock in shipping costs as freight rates revive
summary: Global miners and commodity traders are locking in favorable shipping costs ahead of a potential freight market recovery. Shipowners have ordered large vessels, and demand for capesize ships is expected to rise due to increased iron ore deliveries to China, which is expected to boost demand for larger ships. Companies like Anglo American and Rio Tinto are adapting their shipping strategies, including hiring capesize ships for longer periods and using forward freight agreements to manage risk.

site_title: S'pore faces imminent hotel room shortage
summary: Singapore is expected to face a hotel room shortage from 2014 to 2018, with projected hotel occupancies rising from 80% to 91%. The hotel pipeline is expected to add only 11,147 rooms, about 20% of the existing stock. New attractions and events, such as the Singapore Sports Hub and SEA Games, are expected to boost tourism growth, but hoteliers may raise room rates due to the shortage. The government is urged to review its policy and release more hotel sites for sale under the government land sales programme to address the issue.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: A semiconductor player in Singapore reduced production, ending double-digit growth in factory output. The Russian-China gas deal has significant implications for the US and EU. The government acknowledges the economic transformation's challenges for SMEs. Meanwhile, Japan-China tensions have not affected economic ties, and Boustead's profit fell 8% due to non-recurring items. China has cut ties with American consulting firms, and EU critics won big in European Parliament polls. US jobless claims have fallen unexpectedly, and Chinese property shares surged on reports of a sector revival.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Key economic developments include the success of Singapore's property cooling measures, Thailand's junta focusing on economic growth, and France seeking foreign investment. Investors remain optimistic despite structural issues in France. In the US, weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly. China has introduced new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, while the country's property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Meanwhile, Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year.

site_title: Household wealth takes knock as HDB values fall
summary: Singapore's household wealth took a hit as HDB flat values fell 0.7% to $412.8 billion in 2013, marking the first year-on-year decline since 2005. Despite a 2.4% increase in HDB dwellings and a slight rise in ownership, the property market softened, leading to slower growth in household assets. Experts predict further declines in resale HDB prices, which could impact household balance sheets, but note that most households with paid-off mortgages are unlikely to be affected. The decline in asset prices may hurt those who have pledged assets for loans, but the risk of households falling into negative equity is now remote.

site_title: Air Berlin mulling splitting in two: report
summary: Air Berlin's management is considering splitting the airline into two units, with one focusing on traditional scheduled flights and the other on tourist destinations. The move, reportedly being examined by senior vice president Detlef Altmann, aims to improve the company's performance after five years of annual losses due to rapid expansion and debt. The airline, which owns a 29.2% stake by Etihad, is looking to restore profitability through a fundamental restructuring. The exact details of the proposed split are not provided.

site_title: Strong sales lift Yongmao's Q4, full-year earnings
summary: Yongmao Holdings, a tower crane manufacturer, reported a surge in fourth-quarter and full-year earnings, driven by strong demand in various geographic segments. The company's net profit more than doubled to 51.3 million yuan, with revenue growing 35.2% to 909.6 million yuan. Sales in China and emerging markets like the Middle East, US, and Europe showed significant growth. The company also recommended a final dividend of half a Singapore cent per share and expressed confidence in its growth prospects, citing government approvals for infrastructure projects in China and expansion plans in emerging economies.

site_title: KSH full-year earnings up 22.8% at $44.5m
summary: KSH Holdings reported a 22.8% increase in net profit to $44.5 million for the full year ended March 31, 2014, driven by higher construction revenue and sales of development property in Singapore and China. Revenue rose 40.1% to $324.48 million, with construction segment revenue growing 38.6% and development property sales surging 62.9%. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.75 cents per share and warned of potential cost increases in FY2015.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines to sell 15% stake to foreign investors
summary: Vietnam Airlines plans to sell up to 15% of its stake to foreign investors, with an initial public offering (IPO) in September, as part of the government's efforts to accelerate the overhaul of state-owned companies and spur economic growth. The airline is valued at $3.3 billion and is among over 400 state-run companies to be equitized by the end of next year. The sale is expected to kick-start the government's push for share sales of other state companies, with a successful offering seen as a confidence booster for investors.

site_title: 2014 'not an exciting year' for Asean currencies
summary: Asean currencies are expected to remain flat in 2014 due to low interest rates, according to Leong Sook Mei, Asean head of global markets research at The Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ. The Singapore dollar is forecast to end the year at $1.26 against the US dollar, while the Indonesian rupiah may depreciate to 11,900 to one US dollar. The Thai baht is expected to fall slightly, while the Malaysian ringgit may appreciate slightly. In contrast, the Indian rupee is expected to continue its appreciation, ending the year around 55.

site_title: Japan-China economic ties not affected: economist
summary: Japan's economic ties with China remain unaffected despite rising tensions, according to a senior economist at The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ. The economic relationship is not influenced by the political relationship, with Japan's firms continuing to operate in China. The country's second-largest investment destination in Asia, China received $10.8 billion in Japanese investments in 2013. Japan's economic recovery is steady, driven by "Abenomics" and a tight labor market, with growth expected to be positive at 1.2% in 2014, despite a consumption tax hike.

site_title: Another incident between China, Japan fighter jets
summary: China's fighter jets came within 30 meters of a Japanese plane over the East China Sea, prompting a diplomatic protest from Japan. The incident occurred in airspace near disputed territories, where both countries' air defense identification zones overlap. China claims the area and had established the zone unilaterally last year. Japan's defense minister described the incident as "outright over the top," warning of the dangers of miscalculation and accident, which could escalate into a shooting war.

site_title: Back to the future of quarterly reporting
summary: Singapore's 10-year-old quarterly reporting regime is under review amid recent EU and UK developments. Critics argue the $75 million market capitalization threshold is too low, affecting small-cap companies, and the single-day test is unstable. The regime's implementation is also questioned, with concerns over the contents of quarterly reports, including the inclusion of non-financial measures to combat short-termism. The Singapore Institute of Directors recommends reviewing the philosophy and purpose of quarterly reporting and making adjustments to its implementation.

site_title: Thai coup leader threatens crackdown
summary: Thai coup leader General Prayuth Chan-ocha has been formally endorsed by the king as head of a military council, which will run the country. He warned of using force if protests flare up again, but hopes to hold elections soon. The military has taken custody of politicians, activists, and others since seizing power on May 22. Small crowds continue to gather in opposition, but there have been no serious clashes. The military is focusing on ending dissent and getting the economy back on track, with shares in building contractors rising on expectations of infrastructure projects.

site_title: Adjust expectations as equity returns are low, investors told
summary: Investors are advised to adjust their expectations for stock market returns, as moderate returns are expected due to low inflation. Bill Maldonado, HSBC Global Asset Management's chief investment officer, predicts 6% real returns on top of inflation over the next decade. Investors seeking higher returns must be prepared to take on significant risks, such as using leverage. Asian bond markets, particularly those in North Asia, are considered a good bet, while those in Asean are seen as overvalued. The Asian local currency bond market has posted a positive return every year since 2001, except last year.

site_title: Demand for private jets takes off as prices fall
summary: Demand for private jets has increased as prices have fallen due to online facilities, fleet efficiency, and competition. The cost of a private jet flight can now be as low as 550 euros (S$939) an hour, with some companies offering "empty legs" for up to 75% lower prices. Technology is playing a key role in matching supply and demand, providing customers with greater transparency and cost-effectiveness. Companies such as PrivateFly and NetJets are seeing growth in the market, with over 500 operators and 2,500 aircraft in the European charter market alone.

site_title: Growing data sources plague S'pore firms: IDC
summary: Singapore companies struggle to manage growing data sources, with data creation rates exceeding 20-50% annually. The variety of data from different sources, including social media, machine data, and file data, is exacerbating the issue. To address this, companies are looking into single, unified data management platforms and cloud storage solutions to better track and leverage their data. Proper data management can help reduce costs and improve regulatory compliance, with companies prioritizing data storage based on usage and cost.

site_title: Q&M strikes partnership with IMC Group
summary: Singapore-based Q&M Dental Group has secured a 10% stake in its shares worth $29.1 million after a healthcare private equity fund seeded by IMC Group, Heritas Helios Investments (HHI), acquired the shares. HHI has also entered into a strategic partnership with Q&M, with a two-year call option to acquire an additional 63 million shares. The deal is valued at $30 million, which will be used for working capital and strategic activities. Q&M aims to expand operations in Malaysia and China, with plans to have 60 dental outlets in Singapore by 2015.

site_title: A 35-hour workweek all over France? Not quite
summary: France's 35-hour workweek, a widely debated topic, is not as restrictive as it seems. The actual limit is a bar above which overtime or leave can be claimed, not a fixed 35-hour limit. Managers work an average of 44.6 hours a week, while employees work 36.5. The system provides benefits such as free medical coverage, vacation time, and social security, which may offset the lower take-home pay. French employers like Esker find it advantageous to recruit in France, particularly in fields like engineering and programming, due to the cost of living and access to skilled workers.

site_title: Spanish property market shows signs of recovery
summary: The Spanish property market is showing signs of recovery, with an increase in sales indicating that home prices may be stabilizing. A 45% jump in home sales in the first quarter is attributed to pent-up demand from buyers who have been holding off due to economic uncertainty. Economists forecast that house prices and mortgage approvals will show the smallest decline since 2010, with the GDP data likely confirming economic expansion accelerated to 0.4% from 0.2% at the end of last year.

site_title: 70-80% of Trilive to be dual-key units
summary: Roxy-Pacific's new freehold project, Trilive, in Tampines Road will feature 70-80% dual-key units, with pricing starting at $765,000 for a one-bedroom unit and $1.72 million for a four-bedroom unit. The project's 222 units will be available within a month, with a median price of $1,554 per square foot, comparable to another freehold project in Kovan. The dual-key concept is expected to attract yield-seeking investors and families, with a focus on 3G living, a concept of three-generation living, to differentiate the project from other developments.

site_title: Overseas Shipholding nears deal to advance exit plan
summary: Overseas Shipholding Group, a leading tanker holding company, is nearing a deal with noteholders to advance its bankruptcy exit plan. A US$1.5 billion rights offering will allow existing shareholders to purchase newly issued stock, backed by US$1.35 billion in financing from Jefferies Finance. The deal, which includes a US$1 billion financing, is expected to clear the way for creditors to vote on the exit plan, which is also backed by US$500 million in new debt. The plan aims to exit bankruptcy and return to normal operations.

site_title: Markets shrug off Thailand's coup
summary: Thailand's military takeover has had a minimal impact on the Singapore market, with key stocks remaining largely unchanged. Analysts expect the coup to bring near-term stability to Thailand, although concerns persist about the country's economic future. The Thai economy contracted 0.6% in the first quarter, and a second negative quarter is predicted. However, some analysts are optimistic that the coup could steer Thailand back on the right track, creating a stable social environment that could support market sentiment and ensure a successful democratic election in Q3 2014.

site_title: Cisco confident of bouncing back in Asia
summary: Cisco remains optimistic about long-term growth in the Asia Pacific region, despite a tough quarter in the APJC (Japan, China, and Korea) region. The company's APJ president, Irving Tan, notes that the Asean region grew in double digits and Korea saw good growth, while developed markets like Singapore and Japan have established infrastructure and progressive governments investing in cloud and analytics. Tan highlights the need for businesses to understand market readiness and network connectivity to offer applications that help the economy, citing opportunities such as urbanization, the Internet of Everything, and a tech-savvy workforce.

site_title: Reforms first, then polls, says Prayuth
summary: Thai army chief General Prayuth Chan-ocha has taken over the country after a coup, seizing power from the populist government. He announced reforms are needed before an election, citing the need for economic, social, and political changes. Gen Prayuth said he would return power to the people if the situation remains peaceful. Opposition to the takeover was evident, with several hundred protesters gathering despite a ban on gatherings of five or more people. The military has imposed martial law, censored the media, and imposed a nationwide curfew.

site_title: Zero-growth France woos foreign investment
summary: France, with a bloated public sector and restrictive labor laws, is trying to attract foreign investment despite its stagnant economy. The country has set a one percent growth target for 2014, but its first-quarter GDP growth was zero. Despite this, French officials argue that the country is competitive and offers attractive assets, including a well-educated population and low energy costs. France is partnering with other sovereign wealth funds to invest in real estate and infrastructure projects, and is targeting Singapore as a potential partner. However, critics argue that the government's efforts to trim its public sector and reform labor laws are needed to stimulate growth.

site_title: Mobile marketing takes centre stage
summary: Global mobile advertising expenditure is expected to reach US$18 billion, up from US$13.1 billion last year, according to Gartner. Mobile marketing is gaining traction, with North America and Europe leading the growth, surpassing the Asia-Pacific region. The Mobile Marketing Association's Forum highlighted the need for marketers to leverage mobile data and technology to engage with consumers effectively. Keynote speakers discussed the disruptive role of mobile Internet, the evolution of brands, and the importance of high-quality mobile creatives.

site_title: Cisco's big push into cloud
summary: Cisco, the world's largest networking company, is shifting its focus to cloud computing and data centers in response to the rapid pace of change in the IT industry. Chairman and CEO John Chambers warned that the company must reinvent itself within the next five years to stay relevant. Cisco aims to create a "Star Alliance" of cloud service providers, partnering with companies like Dimension Data and Sungard Availability Services to deliver cloud services. The company also plans to spend over $1 billion on its Intercloud platform, which will provide a global cloud computing platform. This move is seen as a response to the growing threat of software-defined networking (SDN) and the Internet of Things (IoT).

site_title: Thai junta, economic chiefs discuss protecting growth
summary: Thailand's military junta, led by Prayuth Chan-Ocha, met with economic officials to discuss measures to safeguard the country's growth amid a post-coup economic downturn. The junta dissolved the Senate, removing the last democratic institution, and imposed martial law. The king is expected to endorse Prayuth as leader of the military council, further solidifying the military's grip on power. The economy, which shrank 0.6% in the first quarter, faces challenges including delayed payments to farmers and a nationwide overnight curfew discouraging tourists.

site_title: S&P affirms S'pore's strong credit ratings
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has reaffirmed Singapore's strong credit ratings, assigning a triple A long-term rating and A-1+ short-term rating. The agency praises the country's fiscal and external strengths, effective policymaking, and political stability. However, it warns that Singapore's small and open economy, high export exposure, and vulnerability to economic shocks present some risks to its credit profile. The outlook remains stable, with less than a one-in-three probability of a rating cut in the next two years, due to the country's robust reserves, flexible policy responses, and projected fiscal surpluses.

site_title: The perks of recreational asceticism
summary: A growing trend among wealthy Singaporeans involves intentionally depriving themselves of non-essential spending for a period, known as a "financial fast." Inspired by religious and scientific experiments, this practice aims to boost health, longevity, and mental clarity. Participants cut back on unnecessary expenses, find ways to survive on minimal resources, and redirect their spending towards meaningful activities. Proponents argue that this approach can lead to a better quality of life, increased joy in simple things, and a sense of personal growth. By temporarily sacrificing financial indulgences, individuals can develop a healthier relationship with money and cultivate a more fulfilling lifestyle.

site_title: An eye on growing its landbank
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited, a global property player, aims to grow its landbank through moderate bids, tap its strength in mixed-use projects, and scale up its hospitality arm. The company has acquired several properties, including Hotel Porta Marina in Barcelona and serviced residences in Germany, and is considering a hospitality fund to manage acquired assets. Frasers Hospitality Trust, set to list next month, will have an initial portfolio of six serviced residences and six hotels, with the group seeking to increase its investment properties to match development properties in the long run.

site_title: Hawker fare gets upscale touch
summary: The Clifford Pier, a luxurious eatery in Singapore, attempts to elevate traditional hawker fare with designer Andre Fu's interpretation of old-world glamour. The restaurant serves a variety of hawker favorites, including char kway teow, kueh pie tee, and rickshaw noodles, but the dishes are often inconsistent, with portion control issues and overly sweetened sauces. Despite this, the restaurant's friendly service staff and upscale atmosphere make it an enjoyable experience, with some standout dishes like porchetta and kaya ice cream. Overall, the restaurant scores 6.5 out of 10.

site_title: CPFIS-included funds up marginally in Q1
summary: CPFIS-included funds rose 0.32% in Q1, driven by a 1.43% gain in bond funds, outperforming equity and mixed asset funds. This pattern suggests risk aversion, with investors opting for safer assets. Experts attribute this to low interest rates and ongoing global uncertainties, particularly in Europe and the US. Over the past year, CPFIS funds averaged a 6.31% return, with equity funds outperforming bond funds by 8.55%.

images.alt_text: CPF Investment Scheme-included funds rose a marginal 0.32 per cent in the first quarter of this year, following positive increases in the last two consecutive quarters - PHOTO: ST

site_title: Singapore to maintain sound, sustainable fiscal system: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam of Singapore pledged to maintain a sound and sustainable fiscal system despite rising expenditures, particularly in healthcare and infrastructure. The government aims to ensure sustainable spending through judicious resource allocation and efficient public sector management. To achieve this, Singapore will build up its revenues to meet future spending needs, while also enhancing the ease of doing business and promoting innovation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will remain vigilant and guard against financial risks, including those posed by global financial volatility and potential shifts in investor sentiment.

site_title: Perfect performance fit
summary: A new Callaway Performance Centre (CPC) in Singapore has opened, allowing golfers to customize and pick up their clubs and golf balls within a day or two. Located in Big Fish Golf's fitting studio, the CPC offers state-of-the-art facilities for club-fitting and golf ball fitting. The center, the first in South-east Asia, aims to provide premium services to avid golfers, with Callaway managing director Leighton Richards stating that the demand for custom-made clubs is growing. The CPC also offers a unique golf club fitting module using RFID technology, allowing customers to scan their data and preferences.

site_title: Transport sector the week's main driver
summary: Transport sector stocks dominated the market this week, with SMRT, Comfort Delgro, and SBS Transit seeing significant gains. The government's announcement to tender out bus routes to private operators is expected to benefit these companies, as revenue risk will now be transferred to the government. Analysts have upgraded their ratings, with OCBC Investment Research predicting Comfort Delgro will be the biggest beneficiary. However, Maybank Kim Eng remains cautious, citing concerns about sustainable earnings levels.

site_title: Pavilion Energy ventures into LNG transportation
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Singapore-based company, has formed a joint venture with BW Group to acquire and manage maritime liquefied natural gas (LNG) assets. The venture, BW Pavilion LNG, has an initial paid-up capital of $55 million and will build two new LNG carriers at a South Korean shipyard. The first carrier is already on lease, and two new ships will be ready by early 2015. The partnership aims to connect global LNG supplies to regional gas demand centers in Asia, with Pavilion Energy planning to deploy the ships for its own LNG supply delivery requirements in 2018 and 2020.

site_title: Back to STImulate
summary: Subaru has unveiled the new WRX and WRX STI, two high-performance sedans that aim to distance themselves from the "boyracer" image. The new models boast improved refinement and handling, with the WRX featuring a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine and the STI sporting a 2.5-liter horizontally opposed engine. The STI's older engine was chosen for its "practicality" in motorsport applications, despite being less powerful than the WRX's engine. The new cars exhibit better body control, reduced roll, and improved ride quality, making them a more refined driving experience.

site_title: Getaway across the Causeway
summary: Traders Hotel, a 4-star Shangri-La Group property, offers a relaxing getaway in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, with scenic views of Puteri Harbour. The hotel features a rooftop infinity pool, SkyBar, and Lobby Lounge, as well as a variety of dining options. With free Wi-Fi, private massage spa, and proximity to attractions like Legoland and Sanrio Hello Kitty Town, the hotel is an ideal destination for those seeking a quick escape from city life. Accessibility is expected to improve with the opening of the Puteri Harbour International Ferry Terminal, which is slated to begin direct trips to Singapore's HarbourFront Ferry Terminal this June.

site_title: Temasek group has 80.4% Olam stake after offer closes
summary: Temasek Holdings' offer for Olam International closed with 80.4% of Olam's issued shares held by Temasek and its concert parties. The offer valued the company at $5.33 billion. Olam had reported Q3 earnings of $396.1 million, with profit after tax and minority interest falling 15.9% due to higher depreciation and tax expenses. The acquisition marks a tumultuous chapter for Olam, which had faced criticism from shortseller Muddy Waters in 2012.

site_title: Join Racquet Club to mingle with top women tennis stars
summary: The World Sport Group is launching a premium hospitality program, The Racquet Club, for the upcoming BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals in Singapore. The program offers exclusive access to a double-storey pavilion and reserved baseline seats at the Indoor Stadium, along with international cuisine and open bar access. Packages start at $795 per person for four sessions, with the option to buy an entire 11-session package for $6,950. The program is available for 5 years, and early bird discounts are offered until the end of June.

site_title: Investors watching out for signs of continued growth
summary: Stock market indices hit record highs following strong housing data, with new and second-hand house sales rising 6.4% and 1.3% in April, respectively. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average reached new highs, with the Federal Reserve striking a market-friendly tone in its April meeting minutes. However, a correction in small-cap indices, such as the Russell 2000, has raised concerns, with investors rotating into blue-chip stocks and out of small-cap and momentum sectors in search of yield.

site_title: Fall in JV contributions drags GLP's Q4 net
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a decline in its fiscal fourth-quarter net profit due to a sharp fall in contributions from jointly-controlled entities, despite a 25% increase in revenue to US$150.4 million, driven by its strong China segment. Revenue growth was attributed to the completion and stabilization of development projects in China.

site_title: Busting too-busy-to-exercise myth
summary: Celebrity fitness trainer Jon Denoris introduces the "Pop-Up Gym," a 10-minute workout that requires no equipment, perfect for busy professionals with hectic schedules. Denoris, who has worked with executives and celebrities, believes that exercise gives people more energy, peak performance, and mental clarity. He advocates for starting small with 10-minute sessions and gradually increasing the duration to promote consistency and permanent change. His book of the same name offers functional exercises that can be incorporated into daily life, catering to older executives who may find traditional gyms intimidating.

site_title: Langkawi's eco-hotspot
summary: Langkawi's Kilim Karst Geoforest Park, a UNESCO world geopark, is home to a diverse ecosystem with unique flora and fauna. Naturalist Aidi Abdullah guides visitors through a three-hour boat tour, highlighting the park's limestone formations, mangrove trees, and wildlife, including mudskippers, fiddler crabs, dolphins, and otters. The geoforest park's beauty and scale make it a shame to lose it, with Abdullah working to maintain its status and enforce speeding limits to prevent damage to the environment. The Four Seasons Resort Langkawi, where Abdullah is resident naturalist, emphasizes sustainability and luxury, offering unique experiences like private dining and healing therapy.

site_title: The Gardener's Plot
summary: Renowned UK garden designer Chris Beardshaw is set to compete in the Singapore Garden Festival, where he will showcase a garden focused on the effects of urban development on the environment and nature's response to it. Beardshaw, who has won over 20 awards, believes that gardens should be personal and narrative-driven, allowing owners to express their unique paradise. He advises visitors to visit nurseries regularly to discover new plants and stimulate their senses, and encourages people not to be afraid to kill plants, as it's part of the gardening process.

site_title: Why property cooling measures were needed
summary: Singapore's property cooling measures, introduced from 2009-13, successfully contained the property market bubble and were an essential complement to monetary policy, according to MAS managing director Ravi Menon. The measures were implemented during a highly unusual situation following the global financial crisis, and will not be a permanent feature of policy. The measures included interest rate increases, loan-to-value ratios, and transaction taxes, which were effective in stabilizing property prices and preventing a financial bubble. The focus on financial stability has become more important, but monetary policy should not be overdone to the extent that it becomes detrimental to price and output stability.

images.alt_text: MAS managing director Ravi Menon (above) explained that attempts to deal with property price run-ups by conventional monetary policy could have backfired. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Keeping the nest egg safe
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) has evolved to meet changing needs, but its robustness and effectiveness are being challenged by rising medical costs, longer lifespans, and increasing property values. Experts suggest introducing flexible schemes, such as allowing members to redistribute their monies among accounts and start drawing down from their Retirement Account at a later age. They also propose introducing a compulsory annuity plan, reverse mortgages, and enhancing the Dependants' Protection Scheme. Some experts recommend limiting the use of CPF for investment to low-risk areas, such as healthcare and education, and increasing employer contributions to ensure the fund's effectiveness as a comprehensive social security system.

site_title: Vard snags second job for the quarter
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-based shipbuilder, secured its second contract in the second quarter, worth $210 million to build an offshore support vessel for Island Offshore. The project is designed by Rolls-Royce and marks a significant order for the company, which reported a disappointing quarter due to delays and overcapacity. This deal aims to help Vard Holdings recover from its disappointing performance.

site_title: Hot two-wheelers
summary: Several high-end bicycle brands have released new models, showcasing unique designs and features. The Le Flaneur d' Hermes and Le Flaneur Sportif d' Hermes from Hermes feature leather-clad contact points, while the Colossi 5 from Cycle Project Store boasts a mismatched wheel design. The Tokyobike 2014 Limited Edition SS offers a classic look with customizable add-ons, and the Runwell from Shinola features a front rack and high-end Shimano gear. The Coastliner from Coast Cycles is a simple, stylish option with a hidden belt-driven transmission.

site_title: Hong Leong-linked First Sponsor eyes S'pore listing
summary: First Sponsor Group Ltd, a Hong Leong-linked real estate group, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) to raise up to $102.1 million, primarily to fund future property development projects. The company will offer 54.05 million shares at $1.50-$1.60 per share, with cornerstone investors subscribing to 9.75 million shares. Assuming a $1.55 share price, First Sponsor will raise $92.3 million, with a market capitalization of $945.2 million. The IPO is expected to occur in the third quarter of this year.

site_title: Can 'affordable art' be a good investment?
summary: The Affordable Art Fair Singapore, a biannual event, aims to make art accessible to everyone, not just the wealthy. The fair features artworks priced between $100 and $10,000, with 75% of works sold for below $7,500. While some buyers have seen significant profits, buying art for investment runs contrary to the fair's spirit. However, some emerging artists have gained recognition and increased their prices after debuting at the fair. The fair's success has led to its expansion to other Asian cities, with plans to assess its sustainability through biannual editions in Singapore.

site_title: More buying, fewer buybacks
summary: Buying activity on the Singapore Exchange rose significantly from the previous week, with 27 purchases worth $3.1 million, up from nine firms and 18 purchases. Buyback activity fell, with only three firms making disposals worth $1.8 million. This contrasts with the selling side, where the number of firms and trades remained consistent with the previous week.

site_title: SIA aircraft veers off Yangon runway
summary: A Singapore Airlines Airbus A330 veered off the runway at Yangon International Airport during heavy rain, but no injuries were reported. The plane, carrying 265 passengers and crew, was steered safely back to the gate. The incident occurred on May 22, 2014, and was the latest in a series of incidents involving SIA planes this year. The airline has 19 A380s in service, with another five on order.

site_title: Electric Future
summary: The BMW i8 is a revolutionary plug-in hybrid sports car with a unique design and functional features. Its carbon fibre reinforced plastic shell and thermoplastic outer skin provide perfect aerodynamics, while its electric motor and turbocharged petrol engine enable four-wheel drive and superior traction. The car's weight distribution, with 49:51 front to rear, makes it ideal for sports driving. Its advanced features include a laser high beam function, which provides a 600-metre range, and an overboost system that provides 50 Nm of extra power when driving spiritedly.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Stamford Land Corp's FY2014 net profit fell 14.4% to $27.1 million due to a weaker Australian dollar. Surface Mount Technology's Q4 profit plummeted 99% to HK$1.54 million. Tung Lok Restaurants issued a profit warning, expecting a loss in FY2014. Golden Ocean Group reported a 51% increase in Q1 profit to $10.3 million, but is considering delisting from the Singapore Stock Exchange.

site_title: New concepts spice up the mix
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore's F&B scene is attracting international heavyweights, with several new concepts opening in the city-state. Potato Head Folk, the first international outpost of the Jakarta-based Potato Head Group, is set to debut in Keong Saik, offering a range of international cuisine and cocktails. Nutmeg & Clove, a collaborative venture between Nightjar's head barman and silent partners, is also opening on Ann Siang Road, featuring a range of craft cocktails inspired by historical eras. Additionally, art gallery-cum-nightclub Canvas is set to open in July, offering a unique space for art and entertainment.

site_title: Citi: China trade financing a challenge and an opportunity
summary: Citi Research reports that trade finance in Hong Kong and Singapore has surged at over 40% per annum, driven largely by China's significant role in intra-Asian trade and investment growth. This growth is seen as both a challenge and an opportunity for banks, with Citi estimating that 35% of loans in Hong Kong and 14.5% in Singapore are related to China. The report concludes that banks can capitalize on this growth, particularly in regional/cross-border trade and capital-efficient flow-based income, and that Singapore banks, such as DBS, are well-positioned to capture these opportunities.

site_title: Venture capital in S'pore yet to see 'great enough returns'
summary: Singapore's venture capital (VC) industry has yet to attract immense funding due to the lack of high returns, unlike Silicon Valley. Average returns in Singapore over 10 years (2004-2013) were around 18%, compared to 35% in Silicon Valley during the 1997-2000 dotcom boom. This has led to a relatively stable startup ecosystem, with a focus on matching deserving startups to available funds. Experts agree that the industry's evolution is crucial to providing more than just monetary capital, but also human capital to grow startups and achieve good returns for investors.

site_title: Deutsche Bank won't fund coal port expansion near Great Barrier Reef
summary: Deutsche Bank has decided not to finance a US$26 billion coal port expansion near the Great Barrier Reef in Australia, following pressure from green groups and tourism operators. The German bank's stance marks a win for those opposing the project, which would involve dumping soil near the World Heritage-listed reef. Despite this, one company involved, Indian firm GVK Hancock, stated that the bank's decision would not impact their proposed projects. The move is seen as a victory for environmental and tourism groups fighting to protect the reef.

site_title: MapletreeLog acquiring logistics centre in Korea for 25.5b won
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire Daehwa Logistics Centre in South Korea for 25.5 billion won (S$31.2 million). The logistics centre, a Grade A dry warehouse, is located within 50km of Seoul and will increase MLT's presence in South Korea to nine properties. The acquisition will boost MLT's total portfolio to 112 properties with a book value of $4.27 billion.

site_title: S'pore investors most concerned about health care
summary: Singapore investors are most concerned about healthcare costs in old age, with 72% expecting public medical services to cover their needs in retirement. However, only 36% have a policy that will be renewable after 59, and 17% fear their policy will not be available. Despite this, 59% believe they will maintain their current living standard in retirement. The Manulife Investor Sentiment Index survey found that healthcare expenses are expected to account for 13% of monthly expenses during retirement, with 15% annual growth in healthcare expenditure in Singapore over the past decade.

site_title: AirAsia's Fernandes trying to sell Caterham Group: report
summary: Tony Fernandes, CEO of AirAsia, plans to sell the Caterham group, a UK-based automotive and engineering company, for approximately £350 million. The sale includes Caterham Cars Ltd and the Caterham Formula One Team. An information memorandum is being circulated in the Middle East, and Fernandes has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Focus on rail after Singapore's public bus sector overhaul, with SMRT shares boosted due to speculation of government rail asset takeover. Meanwhile, Thailand's army staged a coup, China's factory output reached a five-month high, and SATS' fourth-quarter profit declined 7.8%. GIC plans to enter Brazil's corporate sector, and Manhattan Resources acquired Singxin Resources for $1 billion. Inflation in Malaysia eased in April, but banks predict interest rate hike. US regulators are investigating Charles Schwab and Merrill Lynch for money laundering.

site_title: Airlines not worried about cost of real-time aircraft tracking: UN official
summary: Major airlines agree to implement real-time tracking of commercial aircraft, following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) plans to propose measures by the end of September, with members implementing tracking voluntarily before any binding rules or timelines are established. The United Nations' aviation agency has not raised concerns about the cost of real-time tracking, citing the need for global tracking to enhance safety. Iata's proposal aims to provide better tracking of aircraft, but no specific timeline or cost estimate has been announced.

site_title: GIC eyes Brazil's corporate sector
summary: GIC, a sovereign wealth fund, has opened an office in Sao Paulo, Brazil, signaling its long-term commitment to the country and Latin America. The fund's group chief investment officer, Lim Chow Kiat, sees opportunities in Brazil's corporate sector due to rising incomes and industry consolidation. GIC has made several investments in Brazilian companies, including a $170 million round in online retailer Netshoes. The fund believes depressed valuations in Brazil present a buying opportunity for long-term investors, with the country's benchmark Ibovespa stock index having retreated 7.2% in the past 12 months.

site_title: AirAsia's low-cost model 'won't work in India'
summary: AirAsia's low-cost model is unlikely to be successful in India due to high costs, according to a senior aviation official. SpiceJet's chief operating officer, Sanjiv Kapoor, stated that to offer significantly cheaper fares, AirAsia would need a 30-35% lower cost structure, which is difficult to achieve in India. AirAsia plans to increase its load factor to 85% and rationalize its fleet to reduce costs. The airline has been discussing with investors and is nearing a conclusion, but Kapoor's comments suggest that its Indian operations may not be profitable.

site_title: PM Lee paints possible Asia scenarios
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that war in Asia is "not impossible" if regional tensions are not managed responsibly, citing escalating tensions between China, Japan, and South Korea. Lee presented two possible scenarios: a "peaceful and integrated Asia" and a "riven and fractious Asia". He emphasized the importance of the US maintaining its rebalance towards Asia and China adhering to international law and norms. If tensions are not managed, the region could experience more trade disputes, currency wars, and tit-for-tat protectionism, potentially leading to a proxy battleground.

site_title: Keeping a positive outlook on life
summary: Australian author Andrew Matthews, known for his self-help books on happiness, remains optimistic despite personal challenges, including his stepson's long-term struggle after a severe brain injury. Matthews credits his positive outlook, which he practices by reflecting on three good things from his day, as a key factor in his success. His books, including his latest "How Life Works," have sold over seven million copies and offer insights on the importance of happiness and positive psychology in the workplace, particularly in Singapore's highly regarded society.

site_title: BHP may seek govt help in tugboat dispute
summary: BHP Billiton may seek government assistance to prevent a strike by tugboat workers at the Port Hedland iron ore port, which could disrupt $100 million in daily exports. The workers are demanding higher pay and leave, with BHP calling their demands "unreasonable." The port's large iron ore stocks and existing shipping constraints mean little room for stockpiling, and a strike could have significant economic impacts. The Australian government has intervened in similar disputes in the past, and BHP is considering similar action to avert the strike.

site_title: Manhattan in $1b deal to acquire mining firm Singxin
summary: Manhattan Resources has agreed to acquire Singxin Resources for $1 billion, expanding into China's mineral mining industry. The acquisition will allow Manhattan to diversify into mining, following a 29% drop in its first quarter turnover due to lower coal transportation volume. Manhattan's CEO, David Low, will control the company with a 53.85% stake. The deal is conditional on shareholder approval and will be funded by a one-for-one bonus issue of warrants to existing shareholders.

site_title: Thai army stages coup after six-month political stalemate
summary: Thailand's powerful army chief, General Prayuth Chan-ocha, staged a coup after a six-month political stalemate, seizing control of the country and suspending the Constitution. The coup follows the removal of caretaker premier Yingluck Shinawatra by the Constitutional Court on May 7. A nationwide curfew and ban on protests have been implemented, with the military vowing to restore peace and reform the country's politics, economy, and society. The move has caused economic uncertainty, with the baht weakening against the US dollar, but markets may find short-term stability.

site_title: Global Oil 57 signs deals worth US$20b
summary: Global Oil 57, a Singapore-based oil and gas trading company, has signed deals worth over US$20 billion with Al Qudra Marketing & Business Services and China's Ocean Century Energy group (OCE). The agreements include a 25-year liquefied natural gas supply contract and a refinery crude contract for 70 million barrels per year. Global Oil 57's expertise will help OCE maximize production capacity and operate efficiently. The company was registered in Singapore last August and has offices in over 10 countries, including Australia, China, and Qatar.

site_title: A boring melodrama that's a right royal mess
summary: A new movie, "Grace of Monaco," is a dull and uninspired melodrama that fails to capture the essence of Princess Grace Kelly's life. The film focuses on her marital discord and palace intrigue in the early 1960s, but ultimately devolves into a predictable and formulaic tale. Despite a talented cast, including Nicole Kidman and Tim Roth, the movie falls flat due to its lack of originality and poor execution. The film's portrayal of Princess Kelly is reduced to cliches and stereotypes, making it a disappointing and unentertaining watch.

site_title: A different way of presenting classical music
summary: Award-winning musicians Loh Jun Hong and Abigail Sin are redefining classical music through their "More Than Music" concert series, aiming to change the perception of the genre. The duo creates a casual environment where musicians share personal stories about the music and composers with the audience. Their second concert, "In Good Company," will feature renditions of Beethoven, Schumann, and other classical pieces, with Sin and Loh sharing their favorite music and anecdotes. The series seeks to make classical music more intimate and engaging for the audience.

site_title: SATS Q4 profit slides 7.8%
summary: SATS, an airport services provider, reported a 7.8% decline in its net profit to $42.6 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, primarily due to weaker revenue and lower contributions from associates and joint ventures. Revenue fell 3.2% to $434.6 million, with a 5.7% decline in the food solutions business. The company also warned that the operating environment remains challenging due to rising costs and headwinds in the regional aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Airport services provider SATS's net profit slipped 7.8 per cent from a year earlier to $42.6 million for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2014 - PHOTO: SATS

site_title: Second-Hand, First Choice
summary: The second-hand luxury goods market has seen significant growth, with more platforms emerging to provide access to pre-owned luxury items at lower prices. The Closet Raiders, an Instagram account, has already garnered over 13,000 followers and reports sellers selling items within minutes of posting. Founder Ophelia Teo attributes the shift in mindset to the increasing popularity of discounted prices among younger generations. Meanwhile, established resellers like Designers Exchange and Madam Milan have also seen success, with Designers Exchange earning approximately 10-30% of the sale price. The industry is expected to continue growing, with StyleTribute and The Closet Raider expanding their online presence.

site_title: HUDC estate in Hougang privatised
summary: The Housing and Urban Development Co (HUDC) estate at Hougang Avenue 2 has been successfully privatised, becoming the 15th of 18 such estates to do so. The estate will be converted into a strata-titled property, with a Management Corporation Strata Title council to be elected to manage and maintain it. The privatisation is expected to translate into more resilient pricing for properties in a cautious property market, and may lead to opportunities for developers to acquire the land en bloc in the future.

site_title: Underwater search for MH370 resumes
summary: A mini-sub, Bluefin-21, has resumed its underwater search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in the Indian Ocean, entering its final week of scouring the seabed. The US Navy-operated vessel, which can dive to 4,500 meters, is searching areas with acoustic signals detected from the plane's black box recorders. The Australian-led operation aims to confirm or discount the area as the final resting place of the plane, which vanished on March 8 with 239 people onboard.

site_title: Nay Nai in modern times
summary: Thai dancer Pichet Klunchun returns to Singapore with a new work, "Nay Nai," a contemporary take on a select group of men in the royal Thai court during King Rama VI's reign. The one-act play focuses on the king's interactions with these young gentlemen-in-waiting, exploring themes of identity, history, and societal expectations. Klunchun adapts the story to fit present time, incorporating elements of competition and reality TV shows. His classical Khon dance is reinterpreted to convey the story, while maintaining its traditional roots. The production is presented by TheatreWorks and runs from June 17-21.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: OKP Holdings secured a $50.6 million contract from PUB for a canal construction project, boosting its net order book to $240.2 million. KS Energy secured over $60 million in drilling contracts. Meanwhile, Magnus Energy Group's key executive Koh Teng Kiat resigned due to passport issues, while Chaswood Resources' controlling shareholder pledged its shares to Phillip Asia Pacific Opportunity Fund.

site_title: Airbnb to give New York host information
summary: Airbnb has agreed to comply with a New York state probe into short-term home rentals, handing over host information on an anonymous basis. The company will provide identifying details later for hosts deemed subjects of the investigation. The agreement allows the attorney general's office to examine Airbnb data to identify illegal hotels and accommodations. Airbnb will use the year to improve its regulatory compliance, service for legitimate renters, and lobby for law changes. The deal follows a previous investigation blocked by a New York state judge.

site_title: X-Men stars ham it up in Singapore
summary: Hugh Jackman, Fan Bingbing, and Peter Dinklage promoted the X-Men: Days of Future Past movie in Singapore, discussing their roles in the film. Jackman revealed he prepared for a nude scene by working out intensively, while Dinklage discussed his character, Bolivar Trask, and expressed willingness to return for future films. Bingbing, who played Blink, praised Jackman's discipline and was surprised by her casting in the film. The co-stars also shared lighthearted moments, including Jackman's near-castration incident with Wolverine's claws.

site_title: The fashion cycle
summary: The cycling lifestyle has become a status symbol in Singapore, with chic cyclists investing in aesthetically pleasing city bikes and trendy accessories. Local retailers like Tokyobike and Cycle Project Store have seen increased sales, while concept stores like Coast Cycles and Wheeler's Yard offer hangout spots for enthusiasts. Fashion brands such as Hermes, Agnes B, and Giordano have also collaborated on high-end and affordable bicycles, reflecting the trend's growing popularity. With prices ranging from a few hundred to several thousand dollars, cycling has become a fashion statement as well as a mode of transportation.

site_title: Nothing easy about this experiment
summary: A 1960s Singaporean penal colony on Pulau Senang failed as a social experiment, resulting in a bloody riot and the hanging of 18 men accused of being gangsters. The play "Senang" brings this episode to life, exploring the clash between the British authorities and Chinese gangsters. The drama highlights human nature's darker side, with characters driven by philosophies, motivations, and interests. The production features a strong ensemble cast and raises questions about the official narrative of Singapore's anti-gang history, suggesting a more nuanced view of the events.

site_title: China May factory output highest in 5 months: survey
summary: China's factory sector showed its best performance in five months in May, with the HSBC Flash China Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reaching 49.7, up from April's 48.1. While the data indicates a slight contraction, the overall trend suggests some stabilization in the economy. Asian stocks and currencies rose after the report, with new export orders showing a significant turnaround, climbing to 52.7. However, downside risks to growth remain, particularly due to the cooling property market and potential labor market weakening.

site_title: Cooking up a fundraiser for competition
summary: Chef Yew Eng Tong, a 36-year-old Singaporean chef, is preparing for the regional round of the prestigious Bocuse d'Or competition in Shanghai. With the support of four French mentors, he aims to represent Singapore again and potentially move on to the 2015 World Finals in Lyon, France. To raise funds for the competition, which costs between $80,000 to $100,000, chef Yew and his mentors have organized a Bocuse d'Or Chef's Table, a five-course lunch at Bar-Roque Grill on May 31, costing $1,000 per person.

site_title: Consumer prices up 2.5% in April
summary: Singapore's inflation rose 2.5% in April, exceeding economists' expectations, driven by a 5.7% increase in private road transport costs. Car prices, particularly COE premiums, contributed to the jump, while food inflation rose to 3.1% and core inflation increased to 2.3%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry expect core inflation to remain elevated at 2-3% in 2014, with headline inflation projected at 1.5-2.5%.

site_title: More punch for SGX's queries, trade with caution warnings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has seen a decrease in "Trade With Caution" (TWC) warnings issued to companies, indicating improved circumspection in its use of the tool. However, the process remains insufficient, as unusual activity often triggers a query, followed by a possible explanation, but no follow-up action is taken to ensure companies properly discharge their duties. To improve transparency, the exchange should consider setting up a "Queries/TWC" watchlist, providing daily updates on companies queried and their responses, and visible follow-up actions if warranted.

site_title: US airlines beat Asian and European rivals in profitability
summary: US airlines, led by Delta, American, United, and Southwest, have surpassed European and Asian rivals in profitability, according to Bloomberg data. The carriers have restructured by reducing seating capacity to raise fares and charge for extras, resulting in a 34-fold gain in operating income for Delta. The US quartet now accounts for nearly half of the $190 billion market value of the 20 largest global carriers. Investors have benefited, with airline stocks more than quadrupling in the past five years. The US airlines' recovery is seen as a welcome turnaround, but analysts caution that "hubris" may be a threat to their continued success.

site_title: Hope for ailing JES Int'l as it wins big ship contracts
summary: Chinese shipbuilder JES International Holdings has won a major contract worth US$974 million to build and deliver 11 Ultramax bulk carriers. This is the company's largest contract to date, following previous wins totaling US$1.54 billion. The contracts were awarded by a firm registered in the British Virgin Islands, backed by two private investment funds. The delivery of the vessels is expected to take place between 2015 and 2016, bringing some hope to the company's struggling financials, which have posted losses of 552.2 million yuan in 2013.

site_title: A star fades out at Cannes
summary: Gilles Jacob, 83, is retiring after 35 years as president of the Cannes Film Festival, a position he held for 15 years. Jacob, credited with maintaining the festival's artistic integrity, will step down after a controversy over his on-stage kiss with an Iranian actress. He credits the festival's independence and formula of combining Hollywood glamour with European respect for cinema as key factors in its success. Jacob's legacy includes the Un Certain Regard competition and the Cinéfoundation, which supports new filmmakers. Pierre Lescure will take over as president next year.

site_title: SATS: Why it pulled out of SCC deal
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based global cruise operator, has pulled out of a $110 million acquisition deal for the Singapore Cruise Centre (SCC) due to developments in the Asian cruise market. According to CEO Alex Hungate, the decision was influenced by Royal Caribbean's plan to offer year-round sailings from Marina Bay Cruise Centre (MBCC), where SATS owns the facility. SATS will now move its Legend of the Seas ship to Singapore during the summer months, solidifying Singapore's status as a year-round cruise centre.

site_title: HK's comedy king gets serious
summary: Hong Kong director Pang Ho Cheung, known as the "comedy king," is retiring from filmmaking to focus on his family after his latest film, Aberdeen, breaks domestic box office records. Aberdeen, a family drama, marks a departure from Pang's usual comedies and features an ensemble cast of regular collaborators, including Miriam Cheung and Shawn Yue. Pang, 40, has been praised for reviving Hong Kong cinema with accessible and intelligent films that provide social commentary. He plans to take a break from filmmaking, but is open to exploring other genres and projects in the future.

site_title: TA Corp-led group wins deal to build workers' accommodation
summary: A consortium led by TA Corporation has won a bid to develop a 37,170.5 square metre site into workers' accommodation for 9,200 foreign workers in the marine, process, and manufacturing industries. The $113.9 million project will be designed, developed, and operated by the consortium, with TA Corp owning 62% and partners splitting the remaining 38% equally. The facility is expected to be completed in 2016, filling a shortage of quality workers' accommodation in Singapore.

site_title: BCA plans makeover for building industry
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has launched a five-year plan to revamp the building and construction industry, aiming to attract more women and locals to careers in the sector. The plan includes a rebranding campaign, improved human resource practices, and enhanced work environments. BCA seeks to increase the proportion of locals in the workforce from less than a third to at least a third by 2020. The authority also plans to promote the sector through competitions, career fairs, and scholarships to attract young talent.

site_title: A quality blockbuster that keeps fans fully engaged
summary: Hugh Jackman stars as Wolverine in X-Men: Days of Future Past, directed by Bryan Singer, as he travels back in time to change the past and save the future of mutants. The film features an ensemble cast, including Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen, and has a solid story arc and vigorous tempo. Wolverine is tasked with persuading his younger selves to assist in altering history, while also stopping a renegade mutant from killing a key scientist. The film has a 3D experience and a US$225-million budget, and is rated B.

site_title: Lloyds limits mortgage lending to cool London housing prices
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc, the UK's largest mortgage lender, will cap lending on loans over £500,000 to four times salary in London to counter rising house prices. The policy affects about 8% of its lending in the city, targeting the upper tiers of the market. The move aims to manage risks to the business and protect customers. This is the first of Britain's biggest mortgage lenders to announce such measures, following Bank of England Governor Mark Carney's warning on the biggest risk to the economy.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: CapitaLand's stake in CapitaMalls Asia (CMA) has surpassed 80% after increasing its offer price to $2.35. Ezra Holdings won $95 million in new contracts, Lian Beng secured a $44.5 million dormitory project, and KrisEnergy acquired an oil block in the Gulf of Thailand for $102.5 million. Religare Health Trust reported a 51% increase in net profit to $11.22 million for the fourth quarter, with a full-year distribution per common unit (DPU) of 8.19 cents.

site_title: Rebasing the national accounts
summary: Singapore sets up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. The country also launched a new grant of up to SGD 100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. Additionally, a study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Meanwhile, a minister advises graduates to stay calm, citing better employment rates in early data. DPM Gan will visit the US for trade talks, while a financial institution offers training assistance for businesses with limited resources.

site_title: Yoma posts 45% drop in earnings for final quarter
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-centric firm, posted a 45% drop in net profit to $6.4 million for the January-March quarter, primarily due to the absence of a one-year-old gain. Revenue rose 34% to $27.5 million, driven by sales of residences and land development rights. The company reported a record $16.4 million net profit for the full fiscal year, with revenue reaching a record $100.5 million. CEO Andrew Rickards attributed the growth to solid execution in a rising market, but noted that increased expenses, including staff costs, may mute profit growth in the near term.

site_title: Around Town
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The "Shape Your Time" exhibition at Cartier in Singapore showcases the brand's heritage and technical skill in modern men's watches. The exhibition includes iconic pieces like the Santos de Cartier and Ballon Bleu de Cartier, as well as the debut of the Calibre de Cartier Diver watch. Meanwhile, the Singapore Art Museum hosts "Medium at Large," an exhibition exploring the concept of medium in modern art, and "Simply Scribbly" at The Connoisseur Concerto features doodling as an art form. Additionally, Varnam 2014, a showcase of contemporary Indian art, runs at MICA ARTium.

site_title: NS feedback committee to be revamped into three councils
summary: Singapore's Advisory Council on Community Relations in Defence (Accord) will be restructured into three councils: Employer and Business Council, Educational Institutions Council, and Family and Community Council. The move aims to strengthen community support for defence and National Service. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen announced the plan in a ministry addendum to President Tony Tan Keng Yam's recent address to Parliament. The restructuring is expected to enhance community engagement and feedback on National Service.

site_title: Charting a new course
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Key companies are charting new courses in various sectors. Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi services in California and Arizona, while FedEx partners with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robot deliveries. Delta Air Lines is optimistic about travel demand, boosting its shares. Japan's carmakers have reduced export prices to the US to mitigate the impact of tariffs. EV battery makers, including BYD, face pressure to cut emissions. Nissan is set to issue a record-high coupon in a $4 billion US bond sale. These developments indicate a shift towards innovation and adaptation in response to changing market conditions.

site_title: Focus falls on rail after bus overhaul
summary: SMRT Corp shares rose 3.5 cents to $1.47 after speculation that the government may assume ownership of its rail operating assets, following the bus sector overhaul. The stock initially fell but rebounded in the afternoon, with analysts attributing its gains to anticipation of a potential rail asset purchase. However, some analysts expressed caution due to uncertainty over the transition process and future licensing charges. Meanwhile, ComfortDelGro shares fell 5 cents to $2.25, while SBS Transit's shares rose 18.5 cents to $1.60.

site_title: Tokyo to unveil plan to trim corporate tax next month
summary: Japan plans to unveil a plan to trim its corporate tax rate next month, aiming to enhance competitiveness and boost productivity. The current 35.6% corporate tax rate is higher than Singapore's and OECD average rates. Senior Vice-Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura emphasized the need for a cut, citing the need to remain competitive in the global market.

site_title: Thai developer warns of daunted investors
summary: Thai developer Amata Corp warns that foreign investors may halt investments in Thailand due to martial law, citing delayed contract signings by several clients. The country's army declared martial law to restore order after six months of anti-government protests. Amata, which houses BMW and Bridgestone production bases, is a bellwether for foreign investor sentiment. Japanese car makers are among its biggest clients, and the company fears negative signs from martial law could lead to a loss of investment, making recovery more difficult.

site_title: Shell meets target of 25% women directors
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has met its target of having 25% women directors on its 12-member board after unanimously voting in former StanChart Singapore CEO Euleen Goh and Archer Daniels Midland Company's Patricia Woertz as new directors. Goh and Woertz join Linda Stuntz, bringing the total number of women on the board to 25%. The move follows Shell's annual general meeting in The Hague earlier this week.

site_title: German retail acquisitions soar
summary: German retail property acquisitions more than doubled in the first quarter, reaching 3.43 billion euros, surpassing the UK for the first time since 2012. This surge is attributed to investors seeking stable returns amid record-low interest rates, with insurers, pension funds, and money managers driving the demand. The growth is expected to accelerate in the coming years as retail asset prices are under pressure due to supply failing to keep up. This marks a shift in favor of Germany as a low-volatility, safe market.

site_title: Unexpectedly simple and pure delights
summary: A 2004 Hautes-Cotes de Nuits Blanc wine from Michel Gros and a Hautes-Cotes de Nuits Rouge from Anne Gros were found to offer great pleasure despite being inexpensive. The wines, now 10 years old, exhibit light golden colors, fresh aromas, and flavors of tangerines and nuts, with a clean finish. The reviewer, NK Yong, was pleasantly surprised by the wines' complexity and quality, finding them to be a delightful and unexpected pleasure, comparable to the joy of discovering something charming as a child.

site_title: Not sunset for Singapore's oil refineries
summary: Singapore's oil refineries, despite global competition, are expected to continue operating. The country's refining industry has a history of weathering storms, with only one closure in 1995 due to land use issues. Major players such as ExxonMobil, Shell, and Chevron are upgrading and investing in their operations, integrating refineries with petrochemical crackers to enhance competitiveness. Singapore's strategic location, efficient logistics, and competitive advantages make it an attractive hub for the industry, with plans to build up value-add legs in fuels, chemicals, and lubricants.

site_title: Oxley appoints Accor to run two new hotels
summary: OXLEY Holdings has appointed Accor to run two new hotels along Stevens Road in Singapore, to be developed under the Novotel and Ibis brand names. The hotels, expected to open by end-2016, will provide a recurring income stream and cater to the anticipated increase in business and tourist arrivals.
