The project marks Oxley's first foray into hospitality and will bring Accor's Singapore portfolio to nine hotels, with a combined global network of over 1,400 hotels in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Boxes lift Maersk's Q1 profit 62%
summary: Maersk's Q1 profit rose 62% to $1.15 billion, beating forecasts, driven by increased container shipping earnings. Revenues climbed 0.9% to $11.736 billion, slightly short of expectations. The company expects annual results to beat last year's due to improved operational performance. Maersk Line now forecasts annual profit of $4 billion, up from $3.6 billion. The company attributed its success to cost cuts and an alliance with other ocean carriers.

site_title: Asia demand for marine fuel expected to rise 2%
summary: Asian demand for marine fuel is expected to grow 2% in 2014 due to increased shipment of raw materials in the region. Despite ample fuel oil supplies from the Middle East and Europe, returns on the most common ship fuel are unlikely to improve. Bunker fuel demand in Asia is forecast to reach 1.45 million barrels per day, with growth driven by Asia's increasing trade with other regions, according to consultancy Wood Mackenzie.

images.alt_text: Asian demand for marine fuel is expected to grow up to 2 per cent in 2014 after stagnating for five years, as more goods and raw materials are shipped in the region, though returns on the most common ship fuel are unlikely to improve due to ample supplies - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Singapore reclaims top Asia ranking in competitiveness
summary: Singapore reclaims the top Asia ranking in competitiveness, surpassing Hong Kong after three years, according to the 2014 IMD World Competitiveness Yearbook. In global rankings, Singapore rises two notches to 3rd spot, behind the US and Switzerland. Small economies like Singapore, Hong Kong, and Switzerland prosper due to exports, business efficiency, and innovation. Economists caution against complacency, citing regional and global competition, including Malaysia, Japan, and Indonesia.

site_title: Locals go for bonds issued by China firms
summary: Rich local investors are snapping up bonds issued by Chinese companies, including Yanlord Land Group, Far East Horizon Ltd, and Central China Real Estate. The $400 million, three-year bonds from Yanlord Land Group received $5 billion in orders, while Far East Horizon Ltd's $400 million bonds attracted $3.8 billion in orders. Central China Real Estate's $200 million bonds received $1 billion in orders. This trend suggests that local investors are seeking alternatives to traditional investments and are willing to invest in Chinese companies.

site_title: SSC full-year profit up 25.7% at US$8.6m
summary: SSC's full-year net profit rose 25.7% to US$8.6 million, driven by a 73% increase in revenue to US$34.4 million. This growth was mainly attributed to the acquisition of an agency and logistics business in April 2013. Earnings per share rose to 2 US cents, up from 1.6 US cents the previous year.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine wins US$236m deal
summary: Sembcorp Marine's subsidiary Jurong Shipyard has secured a US$236 million contract to build a jack-up rig for Maersk Oil and Gas. The rig, set for delivery in 2016, will operate in the North Sea waters of 400 feet and drill to 30,000 feet depths. This contract adds to the company's total new orders, meeting 48% of full-year estimates. Analysts from OCBC and DMG & Partners Securities maintain a buy call on the stock, citing stable margins and expected revenue growth.

site_title: Premium air travel sees reversal of fortunes
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) reported a reversal in premium air travel growth, with a 1.9% year-over-year increase in March, down from 4.1% in February. Weak demand is attributed to China's economic slowdown, while markets linked to the US, such as North America, South America, and North America-Central America, showed solid growth. The North Atlantic route also experienced a 2% year-over-year increase. Iata expects premium travel to remain positive, but notes downward pressure from emerging markets' weakness.

site_title: A narrative of time and space through art
summary: Artist Rirkrit Tiravanija, born in Buenos Aires to Thai and Ethiopian parents, has a global upbringing and identifies as a "third culture kid." He navigates his digital age, feeling out of touch with computer-savvy students who rely on technology, contrasting with his own library research days. Tiravanija splits time between Chiang Mai, New York, and Berlin, constantly traveling for exhibitions and residencies. He humorously calls himself an "illegal alien," anticipating potential cultural misunderstandings, particularly in the US.

site_title: ThaiBev sees continuing growth
summary: Thai Beverage Public Co, a major drinks maker, expects to continue its first-quarter growth momentum despite Thailand's martial law, according to CEO Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi. The company's net profit rose 73% to 6 billion baht in the first quarter. Beer volumes fell 11.7% but prices were raised to pass on higher excise rates, helping the business return to profitability. A strategic review of ThaiBev and its investment in Fraser and Neave (F&N) is expected to be completed by early July, with synergies to be implemented from the second quarter of 2015.

site_title: State-owned airlines seen as challenge
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr views state-owned airlines as a significant challenge to the European airline industry. He stated that the competition from government-owned carriers is a major concern for airline executives. Spohr expressed this sentiment during a meeting with US President Barack Obama and other executives, highlighting the need for European airlines to adapt to this changing landscape.

site_title: Flight attendants at Virgin America seek unionised vote
summary: Flight attendants at Virgin America are seeking a unionised vote, with 850 employees potentially forming the airline's first union. The move follows JetBlue pilots' unionisation last month. The Transport Workers Union (TWU) has received signature cards from a majority of workers, paving the way for a potential union victory in the airline industry.

site_title: Another sukuk issue by Saudi firm draws investors
summary: Saudi Arabian real estate developer Dar Al Arkan is set to sell a benchmark US dollar-denominated sukuk due 2019, drawing investors who believe the company's vast land assets outweigh its junk credit rating. The company, which owns over $3.5 billion of property in Saudi Arabia, has seen its yield slide 107 basis points to 6.17% this year. Despite a junk credit rating, Dar Al Arkan's asset-rich status and growing cash reserves have made it an attractive investment opportunity for sukuk investors.

site_title: New model positive for SBS Transit, SMRT
summary: SBS Transit and SMRT, Singapore's two major bus operators, are expected to benefit from the new government contracting model for public buses. Analysts predict that the transition will eliminate operating losses of over $40 million annually for both companies, with SBS Transit likely to be more positively impacted due to its larger market share. The new model is seen as a long-term positive for the bus operators, as it will take away losses from their income statements, allowing them to remain competitive even with new entrants in the market.

site_title: Moody's cuts China property outlook
summary: Moody's has revised its outlook for China's property industry to "negative" from "stable", citing a significant slowdown in residential property sales growth, high inventory levels, and weakening liquidity over the next 12 months. The agency expects modest 0-5% year-over-year growth, driven by tighter onshore liquidity, increased mortgage rates, and slower GDP growth in China. However, developers with good liquidity and access to funding are expected to withstand challenging conditions. The outlook can be revised back to stable if growth in national contracted sales exceeds 5-10% and developers maintain stable access to bank credit.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced significant changes to Singapore's public bus sector to address underlying issues. Singapore reclaimed the top spot in Asia for overall competitiveness, surpassing Hong Kong. Meanwhile, local investors are investing in Chinese bonds, and the small car COE premium rebounded. The Indian government, led by Prime Minister Modi, has room for policy maneuvering despite challenges. The Bank of England's Charlie Bean warned of potential "potholes" in exiting stimulus measures, and Google is holding US$30 billion in cash outside the US for possible acquisitions.

site_title: Sweeping changes to public bus sector
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore announced sweeping changes to the public bus industry, transitioning from a privatised model to a government contracting model. The new system, starting in the second half of 2014, will see the government owning buses and infrastructure, while contracting routes to local and foreign players. Operators will be paid a fee to run services, while the government retains fare revenue. The goal is to raise service standards through increased competition and flexibility, with operators expected to run services at shorter intervals during peak hours.

site_title: UOB stock ahead of peers despite Thai exposure
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is outperforming its Singapore banking peers, despite exposure to Thailand's political crisis, which led to martial law. UOB's stock is up nearly 6% year-to-date, while DBS and OCBC are down 0.5% and 5% respectively. Analysts attribute UOB's performance to its prudent approach to growth in Thailand, strong fundamentals, and low exposure to Greater China. The bank's recent success in selling Basel III bonds also indicates confidence in its capital management.

site_title: Bus sector revamp: better late than never?
summary: The Singapore government has announced a revamp of the bus sector, taking over bus operations and routes from private operators. The move aims to insulate private operators from operational losses and improve service levels. The government will manage assets and determine routes, inviting private operators to tender for them. This approach is similar to London Buses and Singapore's ComfortDelGro, which operate profitably. The decision comes after years of criticism over overcrowding, bus bunching, and long wait times, with the government citing a preference for private sector management as the reason for the delay.

site_title: MTI debunks perception of widespread retail rent spikes
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) in Singapore released a report stating that most retailers face rental hikes in line with inflation when renewing shop leases, contradicting widespread concerns of steep rent increases. A quarter of retailers renewed leases with no rent increases or lower rents, and 75% of leases had increases of 14% or less. The report also found that Reits are not driving up retail rents, but rather, their better locations and renovated features contribute to higher rents. However, SMEs and retailers remain skeptical, calling for more comprehensive data and transparency in the market.

site_title: JTC launches 'future-ready' industrial facility
summary: JTC Corporation launches JTC Space @ Tampines North, a 'future-ready' industrial facility with high-tech manufacturing capabilities, catering to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in heavier manufacturing activities. The nine-storey development features flexible design, high ceilings, and vibration-sensitive space for new industries. Construction begins by the end of the year, with completion targeted by 2016. The facility aims to fill a market gap and set new standards for industrial development, with features such as dry walls, passive design, and energy savings.

site_title: Talk of the town - London's housing boom
summary: London's housing market has experienced a significant boom, with property values rising by 17.7% in the past year, more than double the average annual London wage. Foreign buyers, low mortgage rates, and a lack of supply have fueled the market, with prices reaching record highs. The Bank of England has warned of the risk of housing inflation, and the government is under pressure to take action to cool the market. As a result, homeowners like Katy Barnes and Holly Martin are seeing their property values soar, while the demand for housing continues to outstrip supply.

site_title: Conspiracy theories re-emerge
summary: Conspiracy theories surrounding the disappearance of MH370 have resurfaced, with a book, films, and former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad speculating about possible CIA involvement or a remote-controlled takeover. Theories include a Taliban hijack, meteor strike, or accidental shoot-down. Despite Malaysia's official explanation that the plane likely crashed in the Indian Ocean, speculation persists, with some suspecting the government is hiding something.

site_title: Onboard safety culture - think outside the box
summary: A maritime industry expert, Martin Hernqvist, emphasizes the importance of developing effective safety cultures on ships, which he claims are lacking on many vessels. He suggests that companies must lead from the top down, incorporating in-house training and using the company's own incident reports and procedures. Interactivity in training, similar to video games, is also seen as key to retaining knowledge and promoting behavioral change. Experts, including Hernqvist and Raal Harris, advocate for the use of innovative training methods to improve safety culture and reduce accidents at sea.

site_title: Embraer bets on more overhead storage to boost aircraft sales
summary: Embraer is introducing a second-generation E-Jet with increased overhead storage capacity, offering at least 40% more volume per traveler than current models. This move is seen as a competitive advantage in the sales pitch, particularly for lucrative business passengers who value carry-on space. By providing more room for roller bags, Embraer aims to outsell Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp, Sukhoi Co, and Bombardier Inc in the single-aisle market, addressing a key concern for customers in a revenue-conscious industry.

site_title: Office Reits to outdo industrial: StanChart
summary: Singapore's office Reits are expected to offer higher dividend yields than industrial Reits by 2016, driven by a rising supply of business park space and falling rents. Warehouse rents are also predicted to decline. However, Standard Chartered Research remains optimistic about the Singapore office sector's prospects, citing rising demand for office space.

site_title: Asking clients what they want
summary: Citi Private Bank's chief executive Bassam Salem says the industry's high cost-to-income ratio of 80-100% is a major challenge, mainly due to failure to segment clients and inability to offer services needed by private clients. Citi's cost-to-income ratio is around 60%. The bank has assets under management of $245 billion in the Asia-Pacific, with a focus on catering to ultra-wealthy clients. Salem argues that the $1 million threshold for private banking is too low and that institutions should focus on offering customized services to attract high-net-worth clients.

images.alt_text: Mr Salem: Cautions that consultants' estimates of wealth market sizing tends to be overstated as they include onshore wealth. - FILE PHOTO

site_title: MAS acts against ex-Maybank staff for insider trading
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has taken civil penalty action against former Maybank relationship manager Koh Huat Heng for insider trading. Koh purchased 140,000 shares of Sin Heng Machinery in June 2013 while possessing non-public information about the company's planned rights-issue exercise. He admitted to contravening the Securities and Futures Act and paid a $50,000 civil penalty. Koh is prohibited from providing financial advisory services for three years and must give up his roles as director or substantial shareholder of a licensed financial adviser.

site_title: Why did STATS ChipPAC wait to be queried?
summary: STATS ChipPAC, a Singapore-based semiconductor group, saw its share price surge over 15% in just one trading session due to unusual volume movements. The Singapore Exchange queried the company, but STATS waited until the next day to disclose information about a possible takeover bid, sparking questions about the effectiveness of the exchange's regulatory regime. The incident raises concerns about whether the exchange should pursue matters when companies disclose material information after a query, despite no suspension of trading. STATS' shares have continued to rise since then, fueling speculation about the takeover bid.

site_title: BW expands its chemical tanker fleet
summary: BW Group, a maritime transporter, has signed a purchase agreement to acquire 10 chemical tankers, including two existing vessels and eight newbuildings to be delivered between 2015 and 2018. The newbuildings will feature eco-design hulls and fuel-efficient engines. This expansion strengthens BW's service offering in the chemical tanker segment. The company also recently established a joint venture, BW Pacific, to purchase 10 product tankers and expand its presence in the product tanker market. The acquisition and joint venture are part of BW's efforts to strengthen its market position.

site_title: Pamphlet to promote navigational safety launched
summary: Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia have jointly launched a pamphlet, "The Safe Passage: The Straits of Singapore and Malacca," to promote navigational safety and marine environment protection in the Straits of Malacca and Singapore. The pamphlet, the result of a 2007 initiative, aims to enhance navigational safety and environmental protection in the area. It provides guidelines and best practices for users of the straits, highlighting the importance of adhering to International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea and offering advice on collision-prevention measures and local rules for ships.

site_title: Thai martial law seen having limited impact here
summary: Thailand's martial law, declared by the army to restore order, is expected to have a limited impact on the Singapore economy, with minimal effects observed so far. Singapore's Q1 GDP figures were released without any notable disruptions. The situation in Thailand, which has been marked by deadly street protests, is being closely monitored by observers, but the impact on Singapore is seen as contained if the situation does not escalate further.

site_title: SGX looks to cut dependency on domestic volumes
summary: SGX is partnering with Clearstream to launch a new collateral management service, aiming to reduce its dependency on domestic trading volumes. The new service, expected to be operational in 12-18 months, will help institutions allocate resources more efficiently between clearing and balance sheet management. Regulatory approval is still needed for the new business unit, but the partnership is a step towards diversifying SGX's revenue streams.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Exchange (SGX) is looking to reduce its dependency on trading volumes by partnering with Clearstream to begin a new collateral management service in 12 to 18 months - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Better showing for trade sector; IE maintains forecasts
summary: Singapore's trade sector showed improvement in the first quarter, with total trade expanding 7.2% year-on-year, but the government is maintaining its 1-3% growth forecast for trade and non-oil domestic exports. The decline in non-oil re-exports was mainly due to a drop in electronic exports, with domestic shipments of electronic products tumbling 12.8% year-on-year. Despite this, non-electronic exports rose 4.5% in the first quarter, driven by increases in exports to China, the US, and Indonesia.

site_title: New execs join Indian ship register
summary: The Indian Register of Shipping (IRClass) has announced new senior appointments in Singapore and London, aiming to expand its presence in international maritime centers. IRClass, founded in India in 1975, has achieved full member status in the International Association of Classification Societies (IACS) since 2010. The new appointments are part of IRClass's efforts to increase its global reach and provide ship classification and certification services.

site_title: Significant headway in TPP talks but no deal yet
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) talks made significant progress in market access and tariffs negotiations among 12 Pacific Rim nations, but no deal was reached during a two-day ministerial meeting in Singapore. The talks, which have been ongoing for four years, will continue indefinitely. US Trade Representative Michael Froman expressed optimism about a breakthrough, citing recent bilateral talks between the US and Japan, and a meeting in July to continue negotiations. A final agreement, if reached, would be the world's largest free-trade pact covering nearly 40% of the global economy.

site_title: Western landmark replicas in China entertain some, infuriate others
summary: China is building replicas of Western landmarks, dubbed "duplitecture," which have sparked both fascination and controversy. The trend, which has been ongoing for decades, features miniature versions of iconic structures such as Mount Rushmore, the Eiffel Tower, and an Austrian village. While some see the replicas as a sign of China's cultural exchange and admiration for Western styles, others view them as a form of copying and intellectual property theft. Experts argue that the replicas serve a practical purpose, allowing Chinese developers to convey prestige and success, but also raise questions about national pride and cultural identity.

site_title: Braemar buys British shipbroker ACM
summary: Braemar Shipping Services has agreed to acquire ACM Shipping Group, a British shipbroker, in the largest deal to date. The acquisition aims to grow Braemar's shipbroking presence collectively as the global economy recovers from the 2007-2009 downturn. Ship brokers are seeking to position themselves for a full market recovery, with many viewing bigger scale operations with global teams as the best way to continue earnings growth. The deal is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on improving sector conditions.

site_title: A tentative truce in Thailand
summary: Thailand's military has imposed martial law, but it appears to be a temporary measure, allowing the government to continue functioning. The real motive behind the move is unclear, but a government controlled by fugitive former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra is unlikely to be tenable. A compromise can only be reached if both sides agree to a roadmap to a return to a legitimate civilian government. The military has begun talks with both factions, and a royal decree to establish an interim council could be a potential solution, but a democratically elected government remains the ultimate goal.

site_title: Deutsche Bank tries ethics reform
summary: Deutsche Bank is taking steps to reform itself after past scandals, including raising €8 billion in new capital to reduce dependence on borrowed money and changing compensation practices to discourage short-term profit. The bank aims to achieve a return on equity of 13-15% and has established mandatory ethics seminars and compliance enforcers. However, critics argue that the bank's bonus systems are flawed and may encourage employees to pursue self-interest. Despite this, Deutsche Bank's co-CEO Anshu Jain believes the bank can compete in the global investment banking market and is committed to being a more ethical and responsible institution.

site_title: Financial insecurity up among S'poreans
summary: Financial insecurity among Singaporeans has nearly doubled in the last six months, with 36% of respondents feeling insecure, up from 19% in October 2013. The top two savings priorities remain retirement and "rainy day" emergencies, with 72% and 61% of respondents respectively. External events such as China's economic slowdown and the Ukrainian crisis are cited as contributing factors. Investor sentiment remains uncertain, but may be more bullish going forward, with equities and developed markets showing positive sentiment.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Yongnam Holdings has closed a probe on two top executives, CEO Seow Soon Yong and finance director Chia Sin Cheng, over possible insider trading breaches. Goodpack Ltd has denied reports it is being sold to KKR & Co, while Citic Private Equity Funds Management is considering options to enhance its Biosensors International Group investment. Meanwhile, Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi service to California and Arizona.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: MTI reported that 25% of retailers renewed shop leases with no rent increases or lower rents, and most rent hikes were in line with inflation. Thailand's martial law is expected to have a limited impact on Singapore's economy, unless it escalates. The 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership talks made significant progress in overcoming key issues. Singapore's GDP grew 4.9% in Q1, driven by a 9.8% expansion in manufacturing, while office Reits are expected to offer higher dividend yields than industrial Reits by 2016.

site_title: Top Philippine fund manager sells stocks as valuations rise
summary: Top Philippine fund manager Fitzgerald Aclan of BDO Unibank Inc is reducing equity holdings due to concerns a rally in valuations is poised to end, with the Philippine Stock Exchange Index potentially facing a correction. Valuations have reached 18.1 times estimated earnings, the highest in Asia since August, but Aclan believes the market may overshoot 7,000 and correct. BDO plans to introduce new funds giving clients access to overseas markets, and Aclan sees opportunities when the market corrects, citing improved macro fundamentals and investment-grade ratings.

site_title: Need to discourage Abe's military move
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's move to revise Japan's postwar constitution aims to enable the country to fulfill global responsibilities and engage in "collective self-defence". The proposed changes, which would allow Japan to aid allies in the event of an attack, have raised concerns about a more nationalist Japan and China's growing maritime power. The US is supporting Japan's more proactive role, potentially leading to expanded armed conflict in East Asia. The move contradicts Japan's constitution, which enshrines the country's vow not to venture into militarism, and may encourage China's assertiveness.

site_title: Modi's mandate can change India
summary: India's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won a landslide victory in the general election, securing 282 seats and an absolute majority, marking the end of 30 years of coalition politics. The BJP's victory suggests a shift towards "issues-based" politics, with voters prioritizing development, governance, and leadership over traditional identity politics. Economists hail the result as a "credit positive" event, with Moody's and Morgan Stanley predicting improved growth forecasts and a potential end to stagflation. However, the country still faces significant challenges, including high inflation, fiscal deficits, and infrastructure issues, which will need to be addressed to drive economic growth.

site_title: AirAsia X shares up 11% despite RM11.3m Q1 loss
summary: AirAsia X shares rose 11% to RM0.84 despite posting a Q1 net loss of RM11.3 million. The budget carrier saw a 40% increase in revenue to RM749.5 million, but losses were attributed to deferred taxation. Analysts expect losses to continue due to increased capacity and competition. However, restructuring of Malaysia Airlines could benefit AAX, particularly in the Australian market. The airline's China routes demand recovered after the MH370 tragedy, and a new budget terminal KLIA2 may improve yields and costs.

site_title: ST Engg unit buys Texas-based flight school
summary: ST Engineering's unit, Vision Technologies Aerospace Inc, has acquired Aviation Academy of America in Texas for $811,238 to expand its pilot training business. The acquisition will support the growing global demand for pilot training services. Aviation Academy of America will become a wholly owned subsidiary of VT Aerospace, expanding its global network and offering integrated pilot training services to customers worldwide.

site_title: Marks & Spencer warns that its new website will hit sales initially
summary: Marks & Spencer has warned that its new website may initially affect sales, taking 4-6 months to settle in. The company is shifting focus to higher-quality clothing and more fashionable styles to attract core customers and younger shoppers. Despite this, the retailer is optimistic about its supply chain and in-store clothing sales, which have picked up after three years of decline. Marks & Spencer plans to return excess cash to shareholders on a regular basis, with capital expenditure expected to fall in the next three years. The company's full-year sales were £10.3 billion, 2.7% higher than last year.

site_title: PM Lee: Japan needs 'trust and confidence' of neighbours
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for "trust and confidence" among Japan's neighbors to maintain stability in Asia. He rejected suggestions that the US presence in Asia is decreasing, acknowledging China's growing influence. Lee suggested that Japan and Asean nations should work together to establish a new balance in the region. He expressed confidence in Asean's ability to maintain robust economic growth and China's potential for annual growth of around 7%. Lee's visit to Tokyo comes amid strained relations between Japan and China, as well as with South Korea.

site_title: UGL may shelve A$1.2b sale of property services arm
summary: Australian engineering and property management company UGL Ltd is unlikely to proceed with the sale of its A$1.2 billion property services arm after receiving only one binding offer. The company, which had expected four bids by May 16, will instead focus on improving the unit's performance and may cancel plans to demerge its DTZ global real estate services business. TPG Capital Management LP is the only confirmed final bidder, but its offer may be below the expected price, leading UGL to reconsider its sale plan.

site_title: Jetstar strives to stay in the air, beat overcapacity
summary: Budget carrier Jetstar Asia is maintaining growth despite the regional airline industry's struggles with overcapacity. The carrier has increased aircraft utilisation, reduced costs, and deferred new plane deliveries to stay profitable. Jetstar Asia's average load factor remains above 80%, and yields are 10% higher than the industry average. The airline has also invested in technology to operate more efficiently, such as a virtual customer service website and self-check-in kiosks. By being prudent and pragmatic, Jetstar Asia is eking out growth in a challenging operating environment.

images.alt_text: Mr Pasupathi: Says Jetstar Asia's yields are about 10 per cent higher than the industry average for low-cost carriers operating out of Singapore

site_title: SMRT shares jump to 11-month high
summary: SMRT Corp shares surged to an 11-month high, jumping 14.5 cents or 11% to $1.475, driven by speculation of an imminent industry shake-up or policy changes in the public transportation space. Analysts believe the surge may be linked to the transport operator's submission of a new rail-financing framework, which could benefit operators. However, the details of the framework remain unclear, making the impact uncertain.

site_title: Olam secures US$2.2b credit facility
summary: Olam International has secured a US$2.22 billion revolving credit facility to refinance debt and meet working capital needs. The facility will improve the company's debt balance and reduce overall borrowing costs. Olam's executive director of finance and business development stated that the firm will continue to monitor and optimize its debt portfolio. This move aims to enhance the company's financial stability and flexibility.

site_title: Study finds Reit-property return correlation
summary: A study by IPD found that listed real estate in Asia is positively correlated with direct property returns, with the greatest exposure found in Australia-listed real estate, followed by Singapore and Japan. However, the correlation was weakest in Hong Kong, possibly due to its exposure to overseas assets. Adjusting for appraisal and lag factors improved correlations, suggesting investment in Asian listed property provides some exposure to local direct property markets, with little diversification benefit.

site_title: Clarification
summary: CDL clarified that it did not cut prices for its condo project, but the units were sold at a lower price than initially planned, averaging $980 psf compared to the target of $1,100-$1,200 psf. The project is near an MRT station, and the lower price was likely due to market conditions rather than a price cut.

site_title: Analysts predict long bull run for Indian stocks
summary: Analysts predict a long bull run for Indian stocks following Narendra Modi's opposition bloc's largest electoral victory in 30 years. Companies likely to benefit from a strengthening economy, such as banks, utilities, and industrials, are expected to outperform. The value of Indian equities has risen 37% since Modi's nomination, with foreigners investing $14.4 billion. Analysts predict a 15-17% increase in the S&P BSE Sensex by the end of 2015, with some forecasting a bull run for the next three to five years.

site_title: Zoopla to reveal listing plans this week
summary: British property website Zoopla plans to announce a £1 billion stock market listing, valuing the company at about £1 billion, this week. The flotation will be backed by newspaper publisher Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT), which controls 51% of Zoopla. The company's underlying earnings rose 26% to £18.7 million between October and March. Plans for the listing were confirmed by DMGT's release of its latest financial results, which will include selling a "substantial number" of shares.

site_title: Tax code driving Swedish runaway housing prices
summary: Sweden's National Board of Housing, Building and Planning urges politicians to drop a 22% capital gains tax on housing, citing it as a major contributor to the country's unsustainable housing prices. The tax has kept the market "boiling" under a shortage of supply, with apartment prices tripling since the early 2010s. Many Swedes are reluctant to move due to the tax, leading to distorted property prices and excessive debt. The government has shown reluctance to tamper with property taxes, but economists and policymakers are calling for measures to cool the market, including increased construction and laxer building rules.

site_title: Klepierre plans to buy out mall partners in expansion drive
summary: Klepierre SA, a Paris-based shopping mall landlord, plans to spend up to 500 million euros annually on expansion and may buy out minority stakes from partners in jointly owned shopping centers. The company aims to focus on high-quality properties in growing regions, such as southern Europe, where it operates 28 malls. Klepierre's CEO, Laurent Morel, cited the acquisition of a 50% stake in a mall in Montpellier, France, as an example of its expansion strategy.

site_title: OCBC Aquatic Centre set for 1st big event
summary: The OCBC Aquatic Centre, the first facility of the $1.3-billion Singapore Sports Hub, has opened with a competition pool, training pool, and deep-diving pool. The 6,000-seater arena will host the TYR 2nd South-east Asian Swimming Championships from June 14 to 26. The facility is part of a 15-year naming rights deal with OCBC, worth over $50 million. The Sports Hub is set to become fully operational next year, with the National Stadium and OCBC Arena opening next month, followed by test events to iron out kinks.

site_title: Malaysia, Inmarsat to release satellite data used in MH370 search
summary: Malaysia and Inmarsat are set to release satellite data used in the search for missing flight MH370, which vanished on March 8, 2014. The data, which showed the Boeing 777 met its fate in the southern Indian Ocean, is expected to be made public for independent analysis. The data release follows a joint statement from Malaysia's Department of Civil Aviation and Inmarsat, with no timeline provided for its release. The investigation is ongoing, with Australia leading the search operation and a Chinese vessel to survey the ocean floor at the suspected location.

site_title: Manufacturing drives economy up 4.9%
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector continued to drive economic growth in Q1, with a 4.9% year-on-year expansion, despite slower growth in the services and construction sectors. The 9.8% manufacturing growth helped offset the slower pace of growth in these sectors. The government maintains its 2014 GDP growth forecast at 2-4%. However, some economists believe the recent manufacturing growth may not be sustainable, with a slowdown expected in the second quarter. The global economy is expected to continue improving modestly in 2014, supported by a sustained recovery in the US and eurozone.

site_title: S'pore is SEA's most active private equity market in 2013
summary: Singapore emerged as the most active private equity market in South-east Asia in 2013, with a deal value of US$3 billion, accounting for 60% of the region's US$5 billion deal value. The market saw a surge in early-stage and startup deals, with a 292% year-on-year increase in deal value. This growth is attributed to government support for seed-level funding and a growing startup ecosystem.

site_title: DBS to get new head of capital markets
summary: DBS Bank is set to appoint Eric Ang as senior executive adviser, focusing on business origination and high-level relationship building. Ang, a veteran banker with over 35 years of experience, will step down as head of capital markets on June 1, handing over the role to Eng-Kwok Seat Moey. The bank has consistently topped the Singapore capital markets league tables, with a 17.8% market share in equity last year. DBS is looking to capitalize on opportunities in the sluggish equity market, focusing on Reits and defensive investments.

site_title: Somali piracy in decline but threat remains
summary: Somali piracy has significantly declined since its peak in 2011, with the European anti-piracy fleet Atalanta reporting no major vessel captures since May 2012. Despite this, the threat remains, with pirates still present on the coast and targeting fishing vessels. The presence of armed guards, increased navigation speeds, and deterrence measures have had a dissuasive effect, but experts warn that the economic model of piracy has been broken and that the threat could resurface if measures are relaxed. Efforts to train coast guards and establish legislation to manage maritime waters are ongoing.

site_title: Diversification may be Wilmar's trump card
summary: Wilmar International's first-quarter results showed a 49% decline in net profit to US$161.8 million, amid negative margins for its soybean processing operations. The company's share price dropped 5.4% to $3.16, but recovered to $3.23. Despite six consecutive quarters of profits in its oilseeds division, the negative margins have raised concerns about the company's diversification strategy. Analysts have downgraded Wilmar, citing the disappointing results as a setback to the company's growth prospects.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines shares hit record low
summary: Malaysia Airlines shares plummeted 18.6% to a record low of 15.5 sen after Prime Minister Najib Razak mentioned the possibility of bankruptcy due to the airline's financial struggles, exacerbated by negative sentiments and declining bookings following the disappearance of flight MH370. The airline has lost RM4 billion in the past three years, with analysts projecting hefty losses for FY2014 and FY2015. The Malaysian Airlines System Employees union wants the CEO to leave and urges the government to assist the airline, citing its significant employment and government ownership.

site_title: Stock indices near new highs despite mixed data
summary: US stock indices closed near record highs despite mixed economic data and disappointing earnings reports. The Federal Reserve's comments on Wednesday will influence traders. Economists downgraded second-quarter growth projections due to weak data, including a 0.6% decline in industrial output. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is near a record high, driven by "value" stocks and dividend-paying blue chips, while the Russell 2000 has recorded an official correction.

site_title: Martial law move dents Thai stocks
summary: Thailand's army imposed martial law nationwide amid persistent political turmoil, causing the benchmark stock index to drop 1.1% and the baht to decline 0.6% against the US dollar. The move is not a coup, according to Army Chief Prayuth Chan-Ocha, and aims to force politicians to negotiate. The economy is already facing challenges, with a 0.6% decline in GDP in the first quarter of 2014. Analysts believe the martial law may help break the country's political deadlock, but foreign investors may be wary of the move's implications.

site_title: Park formally apologises over ferry disaster
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye formally apologized for the ferry disaster that killed about 300 passengers, mostly school children, on April 16. The disaster was attributed to the coast guard's failure in its rescue mission. President Park announced her intention to break up the coast guard due to the incident. Polls show a significant drop in support for the president, who has been under intense public pressure over the government's response. At least 286 people were killed, with 18 remaining missing, and only 172 were rescued.

site_title: Top execs' pay: Should shareholders have a say?
summary: Singapore-listed companies should consider giving shareholders a say in top executives' pay, ensuring direct accountability and building bench strength. This practice, known as "say on pay," is already adopted by countries such as the UK, US, and Australia. However, some argue that it could have a negative impact on companies, deterring talent and damaging prospects. The Singapore Corporate Awards seminar highlighted the importance of corporate governance and the need for a balanced approach to regulation. The government must decide whether to adopt this practice, weighing the benefits against potential drawbacks.

site_title: Jurong Aromatics complex set to start up soon: chief exec
summary: Singapore's US$2.4 billion Jurong Aromatics Corporation (JAC) complex is set to start up in August 2014, ahead of its initial baseline schedule. The integrated refinery/aromatics complex will produce 1.5 million tonnes of aromatics annually, including paraxylene, benzene, and orthoxylene, for various industries. The project is backed by eight international shareholders and the Singapore government, ensuring a stable feedstock supply. The start-up will also utilize the newly opened Jurong Rock Cavern, occupying its first two caverns.

site_title: US in anti-dumping probe against two China box makers
summary: US trade authorities are investigating Chinese container makers Singamas Container Holdings Ltd and China International Marine Containers (Group) Co Ltd (CIMC) for alleged anti-dumping practices. The probe, scheduled for a preliminary decision on June 9, alleges the companies' 53-foot domestic dry containers are subsidized by the Chinese government and sold in the US, with a dumping margin of 84.07% and a subsidy rate of at least 2%. Both companies claim the probe will have little impact on their performance and are seeking legal advice.

site_title: Goodpack hits highs amid reports of KKR talks
summary: Goodpack's shares reached record highs amid reports of a potential US$1 billion deal with private equity firm KKR & Co. The company's shares rose two cents to S$2.47, following increased trading volumes. Goodpack's founder, David Lam, owns 32% of the firm and is open to a takeover offer. The deal would mark KKR's first acquisition in Southeast Asia since 2012. Analysts attribute Goodpack's appeal to its strong market position and global network.

site_title: Nasa to test drone in commercial airspace
summary: NASA is set to test its Predator drone in commercial airspace, aiming to prove the safety of large unmanned aircraft operating alongside commercial planes. The tests, scheduled for early 2015, will study sense-and-avoid technology that warns remote pilots of nearby aircraft. Researchers hope to design systems allowing big drones to fly above 18,000 feet, paving the way for future pilotless aircraft to haul freight or beam internet signals. The goal is to ensure safe coexistence with commercial air traffic.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to capitalize on Asia's rising markets, according to the Prime Minister's Office. Meanwhile, Goodpack shares surged amid talks with US private equity firm KKR & Co. Tokyo aims to become the world's first city, while Malaysia Airlines shares hit a record low due to the possibility of bankruptcy. Singapore's banks outperformed in Q1, while domestic wholesale trade declined 2.8%. Bank Negara may raise interest rates due to Malaysia's 6.2% GDP growth, and Chinese corruption charges against GlaxoSmithKline executives could have industry-wide implications.

site_title: Making a splash
summary: Singapore's OCBC Aquatic Centre at the Singapore Sports Hub was officially completed with a ceremony, marking its first use by past and present national swimmers. The facility, which was toured by Culture and Youth Minister Lawrence Wong and other VIPs, is part of the Singapore Sports Hub. No specific opening date or events were mentioned.

site_title: S'pore 'well-placed to capitalise on Asia's rise'
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to capitalize on Asia's rising economy, according to the Prime Minister's Office. The government aims to make Singapore a "nation of opportunities" where every citizen can succeed, regardless of their starting point. Key initiatives include strengthening education and training, developing career pathways, and investing in research and development. Ministries have pledged to support small and medium-sized enterprises, enhance job facilitation efforts, and upgrade infrastructure. The government expects 40,000 to 45,000 young Singaporeans to enter the job market each year, with two-thirds aiming for professional, managerial, executive, and technical roles.

images.alt_text: Asia is on the ascent and Singapore is well-positioned to capitalise on this rise, said the Prime Minister's Office (PMO) yesterday in a statement on behalf of the government - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Banks: the new eager beavers on the social media scene
summary: Banks in Singapore are shifting their focus to mobile banking customers, rewarding loyalty with new services. A survey found frequent mobile banking users show higher loyalty scores than traditional customers. As technology advances, Asian banks have an advantage in adapting to digital systems, while Western lenders struggle with legacy issues and regulations. To stay competitive, banks will partner with start-ups and innovators, providing security and agility. The trend highlights the evolving nature of banking, with digital services becoming increasingly important.

site_title: EU may challenge Boeing's tax breaks
summary: The European Union is considering challenging the US tax breaks given to Boeing, which could deepen the bitter trade dispute between the two planemakers. The EU argues that the tax breaks, worth $8.7 billion, are specific and harmful subsidies, while Boeing claims they are designed to comply with World Trade Organization rulings. The move could lead to sanctions and affect the production of Boeing's 777X and Airbus's A350 jets, which are competing for sales in the coming years.

site_title: Banks steal the show in Q1
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, led the earnings reports in Q1 with DBS posting a net profit of $1.23 billion, followed by OCBC Bank and UOB. Integrated property developer OUE also reported a significant increase in net profit to $946 million. These banks' strong performances were highlighted as they dominated the top earnings list, with 360 firms issuing their earnings reports by the end of the first quarter.

site_title: BlackBerry, Foxconn tie-up signals shifting priorities
summary: BlackBerry has partnered with Foxconn to sell its Z3 smartphone, a budget-friendly device priced at $190, in a bid to shift focus from hardware to services and software. The move comes as the company's sales have plummeted globally, with 1.3 million phones sold in the last quarter, down from 6 million a year earlier. The partnership aims to eliminate financial uncertainties and reduce development cycles, with Foxconn assuming the risk of unsold phones and providing buying power. This may buy BlackBerry time, but analysts question the company's viability in the consumer electronics market.

site_title: Knight Frank sees sustained demand for dual-key homes
summary: Knight Frank reports sustained demand for dual-key homes in Singapore's private residential market, driven by yield-seeking investors and young families seeking multi-generational living. The concept, introduced in 1986, has seen a 35% increase in dual-key units across 74 projects since 2011. Developers have allocated 7.5% of units for dual-key, citing buyers' preference for the living concept. The additional buyers' stamp duty also favors dual-key units, allowing buyers to rent out the sub-unit.

site_title: Mexico's Ara suspends malls' collective sale
summary: Consorcio Ara SAB has suspended an auction to sell a group of US$387 million shopping malls in Mexico, after the top bidder failed to secure financing. The company, which owns the malls with O'Connor Capital Partners, is now considering selling the centers individually. This decision comes as the home-building industry in Mexico faces a shift in government housing policy, causing Ara to forego a cash infusion. The company is not in a rush to sell, prioritizing the best offer.

site_title: An app that keeps things casual for users
summary: Singaporean entrepreneur Daniel Chia has launched BlastOut, a geo-located and mobile-only social networking app that lets users create temporary private social networks around events. The app, valued at $2 million, allows users to connect anonymously and swap contacts, with content disappearing after seven days. Chia aims to put the "social" back into social networking, encouraging users to live in the moment. With $200,000 in angel funding, BlastOut is set to expand into London and the US, targeting businesses to leverage its geolocation function to reach customers nearby.

site_title: Governor plans to make Tokyo 'first city in the world'
summary: Tokyo Governor Yoichi Masuzoe has outlined a plan to transform the city into the "first city in the world" by 2020, with a focus on becoming a global hub for business, finance, and innovation. He aims to "take back" Tokyo's lead from Singapore as a drug development centre and push the city ahead of Hong Kong and Singapore as a financial centre. Masuzoe plans to reform regulations and attract foreigners, with a focus on creating a special economic zone for global innovation.

site_title: Activity trackers only track tip of the iceberg: Zensorium
summary: Singapore-based research spinoff Zensorium has developed a smartphone attachment called Tinke, which tracks vital signs such as resting heart rate and oxygen levels in the blood. Unlike fitness trackers, Tinke provides a more comprehensive view of a user's health. The device was created by Zensorium, which was spun off from Japanese chemicals giant Nitto Denko in 2008. Tinke's technology could revolutionize the way people monitor their health, offering a more accurate and detailed picture of their well-being.

site_title: Multiple directorships: How many is enough?
summary: A study of Singaporean companies found that the average director has an average of 1.3 board affiliations. While there is no numerical limit prescribed in Singapore, regulators are aware of the potential pitfalls of multiple directorships, which can lead to time fragmentation and ineffective governance. The effectiveness of multiple directorships depends on various factors, including the director's time commitment and the complexity of the companies they serve. The Singapore Institute of Directors recommends that shareholders exercise their voice and hold their boards accountable for appointing directors with sufficient time and attention to protect their interests.

site_title: Tapping into AEC's free flow of resources
summary: The Asean Economic Community (AEC) is set to launch in 2015, aiming to create a single market with a population of 600 million, free flow of skilled labor, services, investments, and capital. Businesses are gearing up to ride the market opportunities, with some prioritizing local presence and others focusing on establishing distribution channels. The AEC is expected to eliminate trade barriers, facilitating the free flow of goods, services, and capital, and will bring tremendous opportunities for businesses, including increased competition, productivity, and growth. However, challenges such as country and political risks, talent mobility, and infrastructure development must be addressed.

site_title: Gamification a growing trend: DBS, SingTel
summary: DBS Bank and SingTel see gamification as a key trend to boost customer engagement and business success. Gamification involves using gaming elements in non-gaming environments to increase consumer interaction. DBS Bank's vice-president Christopher Ng believes this trend will translate into better customer acquisition and awareness if done correctly. The companies see opportunities to leverage "dead time" on mobile devices to engage customers and increase brand awareness.

site_title: Pros and cons as firms go big on data
summary: Financial institutions are leveraging big data and analytics, combined with on-the-go technologies, to gain a competitive advantage. However, proper implementation is crucial to avoid problems. Industry specialists agree that data analytics is a source of competitive advantage, but firms must be cautious not to over-spend on data without actionable insights. Key challenges include integrating data from structured and unstructured sources, ensuring timely and relevant information for frontline staff, and differentiating products and services in a crowded market. To succeed, firms need a robust infrastructure, strong security principles, and a customer-centric approach to redefinition of short- and long-term customer profitability.

site_title: Institutional interest in Basel III bonds gains strength
summary: UOB issues its fourth Basel III-compliant bond, a $500 million Singapore-dollar callable bond, which was taken up by 40% of insurance companies and 34% by high net worth individuals. The bonds offer a 3.5% interest rate and are due in 2026, with the option to be redeemed in 2020. This represents a significant shift in institutional interest, with 11% of insurance companies participating in the first issue, and a 25 basis point tighter pricing compared to the initial guidance. The bond's competitive pricing reflects Singapore banks' strong credit standing and disciplined approach to growth.

site_title: OCBC to disburse first WCS payouts
summary: OCBC Bank has announced its first Wage Credit Scheme (WCS) payouts to 1,500 eligible Singaporean employees, totaling $3 million. The payouts, funded by the government, will be disbursed in June and July and can be either credited to employees' Central Provident Fund (CPF) accounts or invested in blue-chip stocks through the OCBC Blue Chip Investment Plan. The move aims to empower employees to manage their finances effectively and contribute to their long-term savings or investment plans.

site_title: Lufthansa latest to halt ticket sales to Caracas
summary: Lufthansa has suspended ticket sales to Caracas, joining airlines that have stopped flights due to Venezuela's currency controls. The airline cited its significant losses, with an equivalent of US$3.9 billion stuck in bolivars. This move comes after Copa Holdings SA cut routes to Venezuela, citing US$488 million owed by the government. The International Air Transport Association reported airlines had an equivalent of US$3.9 billion stuck in bolivars as of April.

site_title: A layman's guide to the shipping industry
summary: The shipping industry is a vital component of global commerce, transporting 90% of the world's goods. Despite its importance, the industry is complex, with a web of customs, jargon, and economic dynamics that can be daunting for laymen. Understanding merchant shipping can provide insight into the recovery of world trade, consumption patterns of commodities, and China's shipbuilding industry, which is a core economic driver. A basic understanding of the industry can also shed light on the trajectory of global trade and economic trends.

site_title: Containers, bulk carriers and tankers
summary: Merchant ships are categorized into three main types: bulk carriers, container ships, and tankers. Bulk carriers convey unpacked commodities, such as oil or chemicals, and dry bulk goods like grains or ore. Container ships carry packaged cargo in 20-40 foot metal containers, while tankers are designed to store liquids or gases in bulk, providing a crucial means of transporting fuel to areas without pipelines. These types of ships play a vital role in global trade and energy supply.

site_title: OSX Brasil offers to pay debt over 25 years
summary: OSX Brasil, a bankrupt shipbuilder, has proposed a plan to pay $2.6 billion in debt over 25 years to a court. The company, controlled by former billionaire Eike Batista, will start repaying debts after three years and can seek new capital through the sale of stakes to investors. OSX aims to generate new revenue by partnering with investors interested in using areas at the Port of Acu complex. The plan comes as the EBX Group, once a high-flying conglomerate, has seen its value nearly evaporate since 2011.

site_title: Dassault Systèmes aims to tap more of Asean potential
summary: Dassault Systèmes, a French software giant, aims to expand its presence in Southeast Asia, particularly in the life sciences, banking, and retail sectors. The company, which has 12,000 employees and $2.1 billion in earnings, is focusing on the "3D experience" - simulating a business from design to customer interaction. Dassault has acquired several companies, including Realtime Technology AG and Accelerys, to develop its 3D software. The company plans to penetrate the region, which currently accounts for only 2% of its business, and is eyeing countries such as Indonesia and Malaysia.

site_title: Signs show London residential property market has peaked
summary: London's residential property market appears to have peaked, with prime properties showing resistance to further price increases. Foreign buyers, particularly Asian investors, have become wary due to rising prices, sterling's appreciation, and potential tax changes. Only 9% of £2 million+ properties and 3% of £10 million+ properties have sold in recent months. Experts warn that a bubble may be forming, and interest rate hikes may be imminent, which could lead to a decline in prices. The market is expected to experience a slowdown in the coming months, with a potential increase in supply.

site_title: Kanesaka branches out
summary: Shinji Kanesaka, a two-Michelin-starred sushi chef, has reopened his second outlet in Singapore at the St Regis hotel. The new restaurant, Shinji By Kanesaka, features larger premises and luxurious digs, but the quality of the sushi remains inconsistent, with some dishes standing out, such as the grilled nodokuro and crab meat dishes. While the restaurant offers a high-end experience, it cannot replicate the unique personal touch of its master chef, Shinji Kanesaka, who is no longer present. The restaurant's rating is 7 out of 10, with a price range of $125 to $450 for lunch and dinner.

site_title: Brazil's new airport terminal glistens amid stumbles
summary: Brazil's new Guarulhos International Airport terminal 3, which opened last week, is a rare success story ahead of the June World Cup, receiving praise for its sleek design and sustainable features. The terminal, built with a 2.9 billion real budget, was completed on time and features water recycling and heat-filter windows. It dwarfs the older terminals, with the capacity to receive 12 million passengers annually. This is a rare bright spot in Brazil's World Cup preparations, which have been marred by cost overruns, worker deaths, and protests over public spending priorities.

site_title: Beauty in simplicity
summary: Landscape designer Yamaguchi Yosuke, from Japan, is participating in the Singapore Garden Festival with a practical and simple garden design that incorporates natural elements and Japanese culture. He believes that style is not as important as functionality and longevity. For this festival, he will be using tropical plants sourced from Singapore and Malaysia, creating a garden that can be enjoyed through all five senses, including a natural stream, tea room, and elements that evoke the Japanese spirit.

site_title: Shanmugam welcomes firmer action by Vietnam
summary: Singapore Foreign Minister K Shanmugam welcomed Vietnam's assurance of firm action against protests at two Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Parks (VSIPs). Shanmugam expressed concern over the riots and highlighted the impact on business confidence. Vietnamese Deputy Prime Minister Pham Binh Minh assured Shanmugam that Vietnam will take necessary steps to protect the parks and take firm action against the situation. The protests occurred in Binh Duong province, and both countries have endorsed the VSIPs.

site_title: Singapore artist hurt in HK, police investigating
summary: Singapore artist Lee Wen was hospitalized in Hong Kong after a suspected assault at a university. He lost consciousness and woke up with cuts, bruises, and blood on his face. Lee Wen reported no recollection of the incident, stating he blacked out and didn't feel anyone approaching. The police are investigating the incident.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore saw a busy first quarter for mergers and acquisitions, driven by property sector privatisations. The London residential property market is expected to peak due to foreign buyers' concerns over prices, taxes, and potential Bank of England action. SCP Consultants aims to expand into new territories with its new president. US stocks are influenced by the Federal Reserve's comments, while institutional interest in UOB's bond issue was high. Property developer City Developments cut prices for its Coco Palms launch, and gamification is becoming a key trend in business.

site_title: Where hospitality meets fitness
summary: Fitness First CEO Andy Cosslett emphasizes the importance of customer service in the hospitality and fitness industries. As a former CEO of InterContinental Hotels Group, Cosslett aims to bring together the two sectors to create a unique experience for Fitness First's one million members. He believes delivering the human touch is key to retaining customers, focusing on frequent interactions to build loyalty and satisfaction.

images.alt_text: Mr Cosslett: 'The daily rate of joining our system of clubs in Singapore is the price of a cup of coffee. I don't see any problem in people buying a cup of coffee every day, so it depends on what you value in your life . . . Don't buy that extra caffeine. Get a gym membership instead.'

site_title: Bumper Q1 for M&A in Singapore
summary: Singapore's M&A activity saw a bumper Q1, driven by privatisations in the property sector, with bankers citing the trend as a positive indicator. The sector's growth is attributed to privatisations, and dealmakers expect more transactions to follow. However, minority shareholders' and activists' growing dissent could impact deal pricing. Despite this, bankers remain optimistic about the pipeline of deals. The surge in Chinese property shares also suggests a potential revival in the sector, although unverified reports contribute to the uncertainty.

site_title: Buying stays flat; selling resumes
summary: Singapore Exchange filings reveal flat buying activity by directors for the third straight week, while selling resumed with 18 purchases worth $9.67 million and 5 disposals worth $10.15 million. Notable buys include Raffles Education Corp ($9.67 million), Sinjia Land ($10.14 million), and Asiaphos Ltd ($16.7 cents). Selling activity includes chairman Daniel Benjamin Glinert of Sarine Technologies, who unloaded 225,000 shares at $2.56 each, and Fil Limited, which disposed of 1.38 million shares at $2.61 each.

site_title: Clarification
summary: SingTel reported a 3.5% increase in Q4 profit to $898m, but missed analyst estimates of $916.3m for adjusted net income. The correct comparison should be against $904m for net income GAAP.

site_title: Covert operations
summary: Two exclusive, under-the-radar bars in Singapore cater to a niche crowd seeking unique experiences. Operation Dagger, opening in June, features a Prohibition-era style underground venue with medicinal-looking brown glass bottles and bespoke cocktails made in-house. The bar's core aim is to make spirits, liqueurs, and bitters entirely in-house, using traditional techniques and modern gadgets. Bar Council, another covert watering hole, specializes in "multi sensory cocktails" made bespoke, with a focus on molecular techniques and no menu. Both bars operate by appointment only, with limited capacity to accommodate a select clientele.

site_title: UOB first Asian bank to become Eurex Clearing member
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is the first Asian bank to become a member of Eurex Clearing, the clearing house for the Deutsche Borse group. This move aims to support Asian investors and corporates in diversifying their investments. UOB's brokerage arm, UOB Bullion and Futures, has been a trading member of Eurex Exchange since 2008, and the new clearing membership complements their services. Eurex Clearing sees this as an important step to expand its presence in Asia, while UOB hopes to corner a 5% market share in clearing volume for Asian benchmark indices contracts in two years.

site_title: SingPost's Q4 profit up 17.7% to $30.7m
summary: SingPost reported a 17.7% year-on-year rise in Q4 net profit to $30.7m, largely due to one-off expenses in the previous period. Excluding these items, underlying net profit fell 1.3% to $31.4m. Revenue grew 5.9% to $193.3m, driven by e-commerce growth and a decline in traditional postal business. For the full year, net profit rose 4.8% to $143.1m, with revenue increasing 24.6% to $821.1m. The company attributed growth to regional e-commerce transhipment business and improved direct mail revenue.

site_title: Mapletree Investments FY14 earnings down 7.8%
summary: Mapletree Investments, a subsidiary of Temasek Holdings, reported FY14 earnings of $859.4 million, down 7.8% from FY13, due to a 20.1% decline in total turnover to $548.6 million. Despite this, the group aims to grow net asset value by over 10% annually for the next five years. Total assets under management rose to $24.6 billion, with 74% held by third-party assets. The group has set a target to expand into new regions and sectors, including Europe and the US, to diversify earnings.

site_title: Olam to invest US$61m in cocoa plant
summary: Olam International will invest US$61 million to establish a new cocoa processing facility in Indonesia, with an initial capacity of 60,000 tonnes, expected to start operations in early 2016. This follows Cargill's announcement of cocoa processing tests at its Gresik, East Java, plant, which will process 70,000 tonnes of cocoa beans into cocoa powder, butter, and liquor when it opens fully later this year.

site_title: CapitaLand sweetens delisting offer for CMA with higher price of $2.35 per share
summary: CapitaLand has increased its delisting offer for CapitaMalls Asia (CMA) to $2.35 per share, exceeding the mean broker price target and eliminating a discount to its adjusted net asset value. The offer price, which is ex-FY2013 final dividend, is non-negotiable and has been extended to June 9 from May 26. This move is seen as a concession to CMA shareholders who were initially unhappy with the initial offer price of $2.22, with some suggesting a higher price of $2.45-$2.55 would have been more acceptable.

site_title: Wilmar JV closer to Goodman Fielder buyout
summary: Wilmar International and First Pacific Company are moving forward with their joint takeover of Australian food company Goodman Fielder after the Goodman board recommended accepting their 50:50 joint venture's bid. The companies initially offered 65 Australian cents per share, later raising the bid to 70 Australian cents, valuing Goodman at A$1.37 billion. The due diligence process is expected to take several weeks and is not expected to impact Wilmar's earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Herbalife thrives despite being under attack
summary: Herbalife, a US-listed nutrition company, is thriving despite being under attack from hedge fund billionaire Bill Ackman, who labelled the firm a pyramid scheme and forecast a plummeting stock price. Despite Ackman's claims, Herbalife's sales grew 18% in 2013 to a record $4.8 billion, and the company has maintained a strong business despite negative publicity. The firm's counter-offensive, including a $1.5 billion share buyback plan, has helped to boost investor sentiment, with the stock nearly doubling in value since December 2012.

site_title: New SCP head leads it into new territories
summary: SCP Consultants, a Singapore-based urban planning firm, has appointed a new president, Foo Say Boon, to lead the company into new territories, including Indonesia, India, and Cambodia. With a focus on expanding into architecture, landscaping, and interior design, SCP aims to acquire companies to gain expertise quickly. The company, which has grown rapidly in China due to the country's urbanization drive, plans to increase its employee count to 280 by the end of this year and 350 by next year. SCP is also exploring opportunities in rural China and South-east Asia, and is not afraid to challenge markets, having recently competed in design competitions in Nigeria and South Sudan.

site_title: New engine, old school
summary: The Volkswagen Touran TDI, a compact seven-seater MPV, has been updated with a frugal 1.6-litre turbodiesel engine, allowing it to remain in COE Category A. The new engine produces 105 hp and 250 Nm, and is paired with a 7-speed dual-clutch transmission. The Touran's handling is praised for its solidity and weight, making it a pleasant drive despite its old-school feel. With a fuel efficiency of 22 km per litre, the Touran TDI is also an economical choice, priced at $149,800 (with COE) in Singapore.

site_title: Tykes with 'tude
summary: Homegrown designers are capitalizing on the trend of celebrity kids' fashion, offering stylish and affordable clothing options for young children. Inspired by the "Kate effect" and the wardrobes of kids like Prince George, Aila Wang, and the Beckhams, these entrepreneurs are creating mini-me versions of trendy outfits without the high price tags. Le Petit Society and Blueprint are among the brands leading the charge, offering comfortable and affordable clothing designed and produced in Asia. This trend is seen as a response to the lack of exceptional Asian children's wear brands, catering to the growing demand for stylish and affordable kids' fashion.

site_title: Rum's the word
summary: Jigger and Pony's second outlet, Sugarhall, has opened on Amoy Street with a focus on rum-based cocktails and a grill-centric menu. The bar features over 50 labels of rum, 18 signature cocktails, and a menu of grass-fed beef steaks and veggie-focused sides. Owner Indra Kantono aimed to create a casual, social atmosphere with a summer block party vibe, offering rum and grill pairings that are "more playful and relaxed" than its sister outlet.

site_title: More PDPA guidelines and initiatives in store
summary: The Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) in Singapore is set to fully kick in on July 2, with three new sectors - healthcare, education, and social services - receiving sector-specific guidelines. The guidelines aim to clarify how personal data will be handled in these sectors, including the collection of patient data in healthcare and the disclosure of student information in education. Public consultations for other sectors, including banking and life insurance, are also planned. To aid firms in complying with the new law, the government is offering training courses and resources, including a free e-learning program and mediation services for disputes.

site_title: Singapore books first corporate Lion City bond
summary: Singapore has issued the country's first corporate "Lion City" bond, worth 1.7 billion yuan (S$341 million), by a Hong Kong subsidiary of Hainan Airlines. The bonds, which will mature in three years, pay a 6.25% coupon and were priced this week. The issuance was well received by financial institutions, with a subscription rate of 2.2 times, highlighting the attractiveness of Singapore as an offshore RMB bond market. This marks the first corporate Lion City bond and further develops the Singapore offshore RMB bond market.

site_title: Salone fresh
summary: The annual Milan Salone Internazionale del Mobile furniture fair has highlighted 10 new designs from designers worldwide. The showcase includes the BD Barcelona Design's wooden version of Jaime Haydon's Multileg Cabinet, Poltronau Frau's Albero bookcase, and Artifort's Gemini seats. Other notable designs include Fiam's Ceralacca coffee table, Sancal Studio's Perigallo stool, and Boffi's Outliner Lights. The collection also features unique pieces like Oki Sato's Peg Mirror, Magis' Trotter chair, and Daniel Libeskind's Web bookcase. The designs blend functionality, sustainability, and creativity, reflecting the evolving needs of home furnishings.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC shares up 19.5% on news of possible buyout
summary: STATS ChipPAC shares rose 19.5% on news of a possible buyout from a third party, with the company stating that the acquisition is subject to conditions. The company, which is majority-owned by Temasek Holdings, has received a non-binding expression of interest but has cautioned that there is no assurance of a definitive agreement. The likely suitor is speculated to be a semiconductor company or technology investment group.

site_title: Najib: Bankruptcy an option being considered to restructure MAS
summary: Malaysia Airlines is considering bankruptcy as a restructuring option due to its financial struggles. The airline's Q1 loss widened to RM443m, from RM279m in 2013. Prime Minister Najib Razak mentioned bankruptcy as one of the options being considered, following the tragic loss of the MH370 jetliner, which may be too far gone to be salvaged.

site_title: A grand affair
summary: The Nissan Elgrand has received a major facelift for the 2014 model year, featuring a new and luxurious cabin, LED front and tail lamps, and 18-inch alloy rims. The updated interior boasts opulent seats, cruise control, and navigation, while the spacious interior offers a walk-through aisle and excellent headroom. However, the 2.5-litre engine is underpowered, and the CVT transmission can be slow and unresponsive. Despite these limitations, the Elgrand's luxurious features make it an attractive option in the premium MPV market.

site_title: Viet protests a 'wake-up call' for S'pore firms
summary: Over 20 people died in Vietnam as anti-China protests spread, with a steel plant set ablaze by rioters. The unrest, sparked by China's deployment of an oil rig in disputed waters, has raised concerns for Singapore firms with investments in the country. Analysts warn that the situation could disrupt operations and urge companies to reassess risks. Singapore companies have stepped up security, while some firms, such as Taiwanese companies, have halted production due to safety concerns. The protests have shattered perceptions of Vietnam's stability, highlighting the need for firms to monitor regional tensions.

site_title: Chemoil to be delisted on Tuesday
summary: Chemoil Energy, a marine oil supplier, will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange mainboard on Tuesday, following a voluntary delisting agreement with Glencore Xstrata. The company, originally founded in 1981, had received an offer to take it private at 40 US cents per share. After shareholder approval, Chemoil suspended trading of its shares in April and received in-principle approval from the SGX in March. This marks the end of Chemoil's 18-year listing on the SGX.

site_title: Green worthy
summary: Several companies in Singapore have won prestigious Green Mark awards for their office interiors, prioritizing sustainability and energy efficiency. Credit Suisse's One@Changi City office, for example, features energy-efficient LED lighting, motion sensors, and real-time monitoring of energy and water consumption. Novartis Singapore's office also incorporates green features such as centralized air-conditioning, motion sensors, and energy-efficient appliances. Olswang Asia LLP's office has a comprehensive eco-office system, including energy-efficient lighting and air-conditioning, as well as a flexible working policy to reduce fuel costs. Samsung Asia's office, meanwhile, uses energy-efficient equipment and materials, including LED lighting and Singapore Green Building Certified building materials. These companies demonstrate the importance of incorporating green features into office design to reduce environmental impact and improve employee satisfaction.

site_title: OCBC appoints new chief risk manager
summary: OCBC Bank has appointed Vincent Choo Nyen Fui as its executive vice-president and chief risk officer, effective August 1, 2014. Choo, a former Deutsche Bank executive, will succeed Gilbert Kohnke, who will remain with the bank until September 30, 2014. The appointment comes as banks intensify their focus on risk management due to increased volatility and uncertainty in the operating environment. CEO Samuel Tsien praised Kohnke's contributions and welcomed Choo's extensive experience and leadership qualities.

site_title: MatchMove wins Innotribe Challenge's London showcase
summary: MatchMove, a Singapore-based e-payment startup, won the London showcase of the 2014 Swift Innotribe Startup Challenge with its mobile virtual credit card, targeting 500 million "uncarded" smartphone users in emerging countries. The company's CEO, Shailesh Naik, said winning the challenge gave them credibility and confidence.
