MatchMove will compete in a final round in Boston in September alongside other winners from the New York and Singapore showcases.

site_title: Posh and down-to-earth
summary: Victoria Beckham, 40, emphasizes the importance of attention to detail in her fashion designs, prioritizing "exquisitely finished pieces that fit into any smart wardrobe." The former Spice Girl and fashion mogul stresses the value of being a "visual person" and paying attention to details such as the ceiling, floors, and visuals in her stores. Beckham, a mother of four, aims to create a welcoming brand experience through her standalone boutique on London's Dover Street, which will open in September. She balances her work and family life, acknowledging the guilt of leaving her children with others while working, but prioritizes her role as a mother and designer.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Vietnam protests against China's growing presence in the South China Sea serve as a warning to businesses of the potential risks of geopolitical tensions. In the business sector, Singapore's private home sales rebounded 55% in April, while Keppel Reit sold its Prudential Tower stake for $512 million. However, SingTel's Q4 profit fell short of estimates, and Olam's Q3 profit surged due to a fair value gain. The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank's launch may boost the use of China's yuan, while the eurozone crisis remains a topic of debate.

site_title: SIA to end Riyadh, Cairo flights from late September
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) will suspend flights to Cairo and Riyadh from late September due to weak demand. The airline will continue to serve Jeddah via Dubai, and customers with tickets beyond the suspension dates are eligible for refunds. This decision follows a similar route suspension in 2012 for Athens and Abu Dhabi. SIA is facing stiff competition from Gulf and regional carriers and plans to introduce a premium economy class on medium- to long-haul routes by mid-next year.

site_title: Exports rise 0.9% in April, defy forecast of 3.4% fall
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 0.9% in April, defying forecasts of a 3.4% decline. The uptrend is attributed to an increase in non-electronic exports, led by petrochemicals and printed matter. Economists expect this trend to continue as the global economy picks up, with forecasts of 7% growth for NODX in 2014. Exports to the US, China, and Malaysia contributed to the growth, while those to the European Union declined. Despite some optimism, others warn that NODX remains volatile and has yet to break out of its recent choppy profile.

site_title: Modi-led bloc trounces Congress party in biggest Indian polls win in 30 years
summary: Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the largest Indian election victory in 30 years, securing 335 seats in the 543-seat parliament. The BJP's landslide win has boosted India's financial markets, with shares reaching record highs and the rupee reaching its strongest level against the dollar in 11 months. Modi's government faces its first test with markets when it delivers a Budget by July, aiming to contain a fiscal deficit of 4.6% of GDP. Analysts expect the government to address issues such as high inflation, a current account deficit, and bad loans, which could impact economic growth and investor confidence.

site_title: The problem with heart-valve disease
summary: Heart-valve disease is less commonly recognized due to subtle symptoms that develop gradually. Patients may experience shortness of breath, palpitations, and chest pain without significant narrowing of heart arteries. Valve disease, such as mitral valve prolapse and aortic stenosis, can be treated with surgery or less invasive catheter-based procedures like Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR). Early detection and prevention measures can help avoid complications. Adults with suspected heart-valve disease should consider a heart assessment, including an echocardiogram or ECG, to detect abnormal heart sounds and diagnose valve disease.

site_title: Fillips and flops of the season
summary: Liverpool fans' 24-year wait for an English league championship has been extended to a quarter-century after Manchester City won the Premier League title. Manchester United, a 20-time winner, was eliminated early in the season, creating an exciting title race. Meanwhile, three teams - Fulham, Cardiff City, and Norwich City - have been relegated to the Championship, while Leicester City, Burnley, and one of Queens Park Rangers or Derby County will join them next season. Manchester City's victory marked a memorable season with many upsets and surprises.

site_title: Do-Not-Call registry: 3,700 complaints filed in less than five months
summary: The Do-Not-Call (DNC) registry in Singapore has received 3,700 valid complaints in under five months since its launch on January 2, averaging 27 complaints per day. The majority of complaints were against cooperative organizations that took prompt steps to correct their practices, while a few recalcitrant firms are under investigation. The PDPC may fine up to $10,000 per DNC registry-related offense. Despite a surge in registrations, the number of new registrations has tapered off in recent months.

site_title: Malaysians pump up the tempo
summary: Malaysia's arts community is set to take center stage in Singapore through the Causeway Exchange festival, marking the fifth year of the platform. Four Malaysian acts will perform in Singapore in June, including stand-up comedian Harith Iskandar, Wushu practitioner Lee Swee Seng, and theatre companies Cempaka Performing Arts Company and theatrethreesixty. The performances showcase a range of disciplines, from comedy to martial arts and theatre, and aim to strengthen cultural ties between Malaysia and Singapore. The festival runs from June 13-22 and features a diverse lineup of Malaysian artists.

site_title: Keppel Reit sells 92.8% stake in Prudential Tower for $512m
summary: Keppel Reit has agreed to sell its 92.8% stake in Prudential Tower for $512 million, a 4.5% premium over its last valuation, to a consortium of KOP, Lian Beng, KSH, and Centurion Global. The sale reflects a 3.5% net yield and is expected to be completed on September 26. The proceeds will be used to repay debt and provide financial flexibility for Keppel Reit.

site_title: Make social spending sustainable: President
summary: President Tony Tan Keng Yam has outlined the government's agenda for the rest of its term, emphasizing the need to strengthen social safety nets and ensure sustainable social spending. He promised to promote home ownership, improve healthcare access, and enhance social programs for vulnerable groups, including low-wage workers and the elderly. The government will also develop innovative solutions using new technologies to improve lives. Tan emphasized the importance of constructive politics and collective effort to build a "smart nation" for the future.

site_title: KrisEnergy posts Q1 net loss of US$18m
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-listed oil and gas firm, reported a Q1 net loss of US$18 million, compared to a net loss of US$500,000 a year ago. The loss was primarily due to a one-off recognition of adjustments and costs from full redemption of its senior guaranteed secured bonds. Revenue rose 5.5% to US$21.2 million, driven by a near-tripling in working interest production to 8,097 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Ebitdax was US$9.8 million, a 9.3% drop from Q1 2013.

site_title: HLA's Q1 profit declines 8.1% to $13.3m
summary: HLA's Q1 profit declined 8.1% to $13.3 million due to margins compression. Revenue rose 15.7% to $1.25 billion, driven by higher contributions from China Yuchai and BMU. Gross profit margin fell to 19.2% due to higher raw material costs and overheads. HLA expects to report a profit for the next quarter and this financial year, despite being exposed to currency fluctuation risk. Industry overcapacity and weaker consumer demand are expected to impact business units, particularly Xinfei.

site_title: Reprieve from total ban for Filipino officers on EU vessels
summary: The European Union has voted not to ban Filipino officers outright from EU-registered ships, giving the Philippines a six-month reprieve to address outstanding issues uncovered by European Maritime Safety Authority (EMSA) audits. The EU had previously threatened to derecognize Philippine STCW certificates due to compliance concerns, but has instead given the country more time to address deficiencies. Filipino officers will keep their jobs, and the EU will send technical experts to help ensure the Philippines complies with required standards. The Philippines must provide proof of resolution by end-July.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust DPU for Q4 dips to 1.21¢
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.21 cents for Q4 2014, down 7.5% from the previous year. Despite a 9.7% increase in gross revenue, net property income rose 19.3% to $22.03 million due to a one-off reversal of excess provisions for repair and maintenance. Improved performance of hotels in Australia, boosted by a A$30 million asset enhancement initiative, underpinned the growth. The trust's DPU for the full year was 5.52 cents.

site_title: Price cuts revive April private home sales; further discounts expected
summary: Singapore's private home sales rebounded 55% in April to 745 units, the highest level since November, after price cuts by developers. The surge in sales, driven by discounts averaging 10-15% below previous levels, suggests underlying demand remains present. Analysts expect further discounts and a growing number of new project launches to support sales in May, potentially exceeding 1,000 units for the first time this year.

site_title: SingTel's Q4 profit up 3.5% to $898m but misses estimates
summary: SingTel's Q4 profit rose 3.5% to $898m, but missed estimates due to a weak Australian dollar and decline in Optus contribution, resulting in a 7.9% drop in revenue. The company's underlying net profit fell 8.1%, while its share of associates' pre-tax profits rose 4.8%. In Singapore, mobile revenue increased 5.6% and postpaid subscribers grew 4.7%. The group declared a final ordinary dividend of 10 cents a share and expects stable revenue and Ebitda for the next year.

site_title: Straits Trading returns to the black in Q1
summary: Straits Trading Co reported a net profit of $5.9 million in Q1, reversing a year-ago loss of $0.3 million. Revenue declined 7.7% to $170.3 million, mainly due to lower earnings from its real estate, hospitality, and mining operations. Associate companies contributed $5.6 million to the group's profits, with earnings per share rising to 1.4 cents from a loss of 0.1 cent. The company attributes its improvement to its resources operations and earnings from its associates.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust's Q3 DPU beats own forecast
summary: Croesus Retail Trust posted a Q3 DPU of 1.76 cents, 8% higher than its forecast, driven by 12.3% higher net property income of 933.7 million yen. Revenue was 3.7% higher than forecast due to strong tenant sales at Mallage Shobu in Saitama Prefecture. The Reit's CEO stated that the company is on track to meet its full-year forecast, despite increased competition for acquiring real estate assets in Japan.

site_title: China firms endure longer wait for payments
summary: China's economy is experiencing a slowdown, causing companies to wait longer for payments, leading to record amounts of receivables on corporate balance sheets. At Longyuan Construction Group, receivables increased 4.9% to 4.1 billion yuan, with average collection times extending to 95.2 days. The situation is repeated across the economy, with the median collection time for billings rising to 90.42 days, the first time in a decade. Policymakers are moving to tighten credit, but the faltering real estate market and tight credit have raised concerns about a sharper-than-anticipated slowdown.

site_title: Nam Cheong's Q1 profit doubles to RM71.1m
summary: Nam Cheong, a Malaysia-based offshore marine company, reported a 74% increase in revenue to RM407.3 million in Q1 2014, driven by higher vessel deliveries. The company's net profit more than doubled to RM71.1 million. Shipbuilding revenue rose 60% to RM229.3 million, with platform supply vessel sales contributing significantly. The order book stood at RM1.4 billion, with deliveries expected until 2015. CEO Leong Seng Keat attributed the strong demand to increased oil investments and supply constraints in certain segments.

site_title: Mining rich vein of life experiences
summary: Local theatre actress Oon Shu An staged a confessional one-woman show, #UnicornMoment, as part of the Esplanade's Studio season, marking her stage-writing debut. The play, which started on YouTube months prior, explored issues such as education, self-esteem, and relationships through skits and multimedia projections. Despite some shortcomings, Oon's natural charisma and engaging personality held the audience's attention, making for a commendable and honest dose of entertainment. Her debut showcases her ability to effectively harvest life experiences for audiences.

site_title: Top livewire comedian is serious about his art
summary: Jeff Dunham, a 52-year-old comedian and ventriloquist, is set to perform in Singapore for the first time, bringing his popular puppets Walter, Bubba J, and Achmed the Dead Terrorist to the stage. Dunham takes his craft seriously, prioritizing his voice and promoting ventriloquism as a dying art form. He aims to revitalize the art, making it hip and fun again, and has crowned himself the top-grossing international 'live' comedy act.

site_title: Singapore makes presence felt in George Town fest
summary: Singapore artists are participating in the four-year-old George Town Festival with a multi-disciplinary event called Sin-Pen Colony. The festival will feature a site-specific play, a culinary experience, and a playwriting immersion workshop. The event aims to celebrate the shared history and cultural ties between Penang and Singapore. The Sin-Pen Colony will run from August 23 to 31, showcasing works by Singapore artists in Penang, with a focus on theatre, food, and music. The event is curated by actor and artist Tan Kheng Hua.

site_title: Biennale's art trove on show
summary: The 27th Biennale des Antiquaires in Paris will showcase a trove of art, antiques, and jewelry from September, with high-end dealers spending up to $1 million on booths. The event aims to up its game in terms of quality, buffet food, and decorations, with a focus on competing with larger international fairs. Notable exhibitors include Hong Kong-based jeweler Wallace Chan, who will showcase his new pieces, and French designer Jacques Grange, who will create an interpretation of the Chateau de Versailles for the event. The fair attracts over 90,000 collectors annually and will also feature a similar Biennale in China.

site_title: Off-key rendering of race-against-time thriller
summary: Grand Piano, a thriller film, follows pianist Tom Selznick (Elijah Wood) as he prepares for a high-stakes concert. Haunted by stage fright and a sniper's deadly threat, Selznick must perform flawlessly to avoid death. Director Eugenio Mira uses music to create tension, as the score becomes a source of urgency. The film delivers over-the-top antics but ultimately falls short in its finale. With Elijah Wood's gifted fingers moving quickly, the movie moves along excitingly but comes undone under the weight of its promises, resulting in a mediocre rating of B-.

site_title: 2Cellos rock the classical groove
summary: Croatian cello duo 2Cellos, Luka Sulic and Stjepan Hauser, have achieved immense success with their unique blend of classical and rock music. Their YouTube cover of Michael Jackson's Smooth Criminal led to a record deal and collaborations with Sir Elton John and the Red Hot Chili Peppers. The duo has sold out major venues, performed at major events, and released two albums, including a No. 1 spot on the US Billboard Top Classical Albums chart. They are set to play their first headlining show in Singapore and have expressed a desire to collaborate with other rock bands and artists in the future.

site_title: HanKore in the red; Memstar profit dives; Moya profit up
summary: Three water companies reported earnings for the three months ended March 31. HanKore Environment Technology Group posted a net loss of 111.9 million yuan, despite a 56.3% revenue increase. Memstar Technology's third-quarter net profit fell 93.1% to 0.65 million yuan. In contrast, Singapore-based Moya Holdings Asia reported a 15% net profit rise to $0.5 million, despite a 27% revenue slump. The companies' earnings were affected by non-cash losses and expenses, including fair-value losses and one-off charges.

site_title: Paean to grand old Rome
summary: The Great Beauty, a film by Paolo Sorrentino, is a love letter to Rome, showcasing its various sides and exploring the themes of life, death, and the search for meaning. The movie follows Jep Gambardella, a 65-year-old magazine journalist, as he navigates the city's decadent party scene and confronts his own mortality. Through Jep's journey, Sorrentino reveals the city's secrets and the human experience, concluding that the journey itself is more important than the destination. The film is a poignant and perceptive exploration of the human condition.

site_title: SIA Indian venture to fly overseas if allowed
summary: Singapore Airlines' Indian venture, Tata-SIA Airlines, plans to fly overseas if the next Indian government allows carriers under five years old to operate internationally. The airline aims to tap into India's growing business travel market, which is projected to double by 2015. Tata-SIA plans to offer business and economy class seats on local flights and potentially fly leased Airbus planes on nine routes locally in the first year. The decision to shed restrictions will be left to the next administration, which will take office after India's elections.

site_title: Meeting of minds of master chefs
summary: Three Asia-based chefs, Emmanuel Stroobant, Lanshu Chen, and Hideaki Matsuo, will collaborate on a six-course dinner featuring champagne and whisky pairings in Singapore from May 22-23. This is part of the Relais & Chateaux Diner des Grands Chefs Singapour, a fine dining event celebrating the association's 60th anniversary. The dinner series, which has been held annually since 2011, brings together Grand Chefs from around the world to showcase their culinary styles.

site_title: Fatca compliance: Banks need to be vigilant
summary: The US Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (Fatca) is cracking down on tax evasion by requiring foreign banks to report on assets of US clients. Over 50 countries, including major secrecy havens like Switzerland, have signed up to comply. Despite initial opposition, the tide may be irreversible, with the OECD issuing a global standard for automatic tax information exchange. Financial institutions, including Singapore, are expected to be vigilant in conducting reviews of clients' accounts to identify potential red flags. The law imposes a 30% withholding tax on non-compliant transactions.

site_title: Celebrating similarities across the Straits
summary: George Town Festival in Penang is set to feature a site-specific play, "2 Houses," about old rich Penang Chinese pioneers and their contributions to the city's growth. The play, written and directed by Lim Yu Beng, explores the lives of 12 people linked to a sworn brotherhood of migrants who arrived in Penang from China in the 1800s. The story takes place in an early 20th-century mansion and delves into the characters' choices that define themselves and Malaya after World War II. The play is a result of Tan Kheng Hua's collaboration with Lim, who researched the rich, English-speaking, Chinese of the colonial era. The play will be performed from August 28-31.

site_title: Back to the roots with vintage Bordeaux
summary: A wine critic revisits Bordeaux's First Growth wines from 2001 and 2003, finding them delightful and full of character. La Mission Haut Brion 2001, Chateau Latour 2003, and Chateau Lafite Rothschild 2003 were all praised for their elegance and complexity, with the Lafite displaying underlying strength and the Latour a youthful maturity. The critic notes that these wines, although already mature, have the potential to last for 10-20 years. The article concludes that the 2003s are on the threshold of maturity and a comparative tasting would be fascinating, but is overshadowed by the news of the passing of Domaine Weinbach's winemaker, Laurence Faller.

site_title: Malaysia Air Q1 loss widens to RM443m
summary: Malaysia Airlines reported a widened loss of RM443 million (S$172 million) in the first quarter, primarily due to a 60% decline in sales in China after the disappearance of MH370. The airline attributed this decline to high cancellation rates and reduced long-haul bookings. The loss is the fifth consecutive quarter for MAS, with revenue only increasing by 4% and yields dropping by 9%. The airline plans to re-examine its business model to ensure sustainability, amid suggestions of privatization or spin-offs.

site_title: UOL bulk leases: a good or bad strategy?
summary: UOL Group's recent bulk leasing deal with the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board has raised questions about whether leasing a large chunk of office space on a long lease to one tenant or dividing it among smaller tenants on shorter leases yields higher rental income. The deal, which involves nearly 210,000 sq ft at Novena Square, appears to maximize revenues at first glance, but long-term average monthly rents are expected to be in the low $7 psf range. The strategy may be driven by the desire to lock in a strong tenant covenant, minimize vacancy, and extract higher net lettable area, despite potential drawbacks such as lower short-term rental income.

site_title: High jinks in high office
summary: A satirical comedy play, "Yes, Prime Minister," based on the award-winning BBC TV series, premiered in Singapore, exploring the dilemma of a Prime Minister deciding whether to fulfill a request from a rich foreigner in exchange for a billion-dollar contract. The play, set in a mock office, revolves around the back-and-forth deliberations between the Prime Minister and his adviser, highlighting the dynamics of power and control in politics. The show, which runs through May 18, features a mix of humor and commentary on democracy and the role of civil servants.

site_title: Disposal gain boosts Swiber's Q1 bottomline
summary: Swiber Holdings' first-quarter net profit more than doubled to US$48 million due to a gain from disposal of its subsidiaries. Revenue fell 35.6% to US$199.5 million, primarily due to a significant portion of ongoing projects being recognized in 2013. The offshore construction and support services provider attributed the decline to recently awarded projects not having commenced.

site_title: Cars a big drag as March retail sales fall 3.9%
summary: Retail sales in Singapore fell 3.9% year-on-year in March, a decline for the second consecutive month. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales contracted 0.4%. The decline was steeper than forecast, with OCBC Bank predicting a -1.9% year-on-year contraction. However, some categories such as medical goods, department stores, and supermarkets experienced growth, with sales increasing 4.7%, 2.8%, and 1.6% respectively.

site_title: Pay hike likely for S'pore finance and accounting execs
summary: Finance and accounting executives in Singapore can expect a pay rise this year, with 55% of companies increasing salaries, according to a Robert Half survey of 2,431 chief financial officers in 16 countries. The trend is driven by competition for top talent and companies' growth prospects. In Singapore, large firms with over 1,000 staff have raised pay for finance and accounting staff at a rate of 65%, compared to 54% at smaller firms and 51% at medium-sized firms. Finance and accounting staff also have a good chance of getting a bigger bonus this year, with 37% of companies increasing bonuses.

site_title: Vallianz secures US$82m contract in Latin America
summary: Vallianz Holdings secured a US$82 million charter and ship management contract in Latin America through a Letter of Award. The contract, awarded to an offshore construction company, includes the deployment of various vessels and a full suite of offshore marine support services. This award augments Vallianz's order book to US$524 million and marks a promising start for the company in the Latin American market.

site_title: Sewol capt, 3 crew charged with homicide
summary: The captain and three senior crew members of the South Korean ferry Sewol, which capsized in April, killing over 280 passengers, including many school children, have been indicted for homicide. Prosecutors also charged 11 surviving crew members with negligence. The investigation found that the ferry was severely compromised after a remodeling, was overloaded, and had insufficient water in its ballast tanks. The crew's escape before passengers led to "grave casualties." The captain and others are accused of gross negligence and failing to aid and relieve passengers, leading to deaths.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management has appointed Khor Un-Hun as its new CEO, replacing Thomas Pang Thieng Hwi. Yongnam Holdings reported a $1.9 million Q1 loss due to a 12.4% drop in revenue. Logistics Holdings won a $72 million HDB contract for building four blocks of flats. Meanwhile, companies such as Tesla, FedEx, and Popiah are making headlines with robotaxi expansions, partnerships, and stock gains.

site_title: Jet search on hold after trouble with mini-sub
summary: The search for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 has been put on hold due to technical issues with a US Navy mini-submarine, the Bluefin-21. The submersible, which was used to search for the missing plane in the Indian Ocean, lasted only two hours in the water before it had to be raised. Spare parts, including transponders, need to be sent from Britain to repair the sub and enable it to continue the search. The search operation is now awaiting the arrival of the spare parts, which are expected to arrive in Western Australia on Sunday.

site_title: Art Basel HK's mega-draw
summary: Art Basel Hong Kong, the region's most prestigious art fair, has seen a massive draw, with over US$1 billion worth of valuable art going on sale. Singapore artist Lee Wen's works, which were sold to eager buyers, validated his determination to gain recognition after years of struggling to make a name for himself. The fair's discerning international audience, known for their speed and purchasing power, has drawn in major galleries and artists, including those from China, Indonesia, and Thailand. Notable sales included a Damien Hirst blade painting for £800,000 and a Ronald Ventura work for S$125,000.

site_title: Famous art collectors demystified
summary: Independent art journalist Patricia Chen has released a documentary on legendary art collector Uli Sigg, premiering at the Hong Kong Arts Centre. The film captures Sigg's collection of Chinese art, featuring works by prominent artists such as Ai Weiwei and Zhang Xiaogang. Chen, who also wrote a book on Sigg, has tracked the Asian art scene for years and aims to share the insights of famous collectors through various platforms. A second film project about Indonesian collector Oei Hong Djien is also in the pipeline.

site_title: Modern-day musketeers hold court
summary: Aymeri de Montesquiou d'Artagnan, a descendant of the hero of The Three Musketeers, leads the Compagnie des Mousquetaires d'Armagnac, a modern-day organization that upholds the values of musketeers from the 17th century. Founded in 1951, the company has around 4000 members worldwide, including ambassadors, celebrities, and individuals from various professions. The organization promotes camaraderie, culinary art, and hospitality, with a growing number of people interested in joining the ranks.

site_title: China's property market finally seems to be stalling
summary: China's property market has stalled, with housing starts plummeting 25% in April from a year ago, according to the Chinese government. Prices are falling for both new and old apartments, and developers are pulling back, furloughing workers and delaying new projects. This could have broader consequences for the country's economy and politics, with experts warning of potential protests and bank exposure to non-performing loans. While some restrictions on the market are being rescinded, economists believe the market's decline is irreversible, with prices expected to continue falling.

site_title: Around Town
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several exhibitions are on display in Singapore, including "Spurious Landscapes" by Sherman Ong at Art Plural Gallery, "Solo Oil Painting Exhibition" by Soon Hock Chay at Volvo Art Loft, and "Between Sense and Sensibility" at TAKSU Singapore. Additionally, Australian singer-songwriter Pete Murray will perform live at Wave House Sentosa on May 17. The "Makan Matters" exhibition, showcasing the future of Singapore's food culture, runs at Artistry until May 25.

site_title: Japan's Q1 growth surpasses expectations with 5.9% surge
summary: Japan's economy experienced a 5.9% surge in Q1 growth, surpassing expectations, driven by strong consumer spending and corporate capital investment. Personal consumption rose 2.1% and corporate capital spending jumped by 5% ahead of a national sales tax hike. However, economists caution that growth may slow in the second quarter due to sales and output falling back. The Bank of Japan is expected to take further easing action if growth suffers, with forecasts predicting domestic demand to remain robust over the next two years.

site_title: Haw Par reports 59% jump in Q1 earnings
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 59% increase in Q1 earnings to $12.2 million, driven by higher operating income and gains from dilution of an associated company. Revenue rose 16% to $38.4 million. The healthcare business led the way, with a 63% higher profit and 28% sales increase, while the leisure division saw a 57% decline in profit due to intense competition. The company expects the leisure division to continue facing challenges.

site_title: Sim Lian, Lee Kim Tah report lower profits
summary: Sim Lian Group posted a 48% decline in net profit to $17.1 million in its third quarter, due to lower contributions from its property development division. Revenue dropped 50.7% to $96.5 million, primarily caused by the completion of the Waterview project. The company expects the private residential property market to become increasingly challenging and will focus on building a stable base of recurring income. Net profit for the first nine months fell 6% to $110.6 million.

site_title: ECS profit falls 12% in Q1 to $7.2m
summary: ECS Holdings, an ICT products and services provider, reported a 12% decline in Q1 net profit to $7.2 million, down from $8.3 million last year. Revenue fell 14.6% to $930.9 million, with declines in North Asia and South-east Asia. However, the enterprise systems segment saw a 36.6% increase in revenue to $351.6 million. ECS shares traded at 63 cents on Monday.

site_title: SIA's passenger load factor declines to 76.7% in April
summary: SINGAPORE AIRLINES' passenger load factor declined to 76.7% in April, down 1.1 percentage points from the previous month, due to a 0.4% increase in passenger carriage and a 1.9% expansion in capacity. The carrier faces intense competition and warned that the operating environment will remain challenging. Cargo traffic also declined, with load factor dropping to 61.7% due to weaker traffic and capacity growth.

site_title: Olam's Q3 profit more than doubles on fair value gain
summary: Olam International's Q3 profit more than doubled to $396.1 million, driven by a $271 million gain from the revaluation of its PureCircle Ltd holding. Revenue rose 2.5% to $4.8 billion, while core net profit increased due to a decrease in fair value losses. Sales volume declined 2.4% to 11.4 million tonnes for the nine-month period. CEO Sunny Verghese attributed the focus on profitable growth over volume, with the company aiming to be FCFF-positive by the end of the financial year.

site_title: Grosvenor to spend 50b yen to buy, refurbish Tokyo apartments
summary: Grosvenor Ltd, a real estate firm owned by the Duke of Westminster, plans to spend up to 50 billion yen (S$614 million) to buy and refurbish luxury apartments in Tokyo. The company sees increasing demand for top-end, refurbished apartments from Asian and domestic high-net-worth individuals, driven by changing tastes among Japanese homebuyers. This investment aims to capitalize on the growing market for renovated residential apartments in Japan, which is estimated to be around 6.5 trillion yen.

site_title: Boeing gets US$3.8b order from China airline
summary: Boeing has received a US$3.8 billion order from China's 9 Air subsidiary, a discount carrier set up by Juneyao Airlines. The order consists of 50 single-aisle 737 jets, valued at US$3.8 billion to US$5.5 billion, from Boeing's 737 Next Generation and Max families. This deal marks a boost for Boeing in a market where Airbus is predicted to surpass the US as the world's largest aircraft manufacturer by 2032. China's government has eased controls on low-cost travel, encouraging budget carriers like 9 Air.

site_title: Airbus Q1 profit beats estimates but challenges remain
summary: Airbus reported a higher-than-expected net profit of 439 million euros in the first quarter, driven by lower production costs and favourable exchange rates. The company's passenger-jet business is experiencing growth, but new commercial jet orders fell sharply in the first quarter. Airbus expects new orders to pick up over the year and maintained earlier forecasts for revenue and orders. The A350-XWB, Airbus's latest wide-body plane, is progressing toward certification, but may face last-minute hiccups that could affect the timetable and result in delays and charges.

site_title: Sex and loneliness in Hong Kong
summary: An art exhibition in Hong Kong, "Ten Million Rooms of Yearning: Sex in Hong Kong," explores various aspects of sex and desire through non-explicit artworks, including videos and photography. The exhibition, at five venues, features artists from Hong Kong, Israel, and Japan, examining the complexities of sex and desire in the city's unique cultural context. Despite its provocative subject matter, the exhibition has sparked a healthy conversation about sex and desire in Hong Kong, with many attendees, including teenagers, finding the artworks thought-provoking and relatable.

site_title: CDL net profit down 13.1%
summary: CDL reported a 13.1% drop in net profit to $119.7 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2014, due to gains from disposal of strata units in previous years. Despite this, the group's property development segment showed a 4% increase in pre-tax profits, driven by joint-venture projects and higher contributions from Bartley Residences. CDL also acquired five prime freehold properties in the UK for £152 million.

site_title: Offer price for HPL raised to $4 a share
summary: A consortium led by tycoon Ong Beng Seng has raised its offer price for Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL) shares to $4 per share from $3.50. The move follows married trades in shares amounting to 3.3% of HPL, driving up the stock 7.3% to $3.84 before a trading halt was imposed. The consortium, which already owns 41.91% of HPL, plans to re-develop the company's prime land assets, including Orchard Road properties. The offer period remains unchanged until June 2.

site_title: Godzilla reboot a CGI colossus
summary: The 2014 film "Godzilla" is a big-budget Hollywood reboot of the iconic monster, directed by Gareth Edwards and written by Max Borenstein. The movie follows two parallel timelines, one in Japan and another in the Philippines, as a giant creature emerges from the Pacific Ocean, wreaking havoc on major cities. The film stays true to the spirit of its Japanese origins while forging a 21st-century identity. The impressive special effects and advancements in filmmaking technology make for an entertaining and convincing experience, with Godzilla emerging as the star of the show.

site_title: Indonesia's Democrats may sit out next Parliament
summary: Indonesia's incumbent President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono's Democratic Party may choose to sit out the next Parliament, aiming to regroup before the 2019 elections. The party faces a daunting task in forming a coalition, and opposition parties, including Joko Widodo's Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDI-P), are negotiating with smaller parties for crucial support. Analysts predict a bruising election battle, with Widodo's popularity and Prabowo's assertive style expected to play a significant role.

site_title: Noble's Q1 net more than trebles to US$152.3m
summary: Noble Group's net profit more than tripled to US$152.3 million in Q1 2014, driven by improved margins in its energy and minerals division and lower losses in its agriculture business. Operating income from supply chains jumped 30% to US$497.4 million, with the energy division posting record operating profit income of US$437 million. The firm's transformational deal to sell a 51% stake in its agriculture business to Cofco is expected to be completed by early in the fourth quarter, offering an opportunity for Noble's shareholders to participate in the next phase of its agricultural platform development.

site_title: The ups and downs of being a gigolo
summary: A man, Fioravante, becomes a gigolo with the help of his friend Murray, played by Woody Allen, after Murray's dermatologist suggests a threesome. Fioravante's newfound profession attracts clients, including Sharon Stone's character, but also the attention of a law enforcement officer, Liev Schreiber. The film's tone shifts in the second act, focusing on Fioravante's romance with Vanessa Paradis's character, leading to a disjointed conclusion. Despite this, Fioravante's heart is in the right place, and the film's charm is undeniable, making it worth watching for Woody Allen fans.

site_title: Jaya earnings more than treble in Q3
summary: Jaya Holdings reported a net profit of US$14.1 million in Q3, more than treble the US$4 million from the same period last year. Revenue increased 81% to US$105.7 million, driven by the sale of a vessel and improved charter utilisation. The company's cash and cash equivalents rose to US$209.7 million, maintaining a net cash position. Earnings per share increased to 1.83 US cents, up from 0.52 US cents.

site_title: NOL sinks into US$98m Q1 loss; revenue down 4%
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) reported a Q1 net loss of US$98 million, down from a US$76 million profit last year, due to low freight rates and oversupply of shipping capacity. Revenue fell 4% to US$2.28 billion. However, the company's core Ebit improved 14% and its loss narrowed to US$65 million. APL, NOL's container shipping business, saw its core Ebit boosted by 10% and its loss narrowed to US$83 million. The company aims to improve its financial performance in 2014 through cost discipline and operational efficiency.

site_title: Golden Agri Q1 profit falls 8% to US$103.9m
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, the world's second largest palm oil producer, reported a 8% decline in Q1 profit to US$103.9 million due to higher raw materials costs. Despite this, revenue grew 34% to US$1.91 billion, driven by higher sales volume in the palm and laurics segment and higher CPO market prices. The company's downstream and upstream businesses remained robust.

site_title: InterContinental plans to return to Rio in time for Olympics
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group plans to reopen a location in Rio de Janeiro before the 2016 Olympics, with two Holiday Inn properties and possibly more near the city's beaches. The move comes after the company lost its only Rio location to Louvre Hotels Group in 2011. The new hotels will be built in a downtown port area with a new road network and light-rail system, and will cater to the city's growing demand for quality accommodations, with occupancy expected to surpass 90% during the World Cup.

site_title: Toronto condo market healthy: builders
summary: Toronto's condominium market remains healthy, according to builders, who attribute the demand to domestic investors. Despite speculation of a bubble, the market has seen a 10.1% increase in home prices to a record C$577,898. Local investors, particularly "mom and pop" investors, are driving the market, with foreign investors' interest declining over the past five to six years. Experts predict a slowdown in construction over the next five years, with rents rising and eventually pricing out some buyers.

site_title: Qantas to lay off pilots in bid to stem losses
summary: Qantas, Australia's national carrier, plans to lay off up to 100 pilots, or about 20% of its 550 pilots, as part of a cost-cutting measure to stem massive losses. The airline aims to save A$2 billion over the next three years by retiring its ageing 747 and 767 fleets. The redundancies will be voluntary, with the airline expecting to stagger the exits with network and fleet reductions. The Australian and International Pilots Association has expressed regret but will work with the company to minimize the impact on individual pilots.

site_title: Factories torched in anti-China riot in Vietnam
summary: Violent anti-China protests in Vietnam's Binh Duong province have resulted in the torching of factories, including two Sembcorp-run Vietnam Singapore Industrial Parks. The unrest, sparked by China's deployment of an oil rig in disputed waters, has left over 500 people in custody. Despite the turmoil, businessmen appear largely unfazed, with some viewing the incident as a one-off isolated incident. Analysts, however, warn that undertones of antagonism towards China could be a recurring theme, posing a risk to foreign investors and potential investments in the country.

site_title: Judge blocks NY's inquiry into Airbnb
summary: A New York judge has blocked the state's investigation into Airbnb, ruling that a subpoena seeking information about hosts was too broad. Acting Supreme Court Justice Gerald Connolly voided the subpoena, stating that it sought materials irrelevant to the inquiry. The investigation aimed to determine if Airbnb hosts were complying with state and local tax registration and collection requirements. Airbnb has said it wants to work with state officials to ease restrictive laws and collect occupancy taxes. A new subpoena is expected to be issued, with the attorney-general's office committing to enforcing laws protecting building residents and tourists.

site_title: Pacific Radiance posts Q1 profit of US$17.8m
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore and marine services provider, reported a Q1 net profit of US$17.8 million, more than doubling the previous year's US$8.5 million. Revenue rose 33% to US$42 million, driven by growth in its offshore support services and subsea businesses. The company's outlook for the oil and gas industry remains positive, and its stock price closed half a cent higher at $1.075.

site_title: M'sia PM calls for changes to prevent another MH370
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak calls for international aviation regulators to implement real-time tracking of airliners to prevent another MH370 disappearance. He admits missteps in the early days of the crisis, including a chaotic public message and slow search and rescue operations. Najib proposes changes to prevent aircraft from disappearing, including tracking, improved communications systems, and extending battery life of flight data recorders and cockpit voice recorders. An ICAO meeting is expected to lead to recommendations within five months to address these concerns.

site_title: Banyan Tree Q1 profit down 72% on lower other income
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings reported a 72% decline in net profit for Q1 2014 to $4 million, down from $14.2 million last year, due to lower other income and revenue from hotel investments and fee-based segments. Revenue fell 3% to $93.9 million. The company is cautious about its operations in Thailand but plans to open five new resorts in the next 12 months.

site_title: 2 more projects launched on Jurong Island
summary: Singapore has launched two new projects on Jurong Island to boost its global competitiveness. The Safety & Risk Management Centre (SRMC) will jointly manage system-level risks for the petrochemicals industry, while a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) terminal will be developed to bring in an alternative feedstock. These projects, under the JI 2.0 initiative, aim to enhance the island's attractiveness for investors, with Infineum's recent US$150 million plant inauguration being the largest single global investment by the ExxonMobil/Shell joint venture to date.

site_title: Raffles Education posts profit of $23.8m in Q3
summary: Raffles Education Corporation posted a net profit of $23.84 million in its fiscal third quarter, driven by a $46.1 million gain from divesting investment properties. Revenue increased slightly to $31.7 million, and earnings per share rose to 2.32 cents. The company also announced the sale of its 50% stake in Value Vantage Hangzhou for $170.9 million. Despite a 2% dip in revenue for the first nine months, the group reported a net profit of $27.1 million, citing stabilizing PRC college revenue and positive outcomes from transformational strategies.

site_title: Yanlord, Ying Li Q1 profits surge
summary: Yanlord Land Group and Ying Li International Real Estate reported significant earnings growth in the first quarter of 2014. Ying Li's net profit surged 4.3 times to 33.7 million yuan, while its revenue jumped 170.2% to 279.7 million yuan. Yanlord's net profit increased almost 4 times to 266 million yuan, and its revenue rose 5% to 1.763 billion yuan. Both companies' shares ended unchanged or higher, with Ying Li's shares closing at 26.5 cents and Yanlord's shares rising one cent to $1.12.

site_title: China plays into Japan's hands with oil rig move
summary: China's decision to station a massive deepwater oil drilling rig near a disputed island in the South China Sea has played into Japan's hands, allowing Japan to point to China's aggressive actions and claim the country is attempting to use force to claim territory. The move coincided with the Asean leaders' summit in Myanmar, where leaders protested at China's action. China's timing has given Japan an opportunity to reframe the narrative and portray China as the aggressor, potentially escalating tensions in the region.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Banks in Singapore are monitoring their exposure to China amid concerns over a slowdown and borrower creditworthiness. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. China has unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions. US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fell, and Wall Street opened mixed as investors assessed a new tariff salvo by President Trump. The region is watching developments closely as US tariffs loom, with China urging South-east Asia to back openness.

site_title: Banks on guard over China exposure
summary: Banks in Singapore are scrutinizing their exposure to China, particularly due to concerns over an economic slowdown and the creditworthiness of Chinese corporate borrowers. While some banks claim to have no direct exposure to shadow banking in China, others acknowledge the risk and are taking measures to manage it. Banks are verifying trade documents, checking commodity prices, and being selective of clients to mitigate the risk. Despite this, there is debate over the extent of responsibility taken by banks, with some arguing that they are not directly responsible for the risks associated with Chinese borrowers.

site_title: Indian market optimism soars following exit poll projections
summary: Indian investors are optimistic following exit poll projections of a decisive Narendra Modi win, driving shares to fresh record highs and boosting the rupee to a 10-month peak. The NSE index jumped 2.3% to 7,172.35 points, and shares have soared by nearly a fifth since Modi became the BJP's candidate. However, some investors warn that investors will need to see proof of corporate earnings recovery before pushing shares up further, and the RBI's monetary policy review on June 3 will also be closely watched.

site_title: Chinese long-tenor trade loans raise eyebrows
summary: Chinese long-tenor trade loans, known as 360-day letters of credit (LCs), have raised concerns over potential involvement in the shadow banking system. Banks in Singapore, including DBS and OCBC, have been cautious in their due-diligence process and selectively take on these loans, which can extend beyond six months. The loans are used by Chinese importers to finance commodity purchases, with the money often being invested in wealth management products. Experts warn of the risk of manipulation and speculation in trade financing, particularly with China's growing economic influence.

site_title: Over 80% of Kallang Wave's space taken
summary: Kallang Wave, a new retail mall in Singapore's Sports Hub, has named anchor tenants including FairPrice Xtra, Uniqlo, H&M, and Harvey Norman. Over 80% of the 41,000-sq-m mall is occupied, with a sports-themed layout featuring a 1,000 sq m climbing wall and sports equipment. The mall will offer a diverse experience, encouraging people to make sports part of their daily lives, with tenants launching new business lines, including a running-centric concept store and podiatric consultation services.

site_title: Brazil's shopping centre glut sparks concerns in bond market
summary: Brazil's shopping center glut is causing concerns in the bond market. General Shopping, the owner of 18 malls, had its rating cut by Moody's Investors Service due to concerns about a building boom in shopping centers harming creditors as consumers reduce spending. The company's rating was reduced to B1, and its perpetual bonds now have a 3% loss this year, compared to a 3% gain for junk-rated emerging-market debt. The downgrade reflects the slowdown in Brazil's economy and the impact on demand for retail space.

site_title: Big data: Helping businesses with indirect tax obligations
summary: Companies must leverage the latest technology to manage indirect tax obligations as tax authorities increasingly use data analytics to scrutinize tax returns. A recent EY report found that 69 countries use data extracted from taxpayers' systems to carry out VAT/GST audits, with this number expected to increase. Taxpayers must keep pace with this trend by utilizing available technology to reduce risk and improve operational efficiency, as traditional views of indirect tax technology as an overhead cost are shifting.

site_title: 17 victims, 206 survivors of shipwreck arrive in Sicily
summary: Italy has received 17 victims and 206 survivors of a migrant boat shipwreck, with many coming from Eritrea, Nigeria, and Syria. Italy threatens to send asylum-seekers to other European countries if it doesn't receive more assistance. The Italian government is urging the EU to intervene in Libya to stop migrants from leaving and to improve border coordination. The UNHCR estimates 170 people have died at sea this year trying to reach Europe, and the Italian navy reported a large-scale operation to rescue migrants and deter traffickers.

site_title: Canary Wharf leads sharp rise in London home prices
summary: London's home prices around Canary Wharf surged 16.2% in the year to April, the fastest pace in the city, driven by increased hiring by banks and demand for housing in financial districts. The City of London financial district and its fringes saw a 15.7% increase in home prices. Experts attribute the growth to the improving UK economy and rising job vacancies in the financial services industry, which is expected to continue with a 67% rise in job vacancies in April.

site_title: Better revenue, margins boost ThaiBev Q1
summary: ThaiBev, a food and beverage group, posted a 73% leap in its first-quarter net profit to 5.97 billion baht (S$230 million) due to higher revenue and stronger margins. Revenue rose 5% to 41 billion baht, driven by an increase in spirits sales, with gross profit margins rising 1.5 percentage points to 33.5%. The company's spirits division saw a 10.4% increase in revenue, while the beer division recorded a 50.2% rise in gross profit despite a 11.7% decline in volume sold.

site_title: No quick fix to revive India's economy: experts
summary: India's new government, led by Narendra Modi, faces a challenging task to revive the economy, experts warn. Despite high hopes for a business-friendly government, growth recovery is expected to be modest and protracted, with a potential 3-4 year gestation period for investment to kick-start. Experts point to stalled projects due to land acquisition issues, corporate leverage, and high non-performing assets in the banking system, limiting scope for monetary easing and policy action. A "marathon, not a sprint" approach to restoring growth is expected, with a temporary rally possible but a sustained recovery challenging and time-consuming.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Businesses in Singapore are more pessimistic about their prospects, despite a global economic recovery. Experts say reviving India's economy won't be quick, while China's economic data shows weakness. TPV Tech reported a significant loss, and POSH shares have stagnated since its listing. Albedo's Iskandar deal faces uncertainty, and SICCI is set to use a turnaround strategy. The International Islamic Financial Market plans to establish global standards for sukuk structuring.

site_title: Khazanah, TPG buy into Manila developer
summary: Malaysia's state investor Khazanah Nasional and global private investment firm TPG have agreed to buy US$132 million worth of shares in 8990 Holdings Inc, a Philippine mass housing developer. The two investors will subscribe to about two-thirds of the developer's follow-on equity offering, worth 9 billion pesos (S$257.6 million). The shares represent around 20% of the developer's equity, equivalent to 5.8 billion pesos. The deal is part of Khazanah and TPG's investment in the Philippine real estate market.

site_title: Cargo boxes jam Manila docks amid truck ban
summary: A truck ban in Manila, implemented by Mayor Joseph Estrada in February, has resulted in cargo containers piling up on the city's docks, causing significant delays and economic losses. The ban, intended to ease traffic congestion, has led to a 50% increase in cargo waiting times, with some containers lingering for over 10 days. This has resulted in estimated annual losses of 61 billion pesos to 320 billion pesos, equivalent to 2.9% of the country's GDP, according to Citigroup estimates. The ban has also led to a decline in daily truck trips to the port, with some truckers expressing concerns that the measure is damaging the economy.

site_title: MAS restructuring slated for May 28: report
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) is set to undergo a major restructuring on May 28, canceling some contracts and reducing its workforce by over 10%. The airline will close several departments, except for in-flight services, and sign new agreements at competitive rates. This move aims to address profit-squeezing contracts and improve the company's financial situation.

site_title: CWT posts Q1 net of $35m
summary: CWT Ltd posted a Q1 net profit of $35 million, driven by a 30% increase in revenue from its commodity marketing business. Revenue tripled to $4.5 billion, with commodity marketing accounting for 93% of total revenue. The company's CEO stated that the results show CWT is executing well in a challenging macro-economic environment. CWT also announced the acquisition of packing services and a warehouse project, and its subsidiary Straits Financial obtained a Capital Market Service Licence to conduct regulated activity in futures contract trading.

site_title: POSH shares stagnating since its mainboard listing
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) shares have stagnated since its mainboard listing in April, trading between $1.13 and $1.20. Despite being the year's biggest IPO offering in Singapore, investors have shown little interest in the stock. Macquarie Warrants, which listed call warrants on POSH, has expressed disappointment with the stock's performance. Analysts attribute the lack of interest to a high valuation and a muted market, with some suggesting investors are waiting for the company to sign contracts before increasing their confidence in the stock.

site_title: Modern Montessori aims to expand into Asian emerging markets
summary: Modern Montessori International (MMI) plans to expand into emerging markets in Asia, specifically Vietnam and Indonesia, with its first school in Vietnam set to open in the end of 2014 and a second centre in Hai Phong in 2016. The company aims to cater to foreign expatriates and young couples seeking quality pre-school education. MMI's expansion into Indonesia will be done through franchising and direct investment, with plans to strengthen teacher-training services. The company also plans to set up new centres in Sri Lanka and is considering an initial public offering.

site_title: EM recovery - stock selection is key
summary: The US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing program has led to a 12-month recovery in emerging markets (EMs) after a period of volatility, driven by geopolitical tensions, weak macroeconomic data, and interest rate hikes. Expectations of a mini-stimulus package from China and favorable election outcomes in key EM countries have contributed to the modest recovery. Fund managers Pimco forecasts EMs to outperform advanced economies over the next three to five years, with growth averaging 6% in EMs versus 2% in advanced economies, as investors increasingly turn to EMs.

site_title: Stricter tax laws may cause more to give up US passports
summary: US expatriates may be more likely to give up their passports due to stricter tax laws. In the first quarter, 1,001 Americans relinquished their citizenship, a 47% increase from the previous year. This marks a significant jump, with 3,000 expatriates giving up their nationality in 2013. The introduction of asset-disclosure rules in July is expected to prompt an estimated 6 million Americans living overseas to reconsider their citizenship. This trend is further fueled by Swiss banks' decision to turn over account data on American clients to avoid prosecution for helping tax evaders.

site_title: Computer memory shortage caused air traffic system failure
summary: A computer memory shortage in the US air traffic control system caused a recent incident in the LA area, resulting in delayed or cancelled flights. The issue was attributed to a common design problem that could have been exploited by an attacker, but replicating the exact conditions is difficult. The error affected a broad area of the southwestern US, from California to Arizona and Nevada. The incident highlights the vulnerability of the air traffic control system to potential cyber threats.

site_title: Penguin's Q1 profit surges on higher revenue
summary: Penguin International, a marine and offshore firm, reported a significant surge in Q1 profit from continuing operations, increasing to $7 million from $1.5 million the previous year. This growth was driven by a 55.2% rise in revenue, from $19.8 million to $30.8 million.

site_title: Drought, El Nino could cause spike in palm oil prices
summary: A drought in Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's top two palm oil producers, could lead to a production shortfall and a spike in palm oil prices. Analysts predict a double-digit percentage drop in production, which could be passed on to consumers, affecting global consumer goods prices. An El Nino weather phenomenon forecast for later this year could exacerbate the situation, potentially causing a 30% drop in production and further price increases.

site_title: TPV's Q1 loss widens to US$50.4m
summary: TPV Technology's net loss widened to US$50.4 million for Q1 2014, from US$4.8 million in the same period last year, due to a 3.9% year-on-year drop in revenue to US$2.56 billion. Weakening of emerging-market currencies and one-off restructuring expenses contributed to the loss. However, gross profit margin improved to 8.9% from 6.4% in Q4 last year. TPV also announced plans to combine innovation sites into a single site in Ghent, Belgium, and inked an agreement to buy Philips' 30% interest in TP Vision.

site_title: Counting the cost when things go wrong
summary: Shipowners face significant financial risks from ship casualties, with a potential "negative equity" trap looming. A recent warning by the Association of Average Adjusters cautions owners to control costs and maintain the vessel to prove their case, but this can lead to mounting expenses. A recent incident involving Evergreen Marine, where a £17,311.01 fine was imposed for spilling fuel oil, highlights the potential costs of accidents. Shipowners must be aware of these risks and take steps to prevent accidents to avoid financial losses.

site_title: A-Sonic, units likely to post losses for Q1
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace, a logistics and aerospace player, announced it is expected to post losses for the first quarter ended March 31, 2014. The company reversed a net loss of US$1.96 million in the same year-ago period, posting a net profit of US$212,000. Turnover slipped 19.5% to US$61.85 million, and earnings per share were 0.03 US cents. The company attributed the losses to global growth headwinds affecting its aviation and logistics businesses.

site_title: FCL unveils details of new trust
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) has unveiled details of its new hospitality trust, Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT), which will list in June. The initial portfolio of six serviced residences and six hotels spans Australia, the UK, Japan, Malaysia, and Singapore, with FCL expected to raise $651.7 million from the sale of the residences. The trust aims to provide investors with a diversified hospitality portfolio in key markets.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Asiasons Capital, an SGX-listed investment management company, reported a Q1 net loss of $1.95 million, compared to a net profit of $1.76 million a year earlier. Revenue increased to $3.39 million from $0.4 million, driven by higher media sales. The group also recently faced a penny-stock crash investigation.

site_title: KOP Ltd to focus on mixed-use devts in key China cities
summary: KOP Ltd, formerly SCORPIO East Holdings, will focus on mixed-use developments in key Chinese cities, including Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen. The company's $2.8 billion Winterland Shanghai project, set to begin construction in Q1 2015, will feature retail, office, residential, and hotel components, complemented by entertainment content. KOP aims to tap synergies between real estate and entertainment to create innovative developments, with a focus on collaborations and strategic partnerships to execute its ambitious plans.

site_title: What is the Singapore market's USP?
summary: Singapore's stock market faces a liquidity crisis, with low conditions and dwindling income for retail brokers. A consultation paper proposes measures to strengthen the market, but experts question the effectiveness of these short-term solutions. The Singapore market lacks a Unique Selling Point (USP), which is a fundamental problem hindering its growth. Despite efforts to revive the market, it remains moribund, with retail investors abandoning it in droves. The proposals may be a band-aid solution, rather than a long-term fix for the market's underlying issues.

site_title: Italy cruise survivors testify for first time
summary: Survivors of Italy's Costa Concordia cruise ship disaster testified for the first time in the trial of its captain, Francesco Schettino. Passengers reported panic, anxiety, and fear after the ship ran aground off Giglio Island in January 2012. Many suffered from long-term health effects, including panic attacks, headaches, and sleep disturbances. The ship's owner, Costa Crociere, confirmed it could be towed away in July, as representatives met with government officials to discuss the salvage operation.

site_title: China still has the most impact on S'pore companies' sales: poll
summary: China remains the country with the greatest impact on Singapore companies' sales, according to a recent survey. 23% of respondents cited China as the key factor, followed by Malaysia (17%), Indonesia and the US (14% each). This represents 68% of the 130 firms surveyed. However, China's influence has decreased among manufacturing firms, with only 19% citing China as the primary factor, while the US took the top spot at 32%. Rising business costs in China are attributed to the cause.

site_title: Carnival deploys fourth ship to China
summary: Carnival Corp is deploying its fourth ship, the 3,780-passenger Costa Serena, to Shanghai from Europe in April, expanding its presence in China's growing cruise market. This move comes as Royal Caribbean International also introduces its Quantum of the Seas to Shanghai, with Carnival aiming to capitalize on China's increasing demand for cruise vacations. The company's strategy includes customized touches, such as Tai Chi classes and English-style afternoon tea, to cater to Chinese tastes and younger customers who are active in social media.

site_title: Emirates not looking for stake in Qantas, says chairman
summary: Emirates chairman Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed al-Maktoum stated that the airline is not planning to buy a stake in Qantas, despite the Australian government's efforts to loosen foreign ownership restrictions. The partnership between the two airlines, which allows them to combine operations and share resources, remains unchanged. Qantas is seeking capital to recover from a significant loss and is exploring ways to raise funds, including issuing senior unsecured bonds. The airline's chief executive, Alan Joyce, has described the current conditions as "tough" due to increased competition from international airlines.

site_title: US developers take lead on school construction
summary: US developers are taking the lead in constructing schools for new communities, bypassing local governments due to tight budgets. This trend is driven by the desire for top-performing schools, which can increase home values by 10-20%. Developers, such as FivePoint and Newland, are investing in schools to attract families and boost sales. In California, where the trend is particularly prevalent, developers are contributing to new school projects, with some donating land and funding for schools in exchange for attracting buyers. This approach is seen as a cost-effective alternative to waiting for local governments to provide schools.

site_title: Flight-tracking on top of UN group's agenda
summary: United Nations aviation officials gathered in Montreal to discuss improved aircraft tracking, following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines' MH370 in March. This marks the highest-level response to the issue, which has been discussed since 2010. The failure to find MH370 in over two months has pushed the issue to the top of the aviation agenda. To address this, Inmarsat is offering a free basic flight-tracking service to airlines.

site_title: China's April data show economic slack
summary: China's economic data for April showed across-the-board weakness, with fixed-asset investment growing 17.3% year-over-year, industrial output 8.7%, and retail sales 11.9%. The data sparked calls for Beijing to ease policies to shore up growth, with some analysts questioning whether the official 7.5% growth target can be met. The central bank has asked commercial banks to speed up home loan approvals and set mortgage rates at reasonable levels, amid concerns about a deteriorating housing market.

site_title: Sell in May and go away comes with caveats
summary: The "Sell in May and go away" adage appears to hold true for Singapore's stock market, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling in May for 9 out of 14 years, according to a BT analysis. However, the strategy's profitability is limited, and analysts note that other factors, such as company fundamentals and broader market trends, are more influential. The correlation may not be fundamental, and other markets, like the US and UK, do not see strong selling in May.

site_title: Firms more pessimistic despite global recovery
summary: Firms in Singapore are more pessimistic about their business prospects despite a global economic recovery. The Business Times-UniSIM Business Climate Survey found that companies are concerned about rising cost pressures, particularly higher rents and wages, which are limiting their ability to cash in on foreign demand. This is the opposite of previous expectations, as firms were previously optimistic about the recovery. The survey's director, Chow Kit Boey, attributed the dimmer outlook to the ongoing cost pressures.

site_title: Goodpack's Q3 profit increases 20.2% to US$13.1m
summary: Goodpack Ltd posted a 20.2% year-on-year increase in net profit to US$13.1 million in Q3 2014, driven by 14.2% revenue growth to US$51.2 million. The company reported a 12.8% increase in nine-month net profit to US$39.4 million. Despite a lack of dividend declaration, Goodpack's CEO expressed confidence in the company's leading market position and ability to drive continued growth. The company also reportedly met with private equity firms Blackstone Group and Carlyle Group regarding a potential takeover.

site_title: Temasek plants US$500m seed to grow hedge funds
summary: Temasek Holdings is investing $500 million in a hedge fund venture with Dymon Asia Capital, allowing new funds to leverage Dymon's existing back-end support. The partnership aims to simplify the process of starting a hedge fund, which is often hindered by compliance burdens and limited capital. The first fund to receive money under the venture is the Port Meadow Fund, a global equity long-short fund focused on the Asia-Pacific region, with $150 million in seed money provided by Temasek and its partners.

site_title: No more taper tantrums
summary: US markets react to possible inflation bottoming out and ending of monetary tightening cycle, with a significant drop in long-term interest rates from 3% to 2.58% in May. Despite stalled equity markets, emerging markets and commodities have seen significant gains. The article notes that the author initially expected equities to rise, but remains supportive of emerging equities and Asia. Global growth has slowed due to unusual weather and monetary tightening, weighing on corporate results and equity performances.

site_title: Huge food cargoes to Iran stuck in transit
summary: Hundreds of thousands of tonnes of grain and sugar are stuck in transit at Iranian ports due to payment problems caused by Western banking sanctions. Ship tracking data shows dozens of ships waiting for several weeks outside ports such as Bandar Imam Khomeini and Bandar Abbas, with some cargoes representing nearly 2% of Iran's annual wheat consumption. Western banks are reluctant to finance humanitarian transactions, fearing penalties under US sanctions, and international trade sources point to difficulties opening letters of credit.

site_title: Abenomics' effect shows in robust profits
summary: Japan's corporate profitability has seen significant improvements under Abenomics, with companies like Hitachi, Sharp, and Nissan reporting robust profits. Hitachi's profits surged 51.1% to 264.98 billion yen, while Sharp returned to profit after three years, and Nissan's profits rose 14%. The weaker yen resulting from monetary expansion has contributed to these gains. However, analysts say further easing by the Bank of Japan is needed before stock prices resume their climb, and no further easing is expected until around July.

site_title: Cordlife's Q3 profit up 24.4% at $1.5m
summary: Cordlife Group's Q3 net profit rose 24.4% to $1.5 million, driven by a 64% increase in revenue to $11.8 million. The growth was mainly attributed to an increase in client deliveries and contributions from subsidiaries and Indonesian assets. For the nine months, net profit rose 49.3% to $14.4 million, with revenue growing 40.7% to $35.3 million. Despite a revenue decrease from the Hong Kong subsidiary, Cordlife remains optimistic about its potential customers in the region.

site_title: Not much hope in Albedo's Iskandar deal going through
summary: Albedo's $1.86-billion Iskandar land deal with Malaysian tycoon Danny Tan is unlikely to proceed, with shares plummeting to 1.3 cents. The deal's long-stop date is September 19, and indications suggest Tan wants out. Albedo had previously claimed no mutual agreement had been reached, but the company's steady share price decline suggests the deal is likely to flop. Other Iskandar plays, such as Rowsley, have had more success, with the latter recently announcing a net profit of $1.8 million for the first quarter.

site_title: Latest China property step seen as a way to fight graft
summary: China has introduced a unified real property registration policy to fight corruption, with a government agency to supervise registration of land, real estate, and other properties. Academics believe the system will deter corruption and help uncover evidence of wrongdoing, particularly among high-level officials. However, challenges remain, including concerns over data accuracy and the potential for officials to abuse the system. The policy aims to create a national registration system in three years and make it operational for information sharing in four years.

site_title: Super Group shares fall after reporting 19% drop in earnings
summary: Super Group shares fell 4.72% after reporting a 19% drop in first-quarter earnings to $17.8 million, primarily due to slower sales in its branded consumer segment affected by civil unrest in Thailand, its largest market. Revenue for the quarter slipped 6% to $124.6 million. The company expects market conditions to remain competitive in the next 12 months and will monitor developments in Thailand. Rising raw material costs and fluctuations in currencies will also impact its operating performance.

site_title: SATS exits deal to buy cruise centre
summary: SATS, a Singaporean airport and cruise terminal services operator, has terminated its $110 million agreement to purchase the Singapore Cruise Centre (SCC) from Temasek Holdings, citing "market developments" as the reason. The deal, which would have given SATS primary hold of the cruise terminal services market in Singapore, was expected to be completed once regulatory approval was received. The Competition Commission of Singapore has been informed of the decision, and analysts are puzzled by the sudden termination of the deal.

site_title: Aspial Q1 net more than doubles to $28m on fair value gain
summary: Aspial Corporation's Q1 net profit more than doubled to $27.78 million, driven by a $25.1 million fair value gain on investment properties. Turnover rose 36% to $128.03 million, with property business doubling in revenue to $63.4 million. The jewellery business recorded a $1.1 million drop in revenue, while financial services saw a 1.1% increase. Aspial expects "substantial" profits from development projects and its property business to continue contributing to revenue and bottom line.

site_title: MAS mulling over sale of engineering division: report
summary: MAS is reportedly considering selling its engineering division as part of its plan to return to profitability. The spin-off would allow the airline to raise funds to finance its core operations, focusing on passenger chartering. The sale could lower maintenance costs and attract strategic investors. However, MAS does not have a solid plan in place, and the move may face opposition from the employee union, which could impact the 4,000 employees working in the division.

site_title: Inmarsat offers free airline tracking service
summary: Inmarsat, a communications satellite operator, proposes a free global airline tracking service to address aviation safety concerns following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines MH370. The service, which will be implemented on 11,000 passenger aircraft equipped with an Inmarsat satellite connection, aims to provide real-time tracking and enhance safety measures. The proposal, announced ahead of an ICAO conference, comes with a one-time cost of $3 million per year. This move aims to boost global aviation safety standards and prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Rates for iron ore-laden ships seen jumping 70% by June
summary: Rates for iron ore-laden ships are forecast to jump 70% by June due to a global glut and cheap imports flooding into China. Bookings for Capesize vessels surged 47% to 90 a month, with freight rates expected to rise to $20,000 a day. This is driven by project expansions by miners like Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton, and a bear market in iron ore prices. Despite a global glut, Chinese growth and low iron ore prices are boosting the global dry-bulk market.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q1 profit increases 9.7% to $63.3m
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport operator, reported a 9.7% year-on-year increase in net profit to $63.3 million for the first quarter of 2014. Revenue rose 9.2% to $950.8 million, driven by growth across all business segments except car rental and leasing. Operating expenses rose 9.6% due to higher staff costs and fuel/electricity costs. The group expects revenue growth in Singapore and UK bus businesses, but decline in Australia's bus business. Despite cost pressures, the company's overseas operations accounted for 50.8% of operating profit.

site_title: OCBC offers cash transfer via Facebook
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a free mobile banking service, allowing customers to send up to $100 daily to any bank account in Singapore through Facebook, phone number, or email. The service, available via the OCBC mobile banking app, eliminates the need for recipient bank account numbers. The recipient receives a notification with a URL link to input the passcode and account number to receive the funds within 24 hours. This is the first bank in Singapore to offer this service, targeting one-time or infrequent transactions between friends and acquaintances.

site_title: Row over costs may hinder safety response
summary: The UN is leading a high-level effort to improve aircraft tracking amid concerns over the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370. However, a proposed EU rule to extend cockpit voice recorder recording time to 20 hours is being hindered by disagreements between planemakers, airlines, and pilots over costs and surveillance. Airbus and Boeing have expressed concerns that the rule could impose significant costs, while pilots argue that it could compromise their privacy and potentially be misused. The EU Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has defended its role in upholding safety, but faces opposition from the pilots' association.
