The event, inspired by the global phenomenon that started in Toronto in 2011, features activities tailored for Star Wars enthusiasts. This marks the first local version of the celebration, which has spread globally with fans commemorating the iconic sci-fi film series.

site_title: Penal experiment turns into riots and lynching
summary: A play about Singapore's 1960s penal experiment on Pulau Senang, where a riot and lynching led to the deaths of an Irish superintendent and three officers, is set to premiere. The play, "Senang," explores themes of brotherhood, redemption, and amnesty, focusing on two main characters: Prison Officer Daniel Stanley Dutton and Tan Kheng Ann, the assumed leader of the riot. The production, which incorporates dialects and classic texts, was inspired by the Little India Riots in 2014, and will run from May 15-25 at SOTA Studio Theatre.

site_title: Beerfest Asia '14 is bigger, better
summary: Beerfest Asia '14, the sixth edition of the festival, is set to return with a bigger and better lineup. Attendance is expected to double from 15,000 to 32,000, while the number of exhibitors has grown from 20 to 45. The festival will feature up to 400 different types of products, including ciders, whiskies, and wines.

site_title: Lloyds to sell US$500m of shipping loans
summary: Lloyds Banking Group agreed to sell $500 million of shipping loans from its remaining ship finance portfolio, cutting sector exposure. The deal is part of a trend of banks selling ship finance loans under pressure to boost capital to comply with stricter industry legislation. Many shipping firms defaulted on loans during the financial crisis, and banks are offloading risky assets at cheaper prices. The sale may be to banks such as BOA or a US hedge fund, although no specific buyer has been confirmed.

site_title: In stitches over politics
summary: The stage version of the popular 1980s British TV series "Yes, Prime Minister" is set to premiere in Singapore, with a new adaptation that incorporates modern elements such as Twitter and social media. The play, written by the original creators, explores the complexities of politics and governance, highlighting the human side of politicians and the impact of social media on their work. Director Robin Herford notes that the show's relevance remains unchanged, despite the passage of time, and that it can provide valuable lessons for real-life politicians.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Christie's Hong Kong Spring Auctions preview is set for May 3-4, featuring 20th-century and contemporary art, paintings, and jewellery. The preview includes educational events and discussions on art and collecting. Meanwhile, solo exhibitions "Explosion of Colours" by Justin Y and "Junk Anthropologies" by Ashley Bickerton are running at F A T Gallery and Gajah Gallery, respectively. The Shakespeare in the Park series continues with "The Merchant of Venice" at Fort Canning Park, and "The Rise & Fall of Little Voice" is set to premiere at the Drama Centre Theatre.

site_title: Art that transcends borders
summary: Thai artist Navin Rawanchaikul, born in Thailand but with a North Indian surname, reflects on his heritage in his art. His family fled India during the 1947 partition and settled in Chiang Mai, Thailand. Rawanchaikul's work, 'Places of Rebirth', combines elements of Indian and Thai cultures, showcasing his connection to both countries. This piece, created in 2009, highlights the artist's journey and the blending of his ancestral roots.

site_title: Wine goes from ugly duckling to fine feather
summary: A 2007 Bordeaux wine, Vieux Chateau Certan, has proven to be a fine vintage, contrary to initial assessments. The wine, tasted in 2008 and again seven years later, showcases its complexity and rich flavors, disproving the notion that it was an "ugly duckling" vintage due to poor growing conditions. This experience highlights the importance of tasting and not relying solely on vintage guides, which can be wrong. The article also touches on the concept of "face" in the wine industry, where serving a lower vintage wine to a guest can be seen as an insult.

site_title: Container lines agree to raise Asia-US rates
summary: Container shipping lines, including Maersk Line, MSC, CMA CGM, Cosco, and Hanjin Shipping, have agreed to raise Asia-US freight rates by $300 per 40-foot container to west coast US ports and by $400 to all other US ports, effective May 15. This decision was made by the Transpacific Stabilisation Agreement (TSA), a group of 15 major shipping companies. The TSA also introduced a $400 peak season surcharge, effective June 15.

site_title: Sunken ship removal project halted: report
summary: The removal project to refloat the sunken Costa Concordia cruise ship has been halted due to environmental concerns. The ship's owner, Costa, has temporarily stopped the project after the supervisory body requested supplementary information on the environmental impact. The project manager, Sergio Girotto, stated that the works will be resumed once the required information is obtained. The suspension is pending a decision on which port will scrap the wreck.

site_title: S'pore elite put on the glitz
summary: Singapore's elite gathered for the ICON Ball at the Shangri-La Hotel, showcasing art and fashion with designs inspired by Chinese traditional paintings, Japanese origami, and contemporary art. Guests, including local and international designers, such as Mary Katrantzou and Zuhair Murad, dressed in gowns and dresses reflecting the theme. The event featured a diverse range of styles, from modern graphic prints to whimsical accessories, highlighting the creativity and glamour of Singapore's high society.

site_title: Collateral-free OCBC loan for startups
summary: OCBC Bank has introduced a collateral-free loan for startups, offering expedited access to up to $100,000 with a one-page application and minimal documentation. The loan is part of the Spring Singapore-backed Micro Loan Programme, with a minimum 5.5% interest rate over four years. However, observers note that a personal guarantee is still required, which may deter some startups. The loan is more suitable for traditional small businesses, while venture capital remains a preferred funding option for many entrepreneurs.

site_title: Surbana looks to splash $120m on acquisitions
summary: Surbana International Consultants plans to spend $120 million on acquiring two or three companies in China and South-east Asia within the next 24 months to boost its annual revenue from $200 million to $500 million by 2018. The goal is to become Asia's urban solutions provider and compete with global giants like Aecom and Jacobs Consultancy. The company is targeting mid-to-large sized local design institutes and state-owned enterprises in China, as well as engineering and project management firms in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Make adherence to Corporate Governance Code mandatory
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been requesting listed companies to provide more information on executive pay, but many firms are not complying, citing confidentiality as a reason. The Code of Corporate Governance, which deals with executive pay disclosure, is not mandatory, leaving shareholders in the dark about senior management's salaries. Only 64% of mainboard companies and 24% of Catalist companies surveyed follow the Code's guidelines on salary. The SGX should make compliance with the Code mandatory to provide transparency and serve the interests of the market.

site_title: US Air Force blocked from buying Russia-made engines
summary: The US Air Force has been temporarily blocked from buying Russian-made rocket engines due to a court order won by SpaceX. The injunction, issued by Judge Susan Braden, prevents the Air Force and its contractors from purchasing engines made by a Russian entity controlled by Deputy Prime Minister Dmitry Rogozin. SpaceX claims the move gives a monopoly to Boeing-Lockheed's United Launch Alliance and funnels hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars to Russia's military industrial base. The decision aims to mitigate supply risks following Russia's invasion of Crimea.

site_title: Tight labour market keeps wage costs up
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported a tight labour market in the second half of 2013, with strong hiring intentions and rising job vacancy rates in every sector. This led to higher resident wage growth, which was also higher than its historical averages. Despite this, other labour market measures, such as unemployment and redundancy rates, were below their historical averages. The MAS warned that wage pressures will intensify over the rest of 2014, and labour chief Lim Swee Say predicted a tight labour market until 2020.

site_title: Guggenheim looks East
summary: The Guggenheim Museum has launched an exhibition of Asian works, "No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia," after a five-year collaboration with UBS to expand its collection. The exhibition features 36 works by 27 artists from the region, including Singapore's Tang Da Wu and Ho Tzu Nyen. The collection aims to showcase the diversity of Asian artists and practices, challenging traditional notions of national boundaries and cultural identity. The exhibition runs until July 20 at the Centre of Contemporary Art in Gillman Barracks.

site_title: Brisk sales at Commonwealth Towers on Day 1
summary: Commonwealth Towers, a 99-year-leasehold condominium project in Singapore, sold 175 out of 300 units on its first day, with more than 100 buyers in the process of having options issued. The units are priced between $1,635-$1,690 per square foot. The strong sales may boost market sales figures for the first quarter of the year, which saw a decline in launches and sales.

site_title: 'Hotel with a view' coming up at 19th-century NY skyscraper
summary: A $350 million redevelopment project is underway at 5 Beekman St in New York's Financial District, transforming a 19th-century skyscraper into a 287-room hotel with a condo tower next door. The Beekman Hotel, set to open in summer 2015, will retain some original architectural features, including a tall atrium and skylight. The hotel will offer modern amenities, including restaurants, bars, and event spaces, while the condo tower will feature 68 units and amenity spaces. The project aims to capitalize on the area's growing tourism and residential demand.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds (April 30, 2014)
summary: Key events and conclusions from the article include: Tesla's plan to expand robotaxi services in California and Arizona, FedEx partnering with Singapore's QuikBot for robot deliveries, and Popiah king Sam Goi making a mandatory offer for PSC shares at S$0.40. Asian markets continued their rally despite US President Trump's new threats, with even 190% tariffs failing to deter US shoemaker imports from China. Japan's elevator empire saw a 6,000% stock gain amid a succession crisis, while Vietnamese stocks surged as foreign investors returned under sweetened US trade terms.

site_title: How to keep Singaporeans working after 65
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged citizens to continue working beyond 65 to address the labour shortage in the country. The labour market is facing a restructuring drive, leading to more layoffs and slower job creation. To mitigate this, the government is pushing for re-employment age extensions and retraining opportunities for older workers. However, economists believe the full impact of restructuring has yet to materialize, and a strong pipeline of jobs is needed to support the economy.

site_title: China's April PMI increases marginally to 50.4
summary: China's factory activity increased marginally to 50.4 in April, according to a government survey, but export orders fell sharply. This data adds to concerns that the world's second-largest economy may not be stabilizing after a first-quarter slowdown. Premier Li Keqiang pledged to step up support for the trade sector, following measures taken in the past month. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 50.4, one of the first indicators of the economy's performance in the second quarter.

site_title: Big on beauty
summary: Skin Inc, a homegrown beauty brand, launches an aggressive campaign to offer customized skincare potions from Valencia to New York. Founder Sabrina Tan, 39, was frustrated with products not working for her skin condition and decided to create a brand that caters to individual skin needs. Tan aims to differentiate Skin Inc from global skincare giants, targeting busy modern women who value convenience and personalized products.

site_title: Hue and cry over love
summary: The French coming-of-age drama "Blue is the Warmest Colour" has been criticized for its edited version, which omits a key lesbian sex scene due to local censorship guidelines. Director Abdellatif Kechiche's adaptation of the graphic novel has been praised for its realism but has also been accused of being self-indulgent and exploiting the lead actresses, Adèle Exarchopoulos and Lea Seydoux. The film, which won top prize at Cannes last year, has received mixed reviews, with some praising its raw portrayal of life and love while others criticize its slow pace and voyeuristic nature.

site_title: Zooming in on events
summary: Upcoming photography exhibitions include "A Little Big of Me" at the National Museum of Singapore, "The Logic of Failure" at 2902 Gallery, and "Roots" at Objectifs Gallery. Meanwhile, the National Museum of Singapore features "Genesis" by Sebastiao Salgado, and the ArtScience Museum showcases "Annie Leibovitz A Photographer's Life 1990-2005". Other galleries, such as Art Plural Gallery, are hosting "Spurious Stories from the Land and Water" by Sherman Ong. All exhibitions are free admission unless otherwise stated.

site_title: PM Lee urges workers to keep upgrading skills
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong opened the Devan Nair Institute for Employment and Employability in Jurong East, a $300 million CET campus, to promote continuous education and training among workers. The campus aims to train 100,000 workers this year and provide job matching and career development services. Lee emphasized the importance of workers upgrading their skills to stay employable in an era of rapidly changing knowledge. The institute's opening reflects the government's commitment to investing in workers and helping them improve their skills.

site_title: Two-tier market still very much in evidence
summary: The Singapore stock market remains polarized, with large blue chips like UOB and SingTel performing well, while smaller companies like Han-Kore and AddValue have seen interest. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% for the week, despite a 9.9-point loss on Thursday. The US market experienced weakness, with internet stocks and tech counters declining, while European bond markets saw heavy selling due to concerns over Greece and the China-Vietnam spat.

site_title: Spidey sequel stuck in web of cliches
summary: The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is a generic superhero film that ticks all the right boxes, but lacks originality. The sequel to the 2012 reboot, it features Andrew Garfield as Spider-Man and Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy, bringing youthful energy to the film. However, the plot is marred by an abundance of cheesy one-liners and three villains vying for screen time. The film's reliance on campy fun and special effects, rather than new ideas, makes it feel like a lazy outing. Despite this, Garfield and Stone's chemistry shines through, making the film an entertaining, if unoriginal, summer blockbuster.

site_title: Sculpture frozen in Time
summary: Singapore artist Jeremy Sharma's solo exhibition "Mode Change" at the Michael Janssen Gallery showcases two bodies of work: large, eight-feet tall foam sculptures and grey paintings. The foam sculptures, inspired by dying stars, and the grey paintings, with their mirror-like surfaces, explore the concept of capturing time and bridging the gap between modern and contemporary art in Singapore. Sharma's use of non-artists and industrial materials reflects the times, while his goal is to create a dialogue and discussion of conceptual art in Asia. The exhibition runs from May 9 to June 13 at Gillman Barracks.

site_title: MH370 remains a mystery as Malaysia releases report
summary: Malaysia released a report on Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which vanished on March 8 with 239 people on board. The five-page report, submitted to the International Civil Aviation Organization, contained no new clues on the plane's disappearance. It primarily recapped previously released information, including audio recordings and cargo manifest documents. The report concluded that the plane likely crashed in the Indian Ocean, but a massive search has been fruitless. The report recommended introducing real-time tracking of commercial air transport aircraft to prevent future disappearances.

site_title: Airbus chief urges staff to vote in polls
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders has urged the company's 144,000 employees to vote in the European Parliament elections, expressing concern over anti-EU populists potentially harming trade and European integration. Enders hopes that radical parties will receive minimal support, while also calling for reforms to make Europe's economic model more viable. He emphasizes the importance of industrial and political leadership to address the challenges facing European industries, including the Ariane space launcher and arms export controls.

site_title: Another delightful opera evening in store
summary: The Singapore Lyric Opera's Opera in the Park is set to return for its seventh year, featuring a lineup of singers and classics, including Bizet's Carmen and Puccini's Tosca. The event, which has seen a surge in attendance since its inception in 2008, is expected to draw a large crowd to the Singapore Botanic Gardens. This year's cast includes Singaporean conductor Joshua Tan, soprano Cherylene Liew, and baritone William Lim, as well as new faces from the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts. Admission is free and the event will take place on June 7.

site_title: Asian debt is good way to get income, says fund manager
summary: A fund manager at JP Morgan Asset Management, Stephen Chang, says investing in Asian debt is a good way to pick up income, citing strong returns this year and growing investor interest. Asian debt sales hit a record in April, with investors putting $3.32 billion into bond funds in the week ended April 23. Chang expects fixed income to trade in a range amid a steady interest rate environment, with US 10-year Treasuries trading between 2.50-3.25%. This follows a bearish outlook at the end of last year, as investors return to the region with a more balanced view of the markets.

site_title: Parents stashed in her closet
summary: Roz Chast's new graphic novel, Can't We Talk About Something More Pleasant?, chronicles the decline of her late parents. The book is a humorous and poignant account of their long and precipitous decline, starting from 2005 when her mother fell off a stepladder. Chast's unique ability to filter normal life through her manic mind produces work that is both sui generis and universal. The book is a mix of primer, cautionary tale, horror movie, and documentary, and showcases Chast's witty and ruminative style. Her personal experience as an only child caring for her parents adds a layer of emotional depth to the narrative.

site_title: Late into the game for World Cup? Prepare to pay more for air ticket
summary: Late bookings for the World Cup in Brazil are leading to significantly higher costs for airfare, match tickets, and accommodation. Round-trip flights on Singapore Airlines can now cost up to $15,000, while match tickets are selling for up to $5,600 on online marketplaces. Hotel room rates in Rio have also skyrocketed, with prices reaching up to $800 per night. Those who waited until late to book have been left with substantial price hikes, with some fans paying up to $20,000 for tickets.

site_title: Around Town
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Magnum Spirits & Wines World of Wines 2014 is a two-day wine-appreciation festival featuring 23 wineries and 15 countries. The event, held bi-annually, will showcase over 50 wine labels and offer a wine fair, live music, and food. Upside Down Act and Tap Dogs are also performing at Parkway Parade and Marina Bay Sands, respectively. Exhibitions include "China Red" by Yu Nan Cheng and "Our Daily Life and Inner Voice" by Park Eun Sook. "Just One Shift" is a charity bartending event on June 4 at Bacchanalia, raising funds for Water to Wine.

site_title: US seeks disclosure of all fees flyers face
summary: The US Department of Transportation proposes requiring airlines and travel agents to disclose fees for services like checked bags, carry-ons, and seat reservations, making it easier for consumers to compare fares. The proposal also expands the definition of "ticket agent" to include travel websites like Kayak and Expedia, which would be subject to the same disclosure rules. Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx stated that the goal is to provide consumers with clear and accurate information, citing "knowledge is power."

site_title: Govt pushing to extend re-employment age: PM
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the government's support for extending the re-employment age beyond 65 to help older workers continue working. The government has already re-employed nearly 800 people above 65 years old. Lee emphasized the need for older workers to adjust to new jobs and pay, and for employers to adapt to the changing workforce. The government aims to amend the Retirement and Re-employment Act to facilitate this, but acknowledges the process will take time.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The government of Singapore is pushing to extend the re-employment age to beyond 65, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong encouraging older workers to continue working. Meanwhile, Surbana International Consultants is preparing to spend $120 million on acquisitions in China and Southeast Asia. China's April PMI increased marginally to 50.4, but export orders fell sharply. The Scottish independence vote has not affected the UK market, which remains optimistic about a Union victory. The Malaysian report on missing plane MH370 contained no new clues, while OCBC Bank has launched a collateral-free loan for startups.

site_title: Abbott should opt for incremental changes
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's budget proposals have sparked widespread criticism and backlash, with his popularity rating plummeting and the ruling coalition's standing in opinion polls suffering. The proposals, which include significant spending cuts and new imposts, have been met with widespread discontent, particularly among families and university students. Experts warn that the government's "user pays" system for previously universally provided services could exacerbate the issue. Abbott will need to navigate the Senate, where his coalition does not have control, and consider incremental changes to avoid further backlash.

site_title: M'sia industrial output expands at slower pace
summary: Malaysia's industrial production expanded at a 4.3% pace in March, falling short of expectations. Despite this, the country's growth momentum remained intact, with manufacturing output rising 6.4%. The slowdown is attributed to water rationing and slower exports. Analysts predict a GDP growth of 5.4% in 2014, with some estimating it could be closer to 6% due to construction figures. The central bank is expected to hike interest rates sooner rather than later due to economic and financial imbalances, including high household debt.

site_title: Cabin comfort to set Boeing 777X apart
summary: Boeing is redesigning its 777X jetliner to set it apart from competitors, focusing on passenger comfort and ease of travel. The aircraft will feature higher humidity, cabin air pressure, and improved lighting to reduce jet lag and improve air quality. The 777X, set to enter service in 2020, will have a 71.1-meter wingspan and will be designed to accommodate 400 passengers, offering a 10% savings per seat flown a mile compared to other wide-body jets. The redesign aims to meet or exceed the comfort of Boeing's 787 Dreamliner.

images.alt_text: A cut above: The 777X promises to stand out in airports for its 71.1 metre wingspan and tips that flip up so it can squeeze into gates that now accommodate the current, smaller edition. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Big financing demand from HNWIs
summary: Credit Suisse's Q1 net new lending in Asia Pacific was 30% of its total loans in emerging markets, driven by high net worth individuals (HNWIs) in the region. The bank's assets under management (AUM) in Asia Pacific grew 5% to 121 billion Swiss francs, while net new lending to ultra high net worth clients was 2.2 billion francs. Credit Suisse aims to continue investing and growing its business in Asia Pacific, where it has achieved significant profitability. The bank has also made strides in reducing costs, achieving 2/3 of its target 950 million francs in cost savings by end-2015.

site_title: Singapore to tap new technologies for 'smart' living
summary: Singapore aims to become a "smart nation" with the integration of new technologies such as driverless vehicles, fibre networks, and sensors. The government plans to develop "smart towns" catering to an ageing population, with initiatives including "Smart HDB towns" with greenery and cycling paths. The Communications and Information Ministry will create an Infocomm Media Masterplan, while the National Development Ministry will review the Sustainable Singapore Blueprint and enhance public housing estates with elder-friendly amenities. The goal is to create a "liveable city and an endearing home" with improved quality of life for citizens.

site_title: No relief yet to IPO drought: bankers
summary: The initial public offering (IPO) market in Singapore remains sluggish, with only one listing so far this year, the OUE Commercial Reit. Investment bankers predict a continuation of this trend, with more privatisations expected, particularly from companies diversifying their stake or selling businesses. New types of assets, such as toll roads and data centres, are expected to feature in upcoming trust listings, which will require a focus on asset quality, stability of dividend flows, and total return expectations. The market's volatility and mismatch in valuation expectations between issuers and investors have contributed to the flat IPO market.

site_title: European stocks could make 2-digit gains
summary: European stocks are predicted to make 2-digit gains this year, with a 10% earnings growth and 2.5-3.5% dividend yields, according to Threadneedle Investments' Dan Ison. The eurozone's recovery and relatively low valuation multiples make European stocks attractive, despite concerns over the euro's strength and potential deflation. Ison notes that companies in the European domestic market, such as financials and media, are more promising than mega-cap stocks exposed to international growth.

site_title: Scottish independence vote worries British firms
summary: The Scottish independence vote has raised concerns among British firms, with many hoping undecided voters will choose to remain in the Union in the September referendum. Despite polls showing a narrowing gap in favor of Union, some Scottish businesses believe the country can thrive as an independent state, citing its energy reserves, economic contribution, and potential for low-carbon technologies. Key uncertainties include Scotland's debt share, interest rates, and foreign investment, but proponents argue that an independent Scotland could establish a Scottish Energy Fund and maintain trade relationships with the EU and other nations.

site_title: Tiong Woon's Q3 earnings dip to $3.87m on weaker sales
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation reported a 1% dip in earnings for the third quarter, with net profit decreasing to $3.87 million from $3.92 million the same quarter a year ago. Revenue dropped 19% to $36.9 million, primarily due to weaker sales across all business segments. The company expects resilient demand for heavy lift and haulage from the oil and gas and petrochemical industries, particularly in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Modi on course to become India's next PM
summary: Narendra Modi is predicted to become India's next prime minister, with his opposition party and its allies forecast to sweep to a parliamentary majority in the country's largest-ever election. Exit polls, conducted by research group C-Voter, showed the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) led by the BJP securing 289 seats, while the Congress party is expected to secure just 101 seats. The results are due on May 16, and Modi's victory would allow him to push through his promised economic reforms.
